Results: We determine the average size of the vocal cord (sopranos: 0.71 cm 2 ; mezzosopranos: 1.20 cm 2 ; tenors: 1.58 cm 2 ; basses: 2.88 cm 2 ) and of mouth and pharyngeal lumen (sopranos: 15.8 cm 2 ; mezzosopranos: 14.6 cm 2 ; tenors: 23.6 cm 2 ; basses: 32.2 cm 2 ). The differences in vocal cord size between sopranos and mezzosopranos (P: 0.0641) and between tenors and basses (P: 0.0833) are tendentially statistically significant. The variation in vocal tract size during the ut-

Tuesday B A C D E F 327 terance of the vowel a between tenors and basses is considered tendentially statistically significant (P: 0.0833) while the difference between sopranos and mezzosopranos is not statistically significant (P: 0.6434).

We demonstrate a correlation between the vocal cord's surface and the vocal tract configuration and the vocal tessitura of a singer. Long vocal cord and wide vocal tract are characteristic of singers with low-pitched voice types (bass, baritone, contralto, mezzosoprano) while short vocal cord and narrow vocal tract are characteristic of singers with high-pitched voice types (tenor, soprano).

Correlation between Arnold Chiari malformation and sleep apnea syndrome (SAS) I. Thomassin 1 , K. Marsot-Dupuch 1 , V. Stahl 2 , F. Bourquin 2 , F. Parker 1 , P. Lasjaunias 1 ; 1 Le Kremlin Bicêtre/FR, 2 Bobigny/FR Purpose: To identify morphologic abnormalities on cervical MRI exams among patients suffering from sleep apnea syndrome and Arnold Chiari malformation. Materials and methods: 13 patients suffering from severe apnea syndrome (30/ mn) were referred for surgery of Arnold Chiari malformation. Pre-and post-contrast sagittal and axial T1 W and T2W images of the brainstem and cervical cord were performed. Were studied the cerebello-medullary cistern, the angle between posterior border of brainstem and cerebellum, location of cerebellar tonsilla, cervicooccipital junction and ventricular system. Results: Three brainstem abnormalities were detected (two isolated and one in a complex malformative syndrome). 9 patients have filling of cerebello-medullary cistern and a diminution of the angle between the posterior border of the brainstem and the cerebellum. Anterior translation of cerebellar tonsils was noticed. Discussion: Many authors have studied obstructive SAS which was partially explicated by laryngo-pharyngeal abnormalities. Associated transient ischemic attacks are well known. Our study suggested that abnormalities of brainstem may alter the function of respiratory nuclei and tracks and that brainstem abnormalities may be linked with sleep apnea syndrome. Conclusion: Sleep apnea syndrome may be associated with lesions of brainstem. Further larger study should be done to prove a statistical correlation. However radiologists should look for posterior fossa abnormalities when exploring patients referred for sleep apnea syndrome.

Comparison of differently viscous iodinated and barium-containing contrast agents in the detection of pharyngeal perforation M. Keberle, G. Wittenberg, A. Trusen, W. Baumgartner, D. Hahn; Würzburg/DE Purpose: Unlike in the investigation of esophageal perforation, the more radiopaque barium-suspensions are not as important as iodinated aqueous contrast agents for the detection of pharyngeal perforations. This study was performed to find out whether the highly different viscosities (of iodinated and barium-containing contrast agents with comparable radiopacities) are a reason for this. Methods: Viscosity, subjective difference in contrast, and CT-density of an iodinated aqueous (Telebrix) and a 50 wt/vol% barium-containing contrast agent (Micropaque) were determined. Moreover, to exclude postoperative perforation, 104 patients were prospectively examined by pharyngography using both contrast media. Pharyngographies of patients with perforation were later compared by two independent readers. All patients with perforation were followed up clinically to exclude complications due to barium-application. Results: In-vitro comparison showed comparable radiopacity but the 50 wt/vol% barium-suspension was much more viscous than the iodinated contrast agent. In total, during pharyngography, 14 perforations were clearly delineated with the iodinated aqueous contrast agent. However, two of them were not detected with the barium-suspension. All the other perforations presented equally. Conclusions: Given a sufficient radiopacity, a low viscosity appears to be essential for a contrast agent to detect pharyngeal perforation. Thus, we recommend the sole use of an iodinated contrast agent (if suspicion of aspiration as isoosmolar variant) for this purpose.

Percutaneous tracheostomy (PT) in the intensive care unit (ICU) using ultrasound guidance T. Geroukis, D. Voultsinou, A. Papachillea, V. Kalpakidis, P. Palladas; Thessaloniki/GR Purpose: To present the ultrasonographic investigation of anterior neck structures conducted prior to the performance of PT in the ICU patients. To determine whether the ultrasonographic contribution could reduce the complication rate and improve the outcome of these patients.

We studied 26 ICU patients, with an average age of 58. The ultrasound investigation was performed with bedside portable equipment in the ICU immediately prior to the tracheostomy, indicating the point of puncture and analyzing the relationships of the anatomic structures lying in the vicinity of the tracheostomy site. Results: In 13 patients the thyroid isthmus was extending over the TR1-TR2 space and in 8 patients a considerable isthmus thickness was calculated. Goiter was found in 7 patients whereas clinical examination indicated this in only in 3 patients.

The clinical examination was unable to evaluate by palpation the guiding points in 6 patients. In all these cases the anatomical relations required were satisfactorily visualized ultrasonographically. Complications included hemorrhage, pneumothorax and subcutaneous emphysema.

The ultrasonographic results influenced the decision for surgical or transcutaneous tracheostomy or surgical management during the procedure in three cases but small complications were unavoidable. With increased practice and better evaluation of the ultrasound results, the radiologist can play a vital role in the management of the ICU patient.

Possibilities of spiral CT in differential diagnosis of carotid chemodectomas G. Results: Chemodectomas were revealed in 23 pts, neurinomas in 8 pts and carotid arteries aneurysms in 11 pts. Among 23 chemodectomas there were 19 carotid and 4 vagal tumours. The analysis of data revealed that chemodectomas were characterised with early (arterial phase) pronounced (up to 200 HU) contrast enhancement. Sometimes a low density area can be seen in center of the lesion. Neurinomas are characterized with less pronounced enhancement (up to 100 HU). "Spots" and "stripes" of the contrasted vessels stand out against parenchyma in neurinomas. There was no significant difference (p < 0.01) of average density rates in arterial phase in chemodectomas (171.2 ± 45.8 HU) and in neurinomas (64 ± 26 HU). There was a simultaneous contrast enhancement both in aneurysm and in surrounding vessels. Additional information valuable for differential diagnosis was not obtained in venous and delayed phases. Simultaneous enhancement of tumor and carotid arteries gives the possibility of evaluat Ing their relationship and the involvement of carotid arteries in pathological processes. Conclusion: Spiral CT with bolus contrast enhancement allows differentiation of tumors and other pathological masses of the carotid space and allows a 3D-image of the area of interest to be obtained for surgery planning.

Acute calcific retropharyngeal tendinitis M. Tassart, C. Le Breton, F. Bahlouli, N. Szelei, J. Bigot; Paris/FR Purpose: To improve early diagnosis of an under recognized cause of cervical pain and stiffness whose initial misdiagnosis can lead to parenteral administration of antibiotics or even open biopsy Materials and methods: Two patients (1 male, 33 a; 1 female: 47 a) were admitted to the hospital with dysphagia, severe neck discomfort and fever. Lateral radiographs of the cervical spine were performed in 2 patients, computed tomography in 2 and MRI in 1. Using non-steroidal anti inflammatory medications (interruption of antibiotics), the two patients had complete resolution of the symptoms within one week Results: The calcification of the prevertebral muscle was demonstrated by CT for 2 patients and identified on lateral radiography in one case only. The soft tissue swelling was seen both on CT and MRI. Conclusion: Acute calcific tendinitis is an under recognized disease which can be initially misdiagnosed as retropharyngeal or nasopharyngeal abscess, leading to unecessary parenteral injection of antibiotics or even biopsy. The radiologist has an important role to ensure the definitive diagnosis: in our 2 cases, specific imaging led to the correct diagnosis. To test the hypothesis that the single testicular artery is low resistance, and two further arteries (cremasteric/differential) are high resistance, we examined the spermatic cord vessels in a cohort of healthy men. Materials and methods: Patients presenting for a scrotal US with normal testes and epididymis were recruited. The right and left spermatic cords were examined from the superior aspect of the testis to the external inguinal ring to locate the testicular, cremasteric and differential arteries. A 15L8w multifrequency (8 -13 MHz) linear array probe (Acuson CA) identifed each artery as separate, allowing a spectral Doppler waveform to be recorded. The resistive index (RI) from each artery was measured three times (right and left) and the mean calculated. The three arteries were labelled A (lowest RI) B and C (two higher RI). Results: 51 patients (median age 39 a, range 18 -79 a) were examined. The RI's on the right were: A: 0.71 ± 0.05, B: 0.82 ± 0.05, C: 0.84 ± 0.04 and the left A: 0.70 ± 0.06, B: 0.84 ± 0.04, C: 0.83 ± 0.05. A paired t-test demonstrated a significant difference of the combined right and left measurements for AvsB (p < 0.001) and AvsC (p < 0.001) but not BvsC (p = 0.3). Conclusion: Although it is not possible to identify a named artery in the spermatic cord, consistently one artery has a significantly lower RI than the other two arteries. This finding may be useful as an adjuvant parameter in the assessment of scrotal pathology in particular with patients with spermatic cord torsion.

Age related changes in testicular perfusion and serum androgen levels O.J. Sommer 1 , K. Kharom 2 , T. Zils 2 , H. Czembirek 2 , H. Pflüger 2 , E. Plas 2 ; 1 Innsbruck/AT, 2 Vienna/AT Purpose: To assess the peripheral vascular resistance of small testicular arteries in different age groups and to match these results with age and androgen levels. Materials and methods: 94 testicular units of 47 healthy subjects were investigated. According to age, patients were divided into 5 groups (30 -39, 40 -49, 50 -59, 60 -69, > 70 a). Using high resolution sonography (7 -13 MHz, Elegra, Siemens, Erlangen) including power mode we measured resistive indices (RI) and pulsatility indices (PI) of centripetal testicular arteries of the lobuli testes excluding mediastinal arteries. Androgen (testosterone, free testosterone, FSH, LH, sexual hormone binding globulin) levels were evaluated between 8 and 10 a.m. and correlated with age, RI and PI values. Results: There was a significant difference of 0.58 to 0.67 in RI (p = 0.025) and 0.94 to 1.29 in PI (p = 0.0005) values between young and old men. With the exception of sexual hormone binding globulin (SBHG) (4.8 versus 2.5; p < 0.05) no significant correlation of androgens with age, RI or PI was shown.

Our study suggests a positive correlation of age with the peripheral resistance of small testicular arteries, i.e. an increase of peripheral resistance with increasing age. SBHG showed a positive correlation with age, RI and PI values. The other androgens do not seem to relate with RI and PI values of the aging male.

Consecutive patients referred for scrotal US were examined with a 15 L8w multifrequency (8 -13 MHz) linear array probe (Acuson, CA). If a focal testicular lesion was identified, the abnormality was re-examined with colour Doppler mode (7 -12 MHz). Vascularity was classified into, (A) no intra lesional vessels, (B) surrounding but no intra lesional vessels, (C) Intra lesional vessels present and subdivided into (1) vessels crossing (2) disordered vessels (3) complete infilling. US findings were correlated with histology or findings confirmed on follow up. Results: Over a 24 month period a total of 2032 patients were examined. 53 focal abnormalities in 44 patients were found. The distribution of vascular patterns was as follows: A: 9, B: 5, C1: 26, C2: 9, C3: 2. 27 primary testicular tumours (seminomas, teratomas) were detected, 26 showing a C1 (criss cross pattern), a single well differentiated teratoma showing no intra lesional vessels (A). Nine patients demonstrated a C2 vascular pattern; 4 secondary tumours, 3 acute myeloid leukaemia, 1 chronic fibrosis and a single patient without histological diagnosis. The C1 pattern was present in 95 % of primary testicular tumours.

The presence of the 'criss cross' vascular pattern allows confident diagnosis of primary testicular tumours, although not differentiating seminomas from teratomas. With the improvement in probe technology, vascularity of testicular tumours proves to be an important differentiating feature.
Varicocele and venous insufficiency in left low extremity S. Deftereos, G. Alexiadis, G. Kafetzis, S. Touloupidis, J. Manavis; Alexandroupolis/GR

The aim of our study is to compare the rate of incidence of varicocele and venous insufficiency in left low extremity. The flow pattern of left common iliac, external iliac, common femoral and great saphenous veins were evaluated with colour Doppler sonography (CDS) in 32 patients (19 -22 years old) with clinically suspected left varicocele. The same veins were also evaluated with CDS in 15 clinically healthy voluntaries (same age range).

In 24 patients of the first group (32 patients with clinically suspected varicocele) when Valsalva manouvre was performed with the patient in upright position, flow reversed for a period of one or more seconds in left common femoral vein. Thus the diagnosis of venous insufficiency was made. In the second group (15 clinically normal males) normal findings were found in thirteen persons. In the remaining two young men the diagnosis of venous insufficiency were made. The CDS of scrotum revealed varicocele in both of them. On the basis of these findings and also because of the anastomotic branches between the veins of scrotum and low extremity we believe that a CDS evaluation of the flow pattern in left common iliac, left common femoral and great saphenous veins must be performed before surgical treatment of varicocele in order to avoid the possibility of varicocele recurrence.

Quantitative evaluation of scrotal veins by colour Doppler US in healthy population A. Cina, T. Pirronti, R. Foschi, G. Restaino, G. Oliva, A. Pignatelli, D. Ribatti; Rome/IT Scrotal varicocele (SV) is a very common disease of the male population. Presently, colour Doppler ultrasonography (CDUS) represents the most frequently adopted technique for confirming the clinical diagnosis of SV and for a treatment indication. Despite for several years CDUS has been clinically used in cases of SV, discriminating quantitative values are not reported in medical literature. This is at least partly due to the lack of studies of CDUS patterns obtained from large populations of healthy subjects. The aim of this paper is to investigate the role of ECD in instrumental diagnosis of male varicocele, the implications in selecting the patients who require treatment, and to investigate the risk of SV overdiagnosis by adopting the qualitative criteria currently used. We prospectively examined by CDUS a population of 150 healthy and symptomless subjects, with a negative clinical examination for varicocele, and a normal spermiogram. We found that the normal value range of the maximum diameter of scrotal veins (2.62 ± 0.53 mm) widely overlaps with the values currently accepted for a varicocele diagnosis (1.5 -3.0 mm). Furthermore, a venous reflux, a criteria adopted also for the diagnosis of subclinical varicocele, was present in 53 % of the normal population. These data show that there is a risk of SV overdiagnosis by using CDUS. The quantitative criteria for SV diagnosis should be re-examined. The patients group included 10 UVJs with grade I -II and 5 UVJs with grade III -IV of reflux. Urethra-to-orifice distance (UOD) and length of intravesical and submucosal parts of the ureter were measured. Results: In normal cases ureteral orifices were situated on equal distances from urethra, the UOD was 11.2 ± 2.8 mm (mean ± SD). The length of intravesical part of the ureter was 24.9 ± 6.6 mm and correlated with height (correlation coefficient 0.78), body surface area (0.73) and weight (0.66). The length of submucosal part of the ureter was 12.6 ± 3.1 mm and correlated with body surface area (0.85), weight (0.83) and height (0.82). The ratio between intravesical and submucosal parts of the ureter was 1.95 ± 0.3. There was no significant difference between the normal values and values of all 10 low-grade reflux UVJs. In 4 from 10 spontaneous resolution of the reflux during 1-year period was found. The grade III -IV reflux orifices (5 UVJs) were situated farther from urethra than opposite normal orifices, the UOD was 14.2 ± 2.5 mm. The intravesical part of the ureter was short (9 ± 2.1 mm) and submucosal part was absent in all cases. None high-grade reflux was resolved spontaneously. Conclusion: Ultrasonography is a valuable noninvasive method of examination of UVJs and may be useful in vesicoureteric reflux assessment.

Comparison of contrast-enhanced colour Doppler targeted biopsy to conventional systematic biopsy: Impact on prostate cancer detection F. Frauscher, A. Klauser, L. Pallwein, A.H. Schuster, H. Volgger, G. Helweg, D. zur Nedden; Innsbruck/AT Purpose: We investigated whether a limited biopsy approach with contrast-enhanced colour Doppler ultrasound (CDUS) targeted biopsy of the prostate could detect cancers as well as grey-scale US guided systematic biopsy with a larger number of biopsy cores.

We examined 230 men (PSA ≥ 1.25 ng/ml). Two independent examiners evaluated each subject. One investigator performed contrastenhanced targeted biopsies (≤ 5) into hypervascular regions in the peripheral zone during intravenous infusion of Levovist™. Subsequently, a second examiner performed 10 systematic biopsies of the prostate. Cancer detection rates for the two techniques were compared. Results: Cancer was detected in 69/230 subjects (30 %). Cancer was detected in 56/230 subjects (24.4 %) by contrast-enhanced targeted biopsy, and in 51/230 patients (22.2 %) with systematic biopsy. Cancer was detected with targeted biopsy alone in 17 subjects, and with systematic biopsy alone in 13 subjects. Overall cancer detection rate was not significantly different for targeted and systematic biopsy (p = 0.53). The detection rate of targeted biopsy cores (118/1139) was significantly better than that of systematic biopsy cores (123/2300) (p < 0.001). Targeted biopsy in a patient with cancer is 2.6 times more likely to detect prostate cancer than a systematic biopsy. Conclusions: Contrast-enhanced CDUS targeted biopsy detected as many cancers as systematic biopsy with fewer than half the number of biopsy cores. Although an increase in cancer detection rate is obtained by combining targeted and systematic techniques in this screening population, contrast-enhanced targeted biopsy alone is a reasonable approach to reduce the number of biopsy cores.

Intermittent contrast-enhanced ultrasonography for prostate cancer detection A. Klauser, L. Pallwein, W. Horninger, F. Frauscher, G. Helweg, D. zur Nedden; Innsbruck/AT Purpose: We investigated the usefulness of intermittent contrast-enhanced ultrasonography (US) in the detection of prostate cancer. Methods and materials: Nineteen patients with an elevated prostate-specific antigen level (³ 2.5 ng/ml) or an abnormal digital rectal examination were enrolled in the study. We used an i.v. US contrast agent (Levovist™). Continuous greyscale, intermittent grey-scale, phase inversion grey-scale, and colour and power Doppler US of the prostate were performed. Sonographic findings were correlated with biopsy results.

After US contrast agent administration we found significant enhancement on both grey-scale and Doppler images (p < 0.01). In 3 isoechoic tumours we only detected focal enhancement using intermittent imaging. Focal areas of enhancement were identified in only 1 patient (5 %) without cancer. Conclusions: Intermittent contrast-enhanced US of the prostate seems to be useful for selective enhancement of malignant prostatic tissue. Therefore, this technique may be useful for targeted biopsies. Power Doppler sonography was more sensitive in detection of tumoral vessels than PD sonography and increased PPV from 81 % to 87 %, NPV from 75 % to 82 %, sensitivity from 80 % to 90 %, specificity from 77 % to 86 %. Conclusion: 3D PD TRUS examination is more informative than PD TRUS examination in detection prostate cancer. 3D PD TRUS examination can be used as a diagnostic tool in addition to complex examination of patients with suspected prostate cancer.

TRUS CD and MRI with contrast agent in the evaluation of local recurrence after radical prostatectomy F.M. Drudi, S. Petta, A. Carbone, A. Righi, F. Trippa, P. Ricci, R. Passariello; Rome/IT Purpose: Aim of our study was to evaluate sensitivity of US CD and MRI, both with contrast medium enhanced, in the detection of local recurrence of prostate cancer after radical prostatectomy and to evaluate the specificity of these techniques in distinguishing recurrent cancer from fibrosis. Materials and methods: Twelve patients (mean age 64.4; range 56 -73) presented with increasing PSA values (> 0.4 ng/ml) in a variable period (mean time elapsed 3 years; range 3 months to 4 years). All patients underwent bone scintigraphy before and after treatment, MRI (Gadolinium DTPA i.v. 2 ml/s, 20 ml total. Flash T1 Fat Sat 20 slice thickness 5 mm), grey scale TRUS, TRUS CD (Levovist SHU508) and TRUS guided multiple biopsy. Presence of colour signal and MR signal after c.a. was considered sign of recurrence, absence of recurrence or fibrosis.

The results were compared to biopsy showing a sensitivity of 100 % and a specificity of 100 % for CD, while MR showed a sensitivity of 100 % and a specificity of 80 %. CD showed colour signal after c.a. in all positive patients. MR showed local recurrence in 5 patients: 4 cases had been evidenced already at CD examination and confirmed by biopsy, while one was a false positive. Scintigraphy detected distant bone metastases in 2 patients, one of which also presented local recurrence.

Conclusions: From this early experience we can say that TRUS CD with c.a. is a valid tool as compared to MR in the evaluation of local tumour recurrence in patients with rising serum levels of PSA after radical prostatectomy.

B-0094 10:55 Tissue harmonic imaging in the evaluation of thyroid nodules. Initial experience K.T. Szopinski, M. Wysocki, A. Pajk, R. Slapa, W. Jakubowski, E. Bialek; Warsaw/PL Purpose: To determine whether tissue harmonic imaging improves resolution between thyroid nodules and the adjacent thyroid parenchyma. Materials and methods: 50 thyroid nodules (1 malignant, 49 benign) in 45 patients (40 female, 5 male, age 20 -79, mean 49.3) referred for a fine needle biopsy were evaluated. The lesions were imaged using fundamental frequency and tissue harmonic imaging (THI) on a Siemens Sonoline Elegra machine using a wide-band linear 7.5 (5.1 -9.0) MHz transducer. Eight nodules were hyperechoic, 10 isoechoic, and 32 hypoechoic. The digital images were transferred to a PC, where the gray scale intensity of the nodule (IN) and adjacent parenchyma (IP) were measured using Adobe Photoshop software. The ratios IN/IP and |(IN -IP)|/IP were calculated. Results: The grayscale contrast was improved in 32 nodules, diminished in 18 nodules. The contrast change defined as |(IN − IP)|/IP was statistically significant p < 0.03. In 3 cases isoechoic parts of nodules became hypoechoic on the THI images. The definition of the nodule contour was improved in 26 nodules. Conclusion: THI may improve the definition of the nodule contour as well as the gray-scale contrast between thyroid nodules and adjacent thyroid parenchyma. FIGREF7.text: Hilar cholangiocarcinoma: Diagnostic accuracy and tumor extent with MR cholangiography H. Eun, J. Kim, T. Kim, S. Lee, H. Ha, A. Kim, P. Kim, M. Lee; Seoul/KR Purpose: To evaluate the accuracy of MR cholangiography in assessing the extent of hilar cholangiocarcinoma. Materials and methods: From January 1999 to August 2000, heavily T2-weighted thick-section (RARE) and thin-section (HASTE) MR cholangiography were performed on 89 patients with pathologically proven hilar cholangiocarcinoma. Hilar cholangiocarcinoma were proven by means of surgery (n = 17) or percutaneous transhepatic cholangioscopic guided biopsy (n = 72). All MR images were retrospectively analysed by two radiologists to assess the tumor extent (Bismuth classification). MR cholagiographic findings were compared with findings on surgery or percutaneous transhepatic cholangioscopy. Result: The sensitivity, specificity and diagnostic accuracy of MR cholangiography in determining the bile duct extent of hilar cholangiocarcinoma were 73.3 %, 93.3 %, and 89.8 %, respectively. The sensitivity, specificity and diagnostic accuracy of each Bismuth type were as the followings: type I (n = 13) of 92 %, 95 %, and 94 %, respectively; type II (n = 22) of 63 %, 95 %, and 88 %, respectively; type IIIa (n = 12) of 83 %, 83 %, and 87 %, respectively; type IIIb (n = 24) of 58 %, 99 %, and 88 %, respectively; type IV (n = 18) of 89 %, 92 %, and 91 %, respectively. Conclusion: Although MR cholangiography tends to underestimate the bile duct extent of hilar cholangiocarcinoma, MR cholangiography may play as effective diagnostic modality as one of preoperative diagnostic modalities of hilar cholangiocarcinoma. FIGREF26.text: Diagnostic accuracy and image quality of phase inversion tissue harmonic imaging (PTHI) compared to fundamental B-mode ultrasound (FI) in the evaluation of focal kidney lesionsT. Schmidt, C. Hohl, M. Blaum, G. Staatz, J.M.A. Meyer, D. Honnef, R.W. Günther; Aachen/DE Purpose: To evaluate if PTHI improves detection and characterization of focal kidney lesions in comparison to FI. Materials and methods: In a prospective study, 72 patients underwent both PTHI and FI ultrasound examinations in a randomly chosen order. Crucial technical parameters were standardized. Focal renal lesions (cystic and solid tumours, perirenal fluid collections) were documented regarding size, localization and ultrasound diagnosis. The ultrasound diagnoses were compared to the final diagnoses based on CT, MRI or surgery. Additionally, three radiologists evaluated overall image quality, delineation of image details and fluid-solid differentiation using a 3 point grading scheme. Results: PTHI provided significantly better overall image quality, delineation of image details and differentiation between fluid and solid structures compared to FI. 108 of 130 focal kidney lesions were detected by PTHI and were correctly diagnosed in 102 cases. 49 of 55 kidneys without focal pathology were correctly evaluated by PTHI (sensitivity: 83.1 %, accuracy: 78.5 %, specificity: 89.1 %). FI detected 81 of 130 and correctly diagnosed 75 lesions. It correctly characterized 47 of 55 kidneys without focal pathology (sensitivity: 61.8 %, accuracy: 57.7 %, specificity: 85.5 %). Conclusion: PTHI offers better fluid-solid differentiation, better overall image quality and an improved delineation of image details when compared to FI. The sensitivity and specificity of PTHI for the detection and characterization of focal kidney lesions is superior to that of FI. contrast media induced nephropathy: Experimental observations and the protective effects of calcium channel blockers Y.-X.J. FIGREF29.text: Using work flow analysis to compare multi-slice with single-slice CT U.K.M. Teichgräber, B. Clasen, C. Gillessen, J. Ricke, F. Knollmann, J.G. Pinkernelle, R. Felix; Berlin/DE Purpose: To compare the differences in examination times between a single-and multi-slice-spiral-CT. Material and methods: I. Application of project graph technique on 10 Chest CT examinations in singleslice and 20 examinations in multi-slice technique: 1. Definition of activities by observation of CT examinations 2. Time measurements of each activity 3. Development of a project graph 4. Calculation of operational measures. II. Multi-cycle process simulation using the data defined in steps 1 -3 including delay-factors for 12 patients. Results: I. A complete CT examination was defined from arrival of the patient in the CT area to written report dispatch including preparation, throughput and postprocessing. For the realistic pathway 48 activities were determined. Total realistic/optimistic examination time was 32 min 58 s/11 min 35 s at single-and 27 min 30 s/9 min 32 s at multi-slice-CT. Realistic/optimistic throughput time was 15 min 15 s/9 min 15 s at single-and 9 min 55 s/6 min 33 s at multi-slice-CT. Under realistic conditions the total slack for radiologists was 14 min 38 s with single-slice and 9 min 45 s with multi-slice CT. II. Total examination time/throughput-time per patient in the process simulation was 59 min 39 s/23 min 10 s at single-and 55 min 31 s/21 min 00 s at multislice-CT. Cycle time amounted to 43 min 30 s at single-and 35 min 52 s at multi-slice-CT.

FIGREF35.text: Spiral blood flow in the abdominal aorta: A predictor of renal function deterioration in patients with renal artery stenosis and renal failure J.G. Houston, P.A. Stonebridge, J.B.C. Dick, D.G. Sheppard; Dundee/GB Purpose: To evaluate the relationship of aortic blood flow patterns with renal function in renal artery stenosis. Methods and materials: 86 patients with chronic renal failure, were studied (1.5 T MRI unit) with phased array torso coil. ECG gated flow quantitation sequences in the coronal oblique plane and 3-dimensional contrast enhanced MR Angiography (Gd 0.15 mmol/kg) were performed. Renal arterial stenoses were classified as unilateral or bilateral, mild (30 -60 %) or severe (> 60 %). Renal function was followed at 6 months pre-and up to 12 months post-MRI. Results: 33 patients (20 male, 13 female) demonstrated significant renal artery stenoses greater than 60 %. Of these, 14 patients demonstrated aortic spiral blood flow and 19 patients did not. At follow-up 16 (48 %) patients showed significant short term deterioration in renal function. Of those with spiral flow, 4 of 14 (28 %) patients showed a deterioration of renal function with a mean creatinine rise of 55 µmol/l, while 12 of 19 (63 %) patients without spiral flow showed significant renal function deterioration with a mean creatinine rise of 102 µmol/l. These rises in creatinine were significantly different (p = 0.048). Conclusions: Spiral aortic blood flow patterns can be observed with MRI. There is variation in the prevalence of spiral flow in renal artery stenosis. Lack of spiral flow is associated with a significantly increased deterioration in renal function compared with patients with spiral aortic flow. FIGREF44.text: laringoscopy: Is it useful? S. Cirillo, L. Martincich, M. Bona Galvagno, G. Canale, D. Regge; Candiolo/IT Purpose: To compare virtual endoscopy (VE) with flexible endoscopy in patients with cancer of the larynx in order to define the limitations and the advantages of this imaging modality and to establish possible indications to its use. Materials and method: This double blind prospective study included 24 patients with endoscopically proven laryngeal cancer. Patients underwent spiral CT during IV infusion of contrast material according to our standard protocol for upper airway. This same set of axial scans was tranferred to a dedicated workstation to obtain VE images. Results of VE were compared to the findings of flexible endoscopy. Results: Exam quality was good in 23 of 24 patients (96 %). VE identified all vegetating lesions: two small flat lesions could be observed as slightly enhanced plaques only on the axial scans. Subglottic extension was correctly depicted in all cases by associating VE to the axial scans. Furthermore VE allowed evaluation of anatomical relations between pathological tissue and laryngeal ventricle and valleculae. Conclusion: VE shows high sensitivity in the identification of vegetating lesions of the larynx and, in adjunct to the axial scans, can establish relations of cancer with nearby structures. The imaging modality shows some advantages as it can be performed in the presence of severe stenosis that can not be by-passed by the fiberscope, does not require sedation and additional scanning. On the other hand VE show limits in the identification of flat lesions and does not allow biopsies and functional imaging to be performed. FIGREF49.text: Doppler studies in soft-tissue tumours: New non-invasive prognostic indicatorsF.G. Fuechsel 1 , J.M. Thomas 1 , E.C. Moskovic 1 , R.S. Adler 2 , J.C. Bamber 1 , D. Bell 1 , D.O. Cosgrove 1 ; 1 London/GB, 2 New York, NY/US Purpose: In order to find new non-invasive prognostic indicators, vascularity was measured in soft-tissue tumors (STT) using quantified power Doppler ultrasound (QPD). Method/materials: QPD was applied to 152 untreated lesions (131 patients) suspicious of soft-tissue sarcoma (STS). Histopathology was obtained in all cases. PD ultrasound was optimized for slow flow and continuous scans over the entire mass were performed. Off-line analysis with colour quantification software (CQ TM ) calculated fractional vascular volume (mean % colour Doppler area: m%CDA) and vascular heterogeneity (Standard Deviation %CDA: SD%CDA). Measurements were compared to diagnosis, grade, and lesion size. Results: Histology revealed 109 sarcomas (low grade: 23, intermediate: 31, high: 55) and 43 benign lesions. All lesions had a median size of 7 cm (0.5 -31 cm).

FIGREF61.text: Electron beam tomography of the left and right ventricle before and after partial left ventriculectomy for end-stage congestive heart failure C.N.H. Enzweiler, T.H. Wiese, A.E. Lembcke, D.E. Kivelitz, A. Baerisch, A. Radeljic, B. Hamm; Berlin/DEPurpose: To assess volumes and function of both ventricles in patients with congestive heart failure (CHF) before and after partial left ventriculectomy (PLV). Material and methods: 23 patients with end-stage CHF underwent electron beam tomography before, within 2 months (Post1), and 6 months or more (Post2) after PLV. Imaging was carried out in the short axis (50 ms per scan). Enddiastolic and endsystolic tracing of endocardial borders of both ventricles was carried out in a blinded fashion. Pre-and postoperative left and right ventricular enddiastolic volume (LVEDV, RVEDV), endsystolic volume (LVESV, RVESV), ejection fraction (LVEF, RVEF), and enddiastolic diameter (LVEDD, RVEDD) were determined. Results: Mean preoperative LVEDV, LVESV, LVEF, and LVEDD were 387.9 ml (± 125.5 standard deviation), 308.3 ml (± 112.3), 21.6 % (± 7.3), and 72.0 mm (± 10.6), respectively. Post1 and Post2 assessment of LVEDV, LVESV, LVEF, and LVEDD yielded 255.6 ml (± 79.3; p < 0.01) and 253.7 ml (± 97.8; p < 0.05), 180.4 ml (± 78.5; p < 0.01) and 174.6 ml (± 87.5; p < 0.05), 31.9 % (± 13.4; p < 0.05) and 34.1 % (± 14.1; p < 0.05), and 64.3 mm (± 8.5; p < 0.05) and 63.5 mm (± 9.4; p < 0.05), respectively. Mean preoperative RVEDV, RVESV, RVEF, and RVEDD were 177.7 ml (± 72.8), 117.4 ml (± 64.9), 38.1 % (± 15.4), and 50.4 mm (± 10.9), respectively. Post1 and Post2 assessment of RVEDV, RVESV, RVEF, and RVEDD yielded 172.4 ml (± 59.2; n.s.) and 178.9 ml (± 60.8; n.s.), 103.5 ml (± 58.8; n.s.) and 100.6 ml (± 44.8; n.s.), 43.7 % (± 16.3; p < 0.05) and 45.1 % (± 11.2; n.s.), and 48.1 mm (± 8.7; n.s.) and 48.5 mm (± 9.8; n.s.), respectively.Conclusion: PLV significantly improves left ventricular volumes and function and right ventricular function while right ventricular volumes do not significantly change. FIGREF66.text: 15:10 CT findings of early papillary necrosis and changes indicating progressive disease E.K. Lang, R. Thomas, R.J. Macchia, B. Gayle, F. Richter, R.A. Watson; New Orleans, LA/US Purpose: To assess reliability of CT findings indicative of papillary necrosis and manifestation of progression or regression of disease. Materials/methods: In 42 (23 M, 19 F, 17 -72 years) out of 380 patients investigated for hematuria multi-phasic spiral CT (pre-enhancement, early corticomedulalry phase, parenchymal and excretory phase) revealed findings suggestive of papillary necrosis. Predisposing medical conditions were diabetes (N = 4), sickle cell disease and trait (N = 6) and bacteruria (N = 8). All patients were followed with CT at 1, 3 and 6 months intervals and in some patients an IVU (N = 18) was performed. Results: Early cortico-medullary and nephrographic phase CTs showed circumscribed areas (6 -10 mm) of decrease enhancement in the tips of the pyramids. Follow-up CTs showed enlargement of 28 lesions in the parenchymal phase and demonstrated slough of the tip of the pyramids in 26 in the excretory phase. Calyceal diverticulae (excretory phase) developed in 4; retracted cortical scars in 9.

FIGREF67.text: spiral CT angiography (MSCTA) of the thoracic outlet: Dose reduction by anatomically-adapted tube current modulation and prospective dose saving I. Mastora 1 , M. Rémy-Jardin 1 , V. Delannoy 1 , C. Scherf 2 , C. Suess 2 , J. Rémy 1 ; 1 Lille/FR, 2 Forchheim/DE Purpose: To evaluate dose reduction in MSCTA of the thoracic outlet by on-line tube current modulation. Materials and methods: 50 consecutive patients undergoing MSCTA (collimation: 4 × 1 mm; pitch: 1.75) for suspicion of thoracic outlet arterial syndrome were evaluated with and without tube-current modulation, using the PDS option ("Prospective Dose Saving"; work-in-progress, Siemens Medical). On-line anatomically adapted tube current modulation with a predefined dose saving of 20 % (PDS 20 %) was applied during the acquisitions obtained in the neutral position (Group 1; n = 25; 140 kV; 140 mAs) or after postural maneuver (Group 2; n = 25; 140 kV; 170 mAs). The following parameters were systematically recorded on each series of images: (a) patient dose; (b) image noise; (c) image graininess and linear streak artifacts, graded on a five-point scale. Results: The mean percentage of dose reduction was 35 % in the overall study group. No significant difference in subjective image quality was found between the acquisitions acquired with and without PDS 20 % in Group 1 (graininess: p = 0.705; streak linear artifacts: p = 0.733) and Group 2 (graininess: p = 0.166; streak linear artifacts: p = 0.433). The mean value of standard deviations of CT numbers in selected ROIs, evaluating the image noise, did not differ between the acquisitions obtained with and without PDS 20 % in Group 1 and Group 2.

B-0419 16:45 The aberrant loop: a new sign of non-obstructive intestinal adhesions on enteroclysis A.E. Gasparaitis, T. Vargish, S.V. Kane, I. Hanan; Chicago, IL/US Purpose: Define and assess the value of an atypical intestinal configuration observed during enteroclysis in symptomatic patients suspected of partial small bowel obstruction. Methods and materials: Over the last five years double contrast enteroclysis (DCE) was performed in 84 patients presenting with recurrent focalized painful abdominal distention but minimal radiologic evidence of intestinal obstruction. All patients had a history of previous abdominal surgical intervention (open or laparoscopic). An atypical radiographic finding involving a loop or cluster of small bowel was subsequently correlated with post-surgical reports for confirmation.Results: In all phases of a DCE a fixed, aberrantly located, loop (or focal cluster of loops) of small bowel was observed in five patients. The loop was atypically situated relative to the conventional gross zonal distribution of the intestinal aggregate. All of the fixed, aberrantly positioned loops were in close proximity to abdominal surgical scars, as well as indicated sites of pain occurring mostly on abdominal distention. In all patients, lapratomic or laporoscopic follow-up confirmed adhesive peritoneal attachment of bowel at sites identified by DCE without evidence of flow-dynamically significant obstruction. Postoperatively all patients were symptom free. Conclusion: Demonstration and recognition of a fixed, aberrantly positioned loop (or cluster) of small bowel during enteroclysis in painfully symptomatic patients is a rare but diagnostically valuable sign for identifying clinically significant non-obstructive intestinal adhesions.

B-0460 11:40 Evaluation of bone marrow response in gaucher disease type I during enzyme replacement therapy using MRI L.W. Poll, J.-A. Koch, S. vom Dahl, M. Cohnen, A. Scherer, A. Saleh, U. Mödder; Düsseldorf/DEPurpose: Enzyme-replacement-therapy (ERT) arrests and reverses the hematological and visceral symptoms of adult Gaucher disease. The aim of this study was to investigate the features of bone marrow (bm) by magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) in these patients during ERT. Methods and materials: MR investigations were performed prospectively in 30 adult type I Gaucher patients before and during ERT with a mean follow-up of 3 years. Spin-Echo-sequences (T1/T2) of the lower extremities were obtained and reconversion (response) or lack of reconversion (non-response) to fatty marrow during treatment was analyzed. The morphological features of bm involvement, a homogeneous (type A) or non-homogeneous (type B) distribution of bm changes and focal bone lesions surrounded by a rim of reduced signal intensity (SI), were analyzed. Results: Overall, 19 of 30 patients (63 %) showed an increased signal intensity on T1-and T2-weighted images after 36 months of ERT, consistent with partial reconversion of fatty marrow during treatment. Focal bone lesions surrounded by a low signal intensity (SI) rim did not respond to ERT, suggesting bone infarcts. Out of the 11 patients with bone infarcts (low SI rim lesions), 82 % demonstrated the non-homogeneous type B pattern (p = 0.0021). In 86 % of patients with splenectomy, bone infarcts were seen (p < 0.05). Conclusion: In adult patients with type I Gaucher disease receiving ERT, treatment effects on bone disease can be demonstrated by MRI using Spin-Echosequences due to partial reconversion of fat marrow. A non-homogeneous signalintensity of bone marrow involvement and a status post-splenectomy correlated with the presence of bone infarcts.B-0461 11:45MR-characteristics of osteoradionecrosis of the pelvis in patients with gynaecological tumors after irradiation J. B-0465 10:50 Identification of articular cartilage lesions of the knee using water-excited 3D dual-echo steady state (DESS) MR imaging S. Waldt, K. Wörtler, A. Burkart, H. Rechl, E.J. Rummeny; Munich/DEPurpose: To evaluate water-excited 3D DESS MR imaging in the identification of articular cartilage lesions of the knee. Materials and methods: 41 patients who underwent MR imaging of the knee joint prior to arthroscopy were evaluated retrospectively. MR imaging was performed on a 1.0 T system (Magnetom Expert, Siemens) and included a 3D DESS sequence with a water-selective excitation pulse (TR = 25.7 ms, TE = 9 ms, FA = 40°, section thickness 1.5 mm, FOV = 16 cm, matrix size 256 × 256). The images were evaluated by two radiologists with agreement by consensus, and the results were compared with arthroscopic findings in 232 cartilage sites. Results: Arthroscopy revealed 82 cartilage lesions: four were classified as grade 1, 19 as grade 2, 41 as grade 3, and 16 as grade 4. In the detection of grades 1 and 2 lesions MR imaging had a sensitivity of 60 % and a specificity 96 %. Surface lesions grades 3 and 4 were diagnosed with a sensitivity of 96 % and a specificity of 96 %. The overall sensitivity and specificity were 77 % and 90 %, respectively. Lesions were graded identical to arthroscopy in 80 % of the cases. Conclusion: Water-excited 3D DESS MR imaging provides excellent identification of grades 3 and 4 articular cartilage lesions but appears to be of limited value in the diagnosis of earlier stages of chondromalacia.

FIGREF79.text: Evaluation of coronary artery bypass flow with MR flow mapping: A comparative analysis with intraoperative transient time flow measurement C. Balci, C. Duran, I. Sanisoglu, M. Sirvanci; Istanbul/TR Purpose: To compare MR flow analysis of by-pass grafts with intraoperative transient time flow measurement (TTFM) in conjunction with contrast enhanced MRA for the assessment of graft patency. Materials and methods: 20 patients (13 male, 7 female, mean age 67.90 ± 7.63) underwent a CABG procedure. Intraoperative TTFM was performed measuring maximum, minimum and mean flows. MR flow mapping was performed during the early postoperative period on a 1.5 T MRI system (Siemens Sonata, Erlangen, Germany). Breathing averaged phase contrast gradient echo sequence was used. Mean intraoperative flow values and mean MR flow mapping values were compared. At the same session contrast enhanced MR angiography was performed. Results: A total of 36 coronary graft flows were evaluated with intraoperative TTFM and postoperative MR flow mapping in 20 patients. Mean LIMA-LAD flow value (n = 14) was 40.59 ± 21.28 ml/min with peroperative TTFM and 51.44 ± 23.30 ml/min with postoperative MR flow mapping. There was a significant increase in LIMA-LAD flow values (z = 3.517; p = 0.000) and good positive correlation between TTFM and MR flow mapping values (r = 0.991; p = 0.000). Mean SVG (saphenous vein graft) flow value (n = 22) was found 21.78 ± 6.83 ml/min with peroperative TTFM and 27.16 ± 7.41 ml/min with postoperative MR flow mapping. There was also a significant increase in SVG flow values (t = 9.090; p = 0.0001) and a good positive correlation between TTFM and MR flow mapping values (r = 0.898; p < 0.01). Conclusion: Our data revealed good correlation between MRI flow analysis and intraoperative transient time flow analysis. FIGREF80.text: Coronary magnetic resonance angiography: The gold standard for determining the proximal course of anomalous coronary arteries R.M. Razmi 1 , A. Meduri 2, 1 , V.K. Rathi 1 , L. Natale 2 , G.M. Pohost 1 ; 1 Birmingham, AL/US, 2 Rome/IT Background: X-ray cineangiography has been considered the gold standard for imaging of coronary arteries, but it often does not delineate their proximal course in relation to the aorta or pulmonary artery (PA). Preliminary data indicates coronary magnetic resonance angiography (MRCA) as an effective tool in defining origin and proximal course of these arteries. We compared the accuracy of MRCA to X-ray angiography or transesophageal echocardiography (TEE) in 16 consecutive patients referred with a diagnosis of anomalous coronary artery. Methods: Patients underwent CMRA on a 1.5 T scanner (Signa CV/i; GE Medical Systems, Milwaukee, WI) After scout images, location of the aortic root and pulmonary artery (PA) was identified by means of axial T1w spin echo sequence; MRCA was performed by 2D cardiac-gated, fat suppressed, breath-held, segmented fast gradient echo images (TR/TE/flip angle 12/4/20°, slice thickness 4 mm), using axial and obliques planes. Results: MRCA images were reviewed and compared with X-ray angiography or TEE; consensus was reached regarding the exact origin and course. MRCA independently delineated origin and proximal course of the coronary vessels in all 16 patients. Coronary anomalies diagnosed by MRCA included right sided origin of LCA (n = 7), right sided origin of CLX (n = 2), slight anterior or posterior displacement of LCA (n = 2), left sided origin of RCA (n = 3), anterior displacement of RCA (n = 1), common ostium of LCA and RCA (n = 1). Conclusion: In this series, MRCA correctly identified every anomaly. This degree of accuracy qualifies MRCA as the imaging modality of choice for assessing coronary anomalies.B-0485 11:10Fast contrast-enhanced 3D MR angiography of coronary arteries: Visible length, detection of stenosis, rare indication, and limitations G.F. Bachmann, T. Dill, A. Kluge, C. Breidenbach, C. Müller, C. Hamm; Bad Nauheim/DE Purpose: Contrast-enhanced (ce) fast 3D sequences permit visualisation of coronary arteries and detection of stenosis within one breath-hold. We want to present our experience in 130 patients with coronary artery disease. Methods: 130 patients were examined on a 1.5 T unit (Sonata, Siemens) using a 3D FLASH sequence (TR 108 ms, TE 1.51 ms, flip angle 20°, 16 partitions, pixel size 1.5 -1.9 × 1.2 mm). Native 3D slaps in breath-hold without inversion pulse were used for individual adaptation of each slap on the course of the three main coronary arteries. Finally contrast medium and an inversion pulse (260 ms) was administered to improve vascular contrast. Compared to catheter angiography each coronary artery (RCA, RCX, LAD) was judged according to visible length, detectability of stenosis and limitations. Results: Visibility of coronary arteries was 16 cm for RCA, 14 cm for LAD and only 6 cm for RCX. Side branches over 2 cm were defined in 100 % for RCA, 87 % for LAD and 34 % for RCX. Severe stenosis (> 70 %) of the proximal coronary arteries were detected with a sensitivity of 78 % (RCA), 72 % (LAD) and 62 % (RCX). Rare indications for MR angiography include aneurysm, acute thrombotic occlusion and variants of origin and course. The benefit of fast ce 3D sequences in breath-hold are reduced acquisition time and motion artefacts permitting accurate diagnosis of proximal coronary artery stenosis. The limitations result from reduced spatial resolution which hamper visualisation of side branches and peripheral vasculature.B-0486 11:20Radiation exposure by multislice CT and electron beam CT in coronary artery imaging P. Hunold 1 , F.M. Vogt 1 , A. Schmermund 1 , G. Kerkhoff 1 , K. Ewen 2 , J.F. Debatin 1 , J. Barkhausen 1 ; 1 Essen/DE, 2 Düsseldorf/DE Purpose: To compare the effective doses of multislice CT (MSCT) and electron beam CT (EBCT) during coronary calcium scoring and CT coronary angiography. Methods and materials: Exams were performed on a 4-row MSCT scanner (Somatom Volume Zoom; Siemens, Germany) and an EBCT scanner (C-150 XP, Imatron, USA). Effective doses of different cardiac protocols were compared: calcium scoring with sequential and spiral (n = 2) technique on MSCT, calcium scoring on EBCT. CT coronary angiography with spiral technique on MSCT (n = 3), and EBCT. Dose measurements were performed using the Alderson-Rando-phantom equipped with 36 LiF thermoluminescent dosimeters (TLD) per exposure. Organ doses were measured and the effective doses for male and female patients were calculated using the ICRP 60 weighting factors.

FIGREF81.text: relaxation time analysis in patients with multiple sclerosis: Correlation with magnetization transfer ratio E. Papadaki, N. Papanikolaou, S. Karampekios, M. Spilioti, T.G. Maris, P.K. Prassopoulos, N. Gourtsoyiannis; Iraklion/GR Purpose: T2 relaxation time analysis and magnetization transfer ratio (MTR) have been utilized for quantitative evaluation of multiple sclerosis (MS) plaques. The purpose of the current study was to perform T2 relaxation time measurements in MS patients and correlate them with magnetization transfer ratio measurements. Materials and methods: A total number of 291 measurements including lesions, normal appearing white matter (NAWM), dirty white matter (DWM) and normal white matter (NWM) were performed on thirteen patients and 10 normal volunteers. MTR and T2 relaxation times of NAWM, DWM and lesions in patients and NWM in volunteers were calculated and linear regression analysis was applied between all subgroups.

FIGREF85.text: of healthcare information: Quality assurance of exam optimisation with automatic transfer of exposure dose parameters into the electronic patient record H.M. Mosser, G. Pärtan, A. Maltsidis, W. Hruby; Vienna/AT Purpose: To present the clinical results of integrating healthcare information by automatic transfer of exposure dose parameters from imaging devices into the electronic patient record.Methods: Due to an inhouse development in the filmless radiology department of a 1000-bed hospital, dose area product for Fluro-and Radiography, and Dose Length product for CT are automatically recorded and transfered into the radiology information system. Results: So far the coupling of imaging modalities with the RIS has been successfully tested in clinical operation with 3000 fluroscopic examinations on 3 different devices. Depending if dose parameters are included in the DICOM header or not, two solutions have been developed. When included, PACS and RIS communicate via their common database. If data are not contained in the DICOM header, the ionization chamber is connected to the RIS by a data cable (serial RS232 interface). A background process records and stores all incoming data in a communication file. The results show that due to this coupling the technicians and radiologists become much more aware of the quality assurance and the optimization of radiological exams. Conclusion: The automatic coupling of exposure dose parameters with the electronic patient record is an important step in the integration of healthcare information. It (1) fullfills the requirements of the EURATOM directive 97/43 of the European Union in regard to medical radiation protection, (2) increases the awareness of technicians and radiologists for dose and exam optimization, and is (3) part of a quality assurance program of a radiology department.B-0502 10:40Methodology and outcome of the multi-step evaluation of providers for a multi-hospital PACS project O. Handgrätinger 1 , T. Boehm 1 , J. Link 2 , R. Ploner 1 , D.R. Voellmy 1 , B. Marincek 1 ; 1 Zürich/CH, 2 Winterthur/CH Purpose: PACS has to fulfill complex clinical requirements, which make an objective evaluation difficult. We present a multi-step evaluation procedure worked out for a large PACS project in the greater area of Zurich. Methods and materials: 3 major public hospitals decided to launch a joint PACS project -TriPACS -in November 1999. Evaluation consisted of 3 major steps:(1) Pre-qualification. (2) Evaluation of qualified vendors in 6 sub-steps: (2.1) Matching the "Request for proposal" (RFP, 25 %), (2.2) Price/effectiveness (25 %), (2.3) Symposium presentations, (2.4) PACS hands-on workshops, (2.5) Reference site visits (2.3. -2.5. together 25 %), (2.6) Integration into the existing environment (25 %). (3) Preliminary project: Evaluation will result in the qualification of one vendor for a preliminary project consisting of a mini-PACS installation. This includes the connection of 3 imaging modalities in every hospital, with full integration of the image distribution software into the electronic patient records of the three hospitals. Results: 32 companies requested the questionnaire for pre-qualification after the official announcement. 16 companies returned the questionnaire and 6 companies qualified for further evaluation: Agfa (Mortsel, Belgium), General Electric (Milwaukee, USA), Image Devices (Taunusstein, Germany), Philips (Netherlands), Siemens (Erlangen, Germany), Fuji (Düsseldorf, Germany). FUJI decided not to take part in the further evaluation. For legal reasons, the rating of the qualified vendors (major step 2) cannot be published before November 2001. Conclusion: We present a multi-step evaluation procedure for the objective evaluation of PACS providers. Questionnaires for the evaluation steps are presented and discussed.B-0503 10:45Fully digital radiology: The first department implemented in China Y. Tao, J. Miao, H. Xu, J. Zhang, J. Zhu, R. FIGREF87.text: Maynar (Las Palmas de G.C./ES) D.K. Tsetis (Iraklion/GR) B-0512 10:30 In vitro evaluation of artifacts and lumen visibility of iliac artery stents in multislice CT-angiography D.C. Maintz, R. Fischbach, K.-U. Jürgens, W.L. Heindel; Münster/DEPurpose: To evaluate the imaging characteristics of various iliac artery stents in a multislice CT angiography (MSCTA) phantom study. Methods: Fifteen stents made of different materials (steel, nitinol, tantalum, cobalt alloy) were implanted in plastic tubes with an 8 mm inner diameter filled with iodinated contrast medium diluted to 200 HU. To evaluate the influence of scan parameters on artifacts the Palmaz stent as one example was scanned using a four slice scanner (Siemens VolumeZoom) with different detector collimations and pitches. All other stents were examined with a collimation of 4 × 1 mm and a table feed of 4 mm/rotation. Axial images and multiplanar reformations were evaluated regarding artifact size, lumen visibility and intraluminal attenuation values. Results: Higher pitch values caused more pronounced artifacts. Image quality and delineation of the stent struts improved with thinner detector collimation. The size of the stent related artifacts and the visibility of the stent lumen depended on the underlying stent material and design. Pronounced artifacts, resulting in an insufficient delineation of the stent lumen, were caused by the Strecker tantalum stent and the Zenith stent. Medium artifacts were caused by the Wallgraft, Passager, Bridge and ZA-stent. Some artificial lumen narrowing, but good lumen delineation was seen with: Strecker nitinol, Symphony, Memotherm, SMART, Corinthian and Wallstent. Conclusions: Scanning parameters, stent material and stent design influence lumen assesibility and image quality in MSCTA. Detailed lumen assessment is impossible in the Strecker tantal and Zenith stent, limited in the Wallgraft, Passager, Bridge and ZA-stent but feasible in all other examined products.B-0513 10:40 A new balloon-expandable active magnetic resonance imaging stent (AMRIS): In vivo results using MR angiography and flow measurements with local signal amplification D.E. FIGREF90.text: Simulation of the heart action: A computer controlled module for the generation of variable flow patterns R. Huttary, M. Verius, G. Bodner, W. Recheis; Innsbruck/AT Purpose: The development of a computer controlled pump for the generation of variable flow patterns with high reproducibility for simulating the hemodynamics in the human blood circuit. Material and methods: The module is controlled by an arbitrary function generator. The shape of the flow profile is generated on the PC with mathematical functions or drawn by hand. The amplified signal drives a strong DC motor which drives a magnet-coupled gear pumphead. The mechanical decoupling ensures a quiet running and a complete attenuation of vibrations caused by the motor and a disturbance-free flow profile. The spectra were analyzed dopplersonographically with a 12 MHz linear probe and with pressure sensors. Silicon tubes were used as vessel simulation and a water glycerine mixture with particles of cellulosis as simulated blood. Results: The generated flow patterns (constant flow and multi phase patterns) correlate highly with the measured pressure and velocity profiles. Conclusion: The variability and high reproducibility of the flow profiles and the real time control of the signal parameters suggest it is possible to simulate the dynamic processes and carry out hemodynamic longtime studies. The developed module enables detailed studies with physiological and pathological flow models and simulated blood with high reproducibility.B-0520 11:45Demographic data on 729 patients (multicenter registry) after angioplasty of peripheral atheromatous lesions S. FIGREF91.text: and management of complications of MR-guided laserinduced thermotherapy (LITT): Experience with 10692 laser applications in 2629 lesions in 943 patients M.G. Mack, R. Straub, O. Söllner, K. Eichler, D. Woitaschek, T.J. Vogl; Frankfurt a. Main/DE Purpose: To evaluate complications and local tumor control rate after MR-guided LITT of primary and secondary liver tumors. Methods and materials: Between June 1993 and August 2001 a total of 10692 laser applications were performed in 2629 lesions in 943 consecutive patients with a total of 2207 treatment sessions. The complications of the procedure were evaluated by clinical examination and MR/CT imaging. The local tumor control was evaluated by plain and contrast enhanced follow-up scans using T1 and T2 weighted SE and GRE sequences every 3 months after the treatment. Results: The overall rate of complications and side effects was 8.0 %. The rate of clinically relevant complications was 1.1 %. The most common side effect of LITT treatment was a reactive pleural effusion (7.9 %), drainage was necessary in 0.8 %. Intrahepatic abscess were observed in 0.7 % and one pleura empyema in 0.1 %, both treated by drainage. An subcapsular hematoma was found in 3.2 %, intrahepatic bleeding in 0.1 % and intrabdominal bleeding in 0.2 %. All required no further treatment. Further complications: local infection in 0.3 % and injury to bile duct in 0.1 %. Three patients died within 30 days, however only one was possible LITT related. Conclusion: In patients with liver tumors, local tumor destruction using minimally invasive percutaneous MR-guided LITT is a safe therapy method with a very low complication rate. Possible complications can be easily managed by an interventional radiologist. Materials and methods: 32 patients with 42 HCC nodules, 1 -5 cm in diameter, underwent contrast-enhanced US before and after RF ablation (RITA Medical Systems). US examination was performed using C3-mode (Technos, Esaote Biomedica) with 1.4 mechanical index coupled with intermittent imaging after a bolus injection of 2.5 g Levovist (Schering AG) at a concentration of 400 mg/ml. FIGREF96.text: Assessment of foetal lung volume development with MRI in sheep with tracheal occlusion U. Wedegärtner, M. Tchirikov, C.R. Habermann, P. Steiner, G.B. Adam, H.J. Schröder; Hamburg/DE Purpose:To investigate the accuracy of MRI in the determination of foetal lung volumes (FLV) in sheep using autopsy as a standard of reference, and to additionally assess the difference in foetal lung growth with and without tracheal occlusion. Material and methods: Seven anaesthetized ewes with singleton fetuses, three with and four without surgical tracheal occlusion, underwent MR imaging using True FISP sequences in a coronal and transversal orientation at 1.5 T. MR imaging was performed 1 -4 times in intervals of 1 -2 weeks between 92 and 141 gestational days. The estimated MR FLV were compared with FLV measurements obtained at post mortem examination. MR FLV in foetuses with and without tracheal occlusion were correlated with the time after surgery. Results: FLV in foetuses with tracheal occlusion increased more with gestational age than in control foetuses (18.0 ml/d, ci 95: 8.2 -27.8; 3.5 ml/d, ci 95: 1.1 -6.0 respectively). No differences in lung volume determination based on coronal or transverse MR images were observed (r = 0.99; slope 1.0). The calculated FLV's on MRI and post mortem examinations showed a high correlation (r 2 = 0.9). However, FLV measured by MRI was approximately 50 ml higher than in post mortem examinations. Conclusion: MRI is accurate in the determination of FLV. Higher lung volumes in MRI may be partly explained with fluid loss in post mortem examinations. MRI allows measurement of lung volume development in foetal sheep with tracheal occlusion.Haemorrhage after percutaneous renal surgery: treatment by transcatheter embolisation C. Vignali, R. Cioni, P. Petruzzi, I. Bargellini, A. Cicorelli, S. Lonzi, C. Bartolozzi; Pisa/IT Purpose: Percutaneous renal surgery has become the standard technique for a number of renal pathologies. Haemorrhage and vascular lesions are the most serious complications. We report our experience with 14 patients treated by selective embolisation performed between 1993 and 2001. Material and methods: Fourteen patients (9 males and 5 females) with a mean age of 58 years had severe peri-operative haemorrhage after percutaneous renal surgery (mean time to onset: 15 days), due to major renal arterial injury, presented by arteriovenous fistulae (n = 6) and pseudoaneurysms (n = 8). Four patients showed transient renal disfunction, with an increase in serum creatinine levels. One patient had a solitary transplanted kidney. Results: Renal arteriography was performed, followed by hyperselective arterial embolisation, obtaining a successful control of the renal or retroperitoneal hemorrhage, in all cases. Renal function was unaffected in all 10 patients with normal serum creatinine level and normalized in the other 4 patients with transient renal failure. No major complications occurred after the procedure. Conclusion: Renal arterial haemorrhage following percutaneous surgery is a rare but severe complication. Selective renal artery embolisation, with either particles or coils, represents the first-choice treatment option, being safe and effective in solving the bleeding.B-0542 10:40 Duplex resistive index: Is it a valuable tool in predicting the outcome of percutaneous treatment of renal artery stenosis? Sidhu; London/GB Introduction: Vascular injuries occur following urological laparoscopic procedures, predominantly consequent to damage of the inferior epigastric artery (IEA) and aortic bifurcation (AB). We have investigated the use of combined CT and US to modify the surgical approach to minimise the risk of vascular complications. Materials and methods: 200 randomly selected abdominal/pelvic post-contrast CT scans were assessed for the site of the umbilicus (mobile point) and anterior superior iliac spine (ASIS, fixed point). These two points were related by measurement to the position of the AB and iliac venous confluence (IV). The angle of the umbilicus to the AB/IV was measured. A further 89 patients were assessed for the position and course of the IEA using US (15L Linear array probe, Acuson CA).

FIGREF112.text: syndesmotic impingement of the ankle: MR imaging findings and arthroscopic correlation G.J. Schaffler 1 , P.F.J. Tirman 1 , D.W. Stoller 1 , C. Ceballos 2 , M.F. Dillingham 2 , H.K. Genant 1 ; 1 San Francisco, CA/US, 2 Menlo Park, CA/US Purpose: This study investigated the MR imaging findings in ankles with an impingement syndrome of the distal tibiofibular syndesmosis. Subjects and methods: 22 ankles with chronic pain and delayed recovery after a supination and external rotation trauma were examined by MR imaging. The soft tissue, ligamentous and osseous structures of the ankle joint were evaluated. Arthroscopy was subsequently performed in all patients and correlated with MR imaging findings. Results: In patients with syndesmotic impingement, MR imaging showed thickened and scarred syndesmotic ligaments with intermediate to low signal intensity on T1 and T2-weighted images. Out of 22 ankles, MR imaging identified soft tissue impingement due to posttraumatic granulation and scar tissue around 15 anterior tibiofibular, 9 interosseous tibiofibular and 5 posterior tibiofbular ligaments. In addition, MR imaging identified findings such as osteochondral lesions, loose bodies, bony spurs, cysts, fractures of the fibula or tibia and sprains of the syndesmotic and collateral ligaments. Conclusion: MR imaging has the capablity to identify posttraumatic alterations of the distal tibiofibular syndesmosis related with symptomatic soft tissue impingement and thus may provide the referring physician with important information regarding the management of these patients. CT appears, in our experience, is the better technique in the depiction of morphological bone alterations, while MRI has diagnostic supremacy in the identification of synchondrosis and/or synostosis B-0592 09:20 Morton neuroma: MR imaging in prone, supine and upright weight-bearing body positions D. Weishaupt, K. Treiber, H.-P. Kundert, J.K. Willmann, H. Zollinger, P. Vienne, J. Hodler, B. Marincek, M. Zanetti; Zürich/CH Purpose: To assess the effect of prone, supine, and upright weight-bearing body positions on visibility, position, shape and size of Morton neuroma during MR imaging. Materials and methods: 18 patients with a total of 20 Morton neuromas underwent MR imaging of the forefoot in the prone, supine and upright weight-bearing positions. Visibility, the position relative to the metatarsal bone, shape, and transverse diameter of Morton neuromas were assessed on transverse T1-weighted MR images obtained in different body positions. Results: In the prone position, visibility of all 20 Morton neuromas was rated with the highest possible score of 3 (good visibility); visibility of the Morton neuromas on MR images obtained in the supine and weight-bearing positions was inferior (mean score, 2.4). 20/20 Morton neuromas (100 %) changed their position relative to the metatarsal bone between the prone and supine, and between prone and weight-bearing body positions. When compared to the prone position, there was a difference in shape of all 20 Morton neuromas in the weight-bearing position (P < 0.001). Between the prone and supine positions, the transverse diameter of Morton neuroma significantly decreased by 1.5 mm (P = 0.03); between the prone and weight-bearing positions, the decrease of the mean transverse diameter of Morton neuroma reached nearly statistical significance (difference, 1.4 mm; P = 0.05). Conclusion: Morton neuroma appears significantly different during MR imaging in prone, supine or weight-bearing body positions. Visibility of Morton neuroma is best on MR images obtained in the prone position. FIGREF126.text: Significance of the lack of communication between the radiocarpal and pisotriquetral joints: Study with arthro CT in 125 patientsA. Chevrot, E. Pessis, J.-L. Drapé, F. Bach, D. Godefroy; Paris/FR Introduction: Communication between the radiocarpal joint (RCJ) and the pisotriquetral joint (PTJ) is common finding, occurring in up to 75 % of wrists. The lack of communication (25 %) is considered as normal variant. The purpose of this paper is to correlate this communication with other disorders of the wrist. Material and methods: 125 patients underwent a three-compartment CT-arthrography of the wrist. Communication between RCJ and PTJ was correlated with others athrographic disorders:• communicating defect of the scapholunate and lunotriquetral ligaments;• state of the triangular fibro cartilage complex (TFCC); • osteoarthritis of PTJ and RCJ; • ulnar variance;• clinical findings. A simple procedure for direct PTJ arthrography and steroid injection was also used. Results: Communication was statistically correlated with:• age of the patient (p = 0.049),• communicating defect of the lunotriquetral ligament (p = 0.023). Communication was a very sensitive (Se = 96 %) but not specific (Sp = 27 %) finding of communicating defect of the lunotriquetral ligament. Lack of communication was highly predictive of the absence of communication between midcarpal joint and RCJ through the lunotriquetral ligament with a negative predictive value of 94 %. Communication was not statistically correlated with:• communicating defect of the scapholunate ligament and of the TFCC,• osteoarthritis of RCJ and PTJ, • ulnar variance, • location (ulnar or radial) of the pain, • history of trauma. Conclusion: Communicating defect of the lunotriquetral ligament is unlikely if there is no arthrographic communication between RCJ and PTJ. FIGREF129.text: Value of spiral CT for grading acute sigmoid diverticulitis using a modified radiological Hinchey's classification B. Lienemann 1, 2 , C. Maurer 2 , J. Triller 2 , H.-P. Dinkel 2 ; 1 Brig/CH, 2 Berne/CH Purpose: To assess the value of a modified radiological Hinchey's classification for grading severity of acute diverticulitis with spiral CT. Methods: Retrospective assessment of spiral CT findings in 69 consecutive patients operated on for sigmoid diverticulitis between 1/1997 and 6/2001. Two staff radiologists blinded to clinical findings independently analyzed preoperative spiral CT scans obtaining final consensus for the presence of diverticula, pericolic inflammation, retroperitoneal and peritoneal fluid, abscess and perforation. A modified radiological Hinchey's classification (stage 0 phlegmonous inflammation, stage I local abscess, stage II pelvic abscess, stage III/IV peritonitis) was assessed and correlated to the surgical Hinchey's classification which was based on the intraoperative and histological findings. Results: All of the 69 patients had diverticulitis, 36 were operated on acutely, 33 in an elective procedure. Clinical Hinchey's stage 0 was found in 39 patients, stage I in 22, II in 6, III/IV in 2. Radiological staging yielded 49 cases of stage 0, 11 cases of stage I, 5 cases of stage II, and 4 cases of stage III/IV. There was a significant correlation between clinical and radiological staging (p < 0.0000005***, r = 0.6199). Most sensitive indicators of severity of diverticulitis were pericolic inflammation, pathological fluid collections, and bowel thickening. Conclusion: There is a close correlation between radiological and clinical staging of severity of diverticulitis. However, radiological staging tended to underestimate the severity of disease as intramural abscesses were underdiagnosed.B-063811:00 Value of graded compression US with use of adjuvant techniques: Detection of the vermiform appendix and diagnosis of acute appendicitis J.-H. Lee, Y.-K. Jeong, J.-C. Hwang, S.-Y. Ham, S.-O. Yang; Ulsan/KRObjective: To evaluate the usefulness of graded compression US with use of adjuvant techniques for detection of the vermiform appendix and diagnosis of acute appendicitis. Materials and methods: 373 consecutive patients for acute appendicitis was examined using graded compression US with a 5 or 7.5 MHz linear transducer. When the vermiform appendix was not identified with graded compression US, adjuvant techniques such as posterior manual compression, positional change of the cecum by sweeping the probe and positional change of the body to mobilize a hidden appendix were used. 8 cases receiving medical treatment for acute mild appendicitis were excluded. Results: Graded compression US enabled visualization the vermiform appendix in 313 of 364 patients (86 %). Following use of three types of adjuvant techniques, 24 cases, 11 cases, 7 cases of the appendix were newly detected, respectively.

FIGREF130.text: MRI of the pelvic floor in comparison to conventional defaecography C. Boehner, R. Struehn, F.A. Fellner, K.E. Matzel, W.A. Bautz; Erlangen/DEPurpose: Comparison of functional MRI of the pelvic floor with conventional defaecography in correlation with clinical findings. We especially investigated, if defaecation provides indispensable information about the cause of the disorder. Material and methods: In a prospective study we examined 30 patients withstool outlet disorders. Static and functional cine MRI of the pelvic bottom was performed after opacification of the rectum using axial an sagittal T2 at rest and a sagittal True-FISP-sequence at rest, during straining. The results were compared with clinical findings and conventional defaecography as actual gold standard in the diagnosis of pelvic bottom disorders. Daefecation had not to be performed during the examination. We especially investigated, if daefecation during conventional defaecography leads to additional information concerning anatomical disorders or organ prolapses in comparison to fMRI. Results: In all cases fMRI showed identical findings compared to conventional defaecography concerning the motion of the rectum. Anterior and posterior rectoceles, intususceptions and pelvic floor descent was shown in both modalities as well. FMRI provided additional information about accompaniing descensus uteri/ vaginae cystoceles and enteroceles in 20 cases. In only threee cases the cause of the disorder could be seen under defecation. Conclusion: FMRI is a usefull tool in the diagnosis of stool outlet disorders and, especially in the case of combined disorders in women and in case of anatomic anomalies, even provides additional information about the motions of the structures of the pelvic floor in comparison to conventional defaecography.B-0644 11:45Dynamic MRI of daefecation and micturition compared with videofluoroscopy C.E.M. FIGREF132.text: findings of fibrocystic changes and accompanying pathologies U. Kerimoglu, M. Gulsun, F.B. Demirkazik, M.Ariyurek; Ankara/TR Purpose: To evaluate the mammographic findings of histopathologically proven cases of fibrocystic changes and assess associated pathologies. Methods and materials: We reviewed histopathologic results of 250 patients who had undergone excisional biopsy after mammographically guided needle localization. Of these, 119 showed fibrocystic changes. We retrospectively evaluated the mamographic findings and determined associated pathologies. Results: In 12 (10 %) of 119 patients, fibrocystic changes were associated with fibroadenoma (n = 6) or carcinoma (n = 6). Every case associated with carcinoma was manifest by pleomorphic microcalcifications suggestive of malignancy. 4 cases of associated fibroadenoma showed masses and other 2 cases microcalcifications. Of the 4 masses, one was spiculated, one lobulated and the other 2 circumscribed. In 107 (90 %) of 119 cases, fibrocystic changes were not associated with other pathology. Of 107 cases, 65 (60 %) had fibrocystic changes without proliferation. Remaining 42 (40 %) had epithelial hyperplasia, sclerozing adenosis and intraductal papillomatosis as well. Mammographic findings of these 107 patients revealed microcalcifications in 44 (41 %), mass in 43 (40 %), asymmetric density in 16 (15 %) and parenchymal distortion in four (4 %). Of 44 patients presenting with microcalcifications, 24 (55 %) were punctate, 10 (22 %) amorphous, 9 (21 %) pleomorphic in morphology and one (2 %) was manifest as milk of calcium. Of the 43 masses, 17 (39 %) had obscured, 8 (19 %) circumscribed, 13 (30 %) spiculated and 5 (12 %) lobulated margins. Conclusion: Microcalcifications and masses are the most frequently seen mammographic findings of fibrocystic changes. Although spiculated masses and pleomorphic microcalcifications may suggest malignant pathology, they may represent fibrocystic changes in some cases.B-064811:00 The use of weighted Kappa (κ) index for the quality control of mammographic readings in a population-based breast cancer screening program I. FIGREF133.text: Material and methods: During the past year, 98.541 women were screened in 20 screening facilities of Valencia Breast Cancer Screening Program (Spain). The radiologists had previously attended meetings and courses in order to complete their educational process.Results:The mean values of weighted k index were: 0.70 (0.43 -0.91), 0.58 (0.36 -0.89), 0.67 (0.43 -0.91), 0.88 (0.42 -1.00) and 0.86 (0.67 -1.00) for normal, benign, probably benign, probably malignant and malignant respectively.Conclusion:The highest values of agreement were found in probably malignant and malignant findings. The lowest values of agreement were found in "negative for cancer" mammograms. This fact can be explained by the random classification -significant findings.
