Percutaneous echocardiography remains the primary method in the evaluation of the postoperative situs.B-066411:50 Left ventricular volumes and mass determination using MRI: On the role of model based approaches R. Rienmüller, G. Reiter, U. Reiter, A. Ryabikin, N. Gagarina; Graz/AT Purpose: Comparison of various approaches to evaluate left ventricular volumes and muscle mass by Magnetic Resonance (MR). Materials and methods: 75 patients with suspected or known coronary heart disease were studied by MR (1.5 T field strength, 40 mT/m gradients, cine-TrueFISP) in 2-chamber and 4-chamber views. Enddiastolic (EDV) and endsystolic (ESV) volumes as well as left ventricular muscle masses (LVMM) were evaluated by a single-plane ellipsoid model. MRI short axis scans were performed in 25 patients to use Simpson rule (ARGUS software) to determine the above parameters. Results: Correlation between the 2-chamber and 4-chamber view is r = 0.93 (95 %confidence interval is 0.89 to 0.95) for EDV, r = 0.94 (0.90 to 0.96) for ESV and r = 0.94 (0.91 to 0.96) for LVMM. Correlation between 2-chamber view and Simpson approach is r = 0.95 (0.88 to 0.98) for EDV, r = 0.98 (0.95 to 0.99) for ESV and r = 0.94 (0.87 to 0.98) for LVMM. Correlation between the 4-chamber view and the Simpson approach is r = 0.98 (0.95 to 0.99) for EDV, r = 0.98 (0.96 to 0.99) for ESV and r = 0.95 (0.88 to 0.98) for LVMM. Conclusion: As the Simpson approach is more time consuming than the 4-and 2-chamber view in evaluation of left ventricular volumes, the 4-chamber view approach may be used routinely as long the morphological configuration of the left ventricle corresponds to an rotational ellipsoid. of ruptured cerebral aneurysms: 3D-rotational angiography in comparison with DSA; a blinded study in 53 patients A. Hochmuth, U. Spetzger, J. Spreer, A. Berlis, J. Klisch, M. Schumacher; Freiburg/DEPurpose: To evaluate the diagnostic value of 3D rotational angiography (RA) in comparison with biplanar Digital Subtraction Angiography (DSA) in the detectionrate, classification, and treatment-planning of ruptured intracranial aneurysms. Subjects/methods: Between 09/99 and 09/00 53 patients with acute Subarachnoid hemorrhage (Hunt-Hess II -V) underwent angiography (GE Advantx-E, GE, Milwaukee, USA) with both methods. Biplanar DSA was performed in 2 to 6 standard-projections for every vascular territory. 3D-datasets of RA were evaluated using a GE Advantage windows workstation with different algorithms (Surface Shaded Display, Maximum Intensity Projection). The DSA-films and 3D-datasets were analyzed retrospectively in a blinded manner in terms of detection and depiction of aneurysms (number and configuration) and impact on therapy-planning. Results: 49 aneurysms were detected in 42 patients, (1 -5/pat, size 0.6 -20.4 mm), whereas no aneurysm was found in 11 pat. However, RA revealed 7 additional aneurysms not seen on conventional DSA and failed to depict one visible only in compression series. The delineation of the neck of the aneurysm was remarkably improved in RA in 70.5 % of all cases. Better depiction of the parent vessel and relationship to adjacent vessels was demonstrated in 45.0 % respectively 50.0 %. In 9/42 patients, endovascular treatment, in 26/42 patients, micro-surgical therapy was proposed. In 7/42 patients, both options were rated as equal. Actual treatment consisted of 8 endovascular procedures and 30 neurosurgical operations.

FIGREF137.text: Assessment of cerebral hemodynamics in patients with cerebralAVMs by means of 2D phase contrast flow measurement of brain supplying arteries M. Essig, J. Scorzin, J.U. Heiss, M. Bock, S.O. Schoenberg, G. van Kaick; Heidelberg/DEPurpose: Non-invasive assessment of blood flow in brain-supplying arteries in patients with cerebral AVMs and correlation with the morphologic and clinical features of the lesions. Patients and methods: In an ongoing prospective protocol we have so far examined 50 patients and 10 age matched volunteers with a 2D-ECG-triggerd phasecontrast-MR-flow measurement. Mean flow, velocity and the shape of the flow profiles were calculated and compared with radiological and clinical features of the malformations. Follow-up studies after radiosurgery are available for 12 patients. Results: Patients with AVMs present with a significant higher flow values and a lateralisation of the flow towards the ipsilateral brain supplying vessels. The mean flow of the ipsilateral internal carotid arteries was 480 ml/min compared to 395 ml/min in the contralateral side (p < 0.05). With increasing size of the malformation the flow-differences increased. Patients with clinical steel syndromes presented with higher flow differences. A correlation between flow differences and the location of the malformation could not be observed. With decreasing size of the malformation after radiosurgical treatment the flow values and differences process toward the values obtained from the volunteers. Discussion: Phase contrast 2D MR flow measurements proved to be a helpful diagnostic tool in the assessment of hemodynamic changes in patients with cerebral AVMs. Flow values correlated with the morphologic and clinical features of the malformation and seem to be helpful in the follow-up of therapy.B-0670 11:20Contrast-enhanced projection MRA and dynamic star MRI in patients with intracranial arterio-venous malformationsM. Wagner 2 ; 1 Washington, DC/US, 2 Reading, PA/US Purpose: To describe characteristic imaging features of urachal carcinoma.Methods and materials: 25 cases of surgically proven urachal carcinomas were retrospectively reviewed. Computed tomography images were evaluated to determine tumour morphology, presence and localization of calcification, extent of bladder invasion and metastases. The imaging characteristics were compared with gross pathologic appearance. Results: The average patient age was 48 years (range 21 -69 years). There were 13 males and 12 females. Tumour size averaged 6 cm in the largest diameter (range 2 cm -12 cm). 20 cases (84 %) appeared as mixed cystic-solid lesions (16 predominately cystic and 5 predominately solid), 4 (16 %) were completely solid. This correlated well with gross pathologic findings. Calcifications were present in 18/25 (72 %). Eleven cases had purely peripheral calcifications, 4 had both peripheral and central calcification, and 3 showed purely central calcification. Invasion of the bladder wall occurred in 23/25 (92 %). Intraluminal extension of tumour occurred in 13/25 (52 %). The majority of the mass was extravesicular in 22/25 (88 %). Nine cases (36 %) had either local invasion and/or distant metastases at presentation. Two cases of local invasion were not radiologically evident. Conclusion: The CT features of urachal adenocarcinomas in this series were those of a midline, mixed cystic-solid or less often completely solid mass. Focal calcifications (predominately peripheral) are a common finding. Although invasion of the bladder wall and lumen is often seen, the majority of tumours are predominantly extravesicular. Local invasion and/or metastases are common.B-072210:40 CT cystography: Analysis of the inner surface and surrounding tissues of the bladder on the same examination J.S. Calha, A.M. Pereira, J.M. FIGREF157.text: CT quantitative morphometric-functional correlative study of silicosis C.G.C. Ooi, P.L. Khong, I.W.T. Ho, F.T.F. Cheung, M.S.M. Ip, W.K. Lam, H. Ngan, F.L. Chan, K.W.T. Tsang; Hong Kong/HKPurpose: To quantify emphysema and nodular profusion with CT and evaluate their relationships with lung function, clinical and exercise parameters. Materials and methods: 76 (64.6 ± 8.8 years) men with silicosis underwent CT scans of the thorax. Lung function and exercise parameters [O2 uptake, distance walked] including Borg's scale of dyspnoea were obtained. Nodular profusion (NP) and progressive massive fibrosis (PMF) were graded following a 4-point scale (1 -4). Emphysema, using threshold values (−950 to −1024 HU), and mean lung density (MLD) were quantified. Duration of silica exposure and cigarette consumption (pack years) was obtained. Spearman's and multiple regression analysis were performed to evaluate the inter-relationships between the different parameters (p < 0.05 as significant).Findings: PMF was correlated to emphysema (r = 0.58). All CT parameters were inversely related to lung function indices. PMF showed the best correlation with indices of obstruction [FEV1(r = −0.63), FEV1/FVC (r = 0.51)]; MLD with TLC (r = − 0.53)] emphysema with DLCO/VA (r = −0.42). MLD and PMF were associated with Borg's grade. NP and PMF were inversely related to exercise parameters. After multiple regression, PMF remained a significant determinant of FEV1 and FEV1/FVC; MLD of TLC, VC and Borg's scale; emphysema of FEV1, FEV1/FVC and DLCO/VA. Men with PMF (n = 58) had significantly worse lung function, CT grades, Borgs scale and O2 uptake than those with simply silicosis. Smoking and silica exposure exerted no independent effects on lung function. Conclusion: PMF is an independent determinant of airflow obstruction associated with functional impairment and disease severity in silicosis. MLD and emphysema can be regarded as indirect measures of functional disability. B-0750 14:25 The use of objective CT measurements of emphysema to develop a composite functional index S.M. Ellis, A. Walker, J.-M. Fellrath, D. Cramer, D.M. Hansell, A.U. Wells; London/GB Purpose:

B-0759 14:20 Diffusion-and perfusion-weighted MRI in eclampsia and HELLP-syndrome U. Weber, K.-T. Hoffmann, G.-J. Jungehülsing, L. Niehaus; Berlin/DEPurpose: Neurological complications often occur postpartum in patients with eclampsia and HELLP-syndrome (Hemolysis Elevated Liver enzymes and Low Platelet count). The aim of the study was to elucidate the pathogenesis of brain lesions in these patients using diffusion-and perfusion-weighted imaging (DWI; PWI). Methods: Three women with eclampsia (n = 2) and HELLP-syndrome (n = 1) (aged from 25 -29 a) with seizures, altered mental status, visual disturbances and further neurological deficits were investigated. DWI (TR/TEeff 4800/145 ms; EPI factor 13; b = 0/386/868 mm 2 /s) and PWI (3D-susceptibility-based; TR/TE/α 18 ms/ 25 ms/8°) were performed postpartally. Results: In all patients MRI showed brain lesions with increased apparent diffusion-(ADC) coefficients (up to 215 mm 2 /s) which resolved within several weeks. PWI did not reveal areas of hyper-or hypoperfusion assessed by mean time of bolus track arrival. Conclusion: Brain lesions in eclampsia/HELLP-syndrome represent vasogenic edema which may be completely reversible. There is no indication for cerebral ischemia causing cytotoxic edema.B-0760 14:30 Experience with a new imaging protocol by using contrast enhanced MR angiography with CARE bolus technique for cerebral stroke patients Ö. Özsarlak, P.M. Parizel, J.W. van Goethem, A.M.A. de Schepper; Edegem/BE Purpose: To define the role of contrast enhanced MR Angiography (ce-MRA) of the carotid and intracranial arteries in patients with acute cerebral stroke. Methods and materials: The images were obtained using combined head and neck coils. The MR imaging protocol for patients with a clinic of acute cerebral stroke (within 48 hours) as follows: (1) Ax FLAIR, (2) Ax TSE T2, (3) Sag SE T1,(4) Ax EPI BOLD Diffusion WI with ADC map, (5) 3D ce-MRA of the carotid and intracerebral arteries with 2D CARE Bolus technique, (6) Ax TSE T1 after GD injection. Results: Besides depicting acute cerebral infarction due to cytotoxic edema on diffusion WI, ce-MRA shows us the underlying vascular etiology in most of the cases such as high grade stenosis with plaques, dissection, emboli, and vascular malformations. T1 WI after gadolinium enhancement reveals also gyral enhancement which has a value in therapetic desicions.Conclusion: CE-MRA with care bolus technique of the carotid and intracranial arteries combined with postcontrast Ax T1 WI may show the underlying etiology in most of the patients with acute cerebral stroke. FIGREF165.text: Comparison of stereoscopic 3D-CT and standard 3D-CT in the classification of acetabular fractures: A ROC analysis R. Kickuth, G. Hartung, U. Laufer, C. Gruening, C. Stueckle, D. Liermann, J. Kirchner; Herne/DE Purpose: To compare the diagnostic power of stereoscopic and standard threedimensional computed tomography (3D-CT) in the classification of acetabular fractures by interdisciplinary review. Materials and methods: Receiver Operating Characteristics (ROC) were assessed for two radiologists and two surgeons blinded to the presence of acetabular fractures in an animal model (a total of 62 pork hips, 40 of them with artificial acetabular fractures). Interpretation of stereoscopic and standard 3D-CT images was performed on a workstation (Virtuoso®, Siemens Medical Systems, Forchheim, Germany) using two specific volume rendering algorithms: unshaded bone and shaded bone. Main target parameter was the diagnostic accuracy in the classification of artificial fractures following Judet and Letournel. Results: ROC analysis for radiologists showed Az-values of 0.83 for standard 3D-CT and 0.81 for stereoscopic 3D-CT when using an unshaded bone algorithm (p > 0.5); Az-values were 0.82 for standard 3D-CT and 0.81 for stereoscopic 3D-CT when using a shaded bone algorithm (p > 0.5). Az-values for the surgeons were 0.87 for standard 3D-CT and 0.86 for stereoscopic 3D-CT when using an unshaded bone algorithm (p > 0.5); Az-values were 0.82 for both standard and stereoscopic 3D-CT when using a shaded bone algorithm (p > 0.5). Conclusion: The diagnostic accuracy of stereoscopic 3D-CT in the classification of acetabular fractures was comparable to that of standard 3D-CT.B-0768 14:20Multi-slice CT (MSCT) in the detection and classification of pelvic and acetabular fractures U. Wedegärtner, C. Gatzka, P. Steiner, J.M. Rueger, G.B. Adam; Hamburg/DE Purpose: To assess the usefulness of MSCT in the detection and classification of pelvic and acetabular fractures. and methods: Routine radiography and MSCT of the pelvis with sagittal and coronal MPR's were performed in 41 patients with clinically suspected pelvic or acetabular fractures. One trauma surgeon and a radiologist evaluated routine radiography and CT images in terms of fracture detection, classification and illustration. Fracture classification was obtained using the AO classification system, Tile and Letournel. Results: In 15 patients a suspected fracture was excluded by MSCT. In the remaining 26 patients 19 anterior pelvic ring, 4 anterior and posterior pelvic ring, 11 acetabular and 7 sacral fractures were diagnosed. All MSCT-findings were obtained by transversal source images. Multiplanar reconstructions were especially advantageous in cases with fractures of the sacrum und acetabulum. In 7 (27 %) patients additional fractures (5 acetabular, 2 posterior pelvic ring) were detected with MSCT, but not on plain film. In 4 additional patients MSCT-diagnosis resulted in changes of fracture classification based on MSCT. In 6 (23 %) patients the therapeutical algorithm was changed according to MSCT diagnosis. Conclusions: MSCT examinations of the pelvis should be performed in patients with clinically suspected fractures to confirm or exclude pelvic fractures and may replace conventional radiography in the future. MPR's are useful in fracture illustration and classification.

FIGREF166.text: 15:00 MR imaging characteristics of pelvic heterotopic ossification H.P. Ledermann 1 , M.E. Schweitzer 2 , W.B. Morrison 2 , G.M. Bongartz 1 , W. Steinbrich 1 ; 1 Basle/CH, 2 Philadelphia, PA/US Purpose: To investigate MR signal patterns and location of pelvic heterotopic ossification in paralysed patients. Patients and methods: 36 patients (female n = 3, male n = 33, mean age 43.3) with proven heterotopic ossification on CT (n = 17) or radiographs (n = 19) who had a 1.5 T pelvic MR (contrast enhanced, n = 34) within 3 months of CT or radiographs were included. Maturity of heterotopic ossification was graded by two musculoskeletal radiologists on CT or radiography as: (I)Fluid density on CT without calcification; (II) Calcification; (III) Immature ossification; (IV) Mature ossification. Location and MR signal of all heterotopic ossification sites was noted. Results: 141 sites of heterotopic ossification were graded as follows: grade I: n = 20; grade II: n = 39; grade III: n = 30; grade IV: n = 52. With increasing maturity the frequency of hyperintense signal within heterotopic ossification decreased (I: 70 %, II: 58 %, III: 44 %, IV: 4 %) and the frequency of fat and cortical signal increased (I: 0 %, II: 3 %, III: 13 %, IV: 86 %). With progressive maturity of heterotopic ossification a decrease in frequency of enhancement from 100 % (grade I) to 20 % (grade IV) was observed. Fifteen (88 %) patients with CT correlation had heterotopic ossification localized to the trochanteric or iliopsoas bursa (55/91 sites (60 %)). Conclusion: With progressive maturity of heterotopic ossification a decrease of T2 hyperintensity and enhancement is seen while fat and cortical bone-equivalent signal increases. CT correlation localizes the majority of heterotopic ossifications in the trochanteric and iliopsoas bursa. FIGREF168.text: of the lower extremity arterial runoff vessels: Intraindividual comparison of 3D MR-angiography, MDCT-angiography and digital subtraction angiography J.E. Roos, D. Weishaupt, J.K. Willmann, T. Pfammatter, M. Borut, P.R. Hilfiker; Zürich/CH Purpose: To compare 3D MR angiography (MRA) and MDCT angiography (CTA) for assessment of peripheral runoff vessels with intraarterial digital subtraction angiography (DSA) as the standard of reference.Materials and methods: DSA, MRA and CTA were performed in 20 consecutive patients with suspected occlusive arterial disease. MRA (1.5 T; GEMS) and CTA (Volume Zoom, Germany) were assessed independently by two readers for the presence of significant arterial stenosis; a third reader evaluated the DSA images. Volume rendered (VR) images for CTA, maximum intensity projection (MIP) for MRA; multiplanar reformations (MPR) and source images for both were used for evaluation. Time for post-processing and reading time of both data sets were computed. Results: Highest overall sensitivities/specificities were found at the pelvic and femoral level (CTA 84 %/98 %; MRA 88 %/95 %) and lowest at the level of lower leg (CTA 70 %/95 %; MRA 65 %/90 %). Interobserver agreement for both MRA and CTA was good (kappa = 0.64) and intermodality agreement between CTA and MRA was 0.62. Post-processing of the data sets was significantly more time consuming for CTA (29 min) than for MRA (9 min). Reading time was similar with both methods (CTA 5 min; MRI 4 min). Major difficulties encountered in CTA were calcification of the vessels, in MRA the bolus tracking for the lower leg. Conclusion: Using state-of-the art post-processing, both MR and CT Angiography are similar regarding the assessment of peripheral runoff vessels in patients with peripheral arterial disease.B-0777 14:20Stereo viewing as a tool for adding accuracy in the evaluation of 3D-MRA data sets U. Fronz, M. Goyen, S.G. Rühm, J. Barkhausen, J.F. Debatin; Essen/DE

FIGREF169.text: Evaluation of the diagnostic accuracy of high resolution contrast enhanced MRA (CE-MRA) of the calf in PAOD -comparison to DSA and intraoperative findings J.O. Balzer, R. Ritter, K. Davis, C. Thalhammer, A. Pira, T.J. Vogl; Frankfurt a. Main/DEPurpose: To evaluate high resolution contrast enhanced MRA (CE-MRA) for treatment planning in patients with peripheral arterial obstructive disease (PAOD) and lesions in the calf. Method and materials: 65 patients with PAOD of the popliteal or infrapopliteal arteries were prospectively studied with CE-MRA before angioplasty or a surgical bypass operation. All MR examinations were performed on a 1.5 T MR unit (Symphony Quantum, Siemens) with employment of a newly developed phased array peripheral coil and automatic table movement. CE-MRA results were correlated with subsequent DSA findings. All results were blinded and reviewed by three radiologists. The findings were graded as normal, minor changes, stenotic (< 50 %, 50 -70 %, and > 70 %) or occlusion. 37 patients subsequently had a femoro-crural bypass operation and 28 patients PTA. Results: A total of 153 abnormal arterial segments were evaluated with CE-MRA and DSA. CE-MRA correlated to DSA findings in 94 % of the cases. In 14.7 % of the cases CE-MRA overestimated vascular perfusion. In 4 cases, where CE-MRA showed a perfused vessel, intraoperative findings revealed an occluded vessel. Detection of arteriosclerotic changes within the vessels of the calf was markedly employment of the new peripheral coil. Suggested treatment and the interventional approach based on the CE-MRA findings corresponded to DSA in 95 %. Conclusion: High resolution CE-MRA of the calf is an excellent modality for the detection of vascular lesions in this region when findings are interpreted with caution. The correlation of CE-MRA findings with clinical findings is mandatory for correct interpretation of the distal run-off situation.B-077914:40 Evaluation of the diagnostic accuracy of contrast enhanced MRA (CE-MRA) in peripheral arterial occlusive disease with a new, dedicated peripheral MRA coil -comparison to DSA findings J.O. Balzer, K. Davis jr., C. Thalhammer, A. Pira, M.G. Mack, T.J. Vogl; Frankfurt a. Main/DE Purpose: To evaluate contrast enhanced MRA (CE-MRA) with employment of a newly developed peripheral MRA coil for treatment planning and follow-up after laser angioplasty or PTA in patients with peripheral arterial obstructive disease (PAOD). Material and method: 157 patients with stenosis or occlusion of the pelvic or lower extremity arteries were prospectively studied with CE-MRA before laser and/or balloon angioplasty. All MR examinations were performed on a 1.5 T MR unit (Symphony Quantum, Siemens) with employment of a newly developed phased array peripheral coil and automatic table movement. CE-MRA results were correlated with subsequent DSA findings. For planning of the interventional approach CE-MRA and DSA findings were included in the review. All results were blinded and reviewed by three radiologists. The findings were graded as normal, minor changes, stenotic (70 %) or occlusion. Results: In 157 patients, a total of 451 abnormal arterial segments were evaluated with CE-MRA, CTA, and DSA. CE-MRA correlated to DSA findings in 100 % (occlusions), in 98 % (stenosis > 70 %), 97 % (stenosis 50 -70 %), and 98 % (stenosis < 50 %). Minor arteriosclerotic changes were detected in 87 % of cases. Detection of arteriosclerotic changes within the vessels of the calf were markedly improved by employment of the new peripheral coil. Suggested treatment and the interventional approach based on the CE-MRA findings corresponded to DSA in 98 %. Conclusion: CE-MRA is an excellent modality for screening, treatment planning, and follow-up in patients with PAOD. The peripheral MRA coil facilitated patient examination and increased spatial resolution thus making CE-MRA even more accurate. B-0780 14:50 Multi-slice spiral CT-angiography in peripheral arterial occlusive disease: A valuable tool in detecting significant arterial lumen narrowing? H.R. Portugaller, H. Schoellnast, K.A. Hausegger, W. Amann, M. Aschauer, J. Tauss; Graz/AT Purpose: To evaluate the potential of multislice CT-angiography (CTA) in the detection of hemodynamically significant (≥ 70 %) lesions of the aortoiliac, femoropopliteal and infrapopliteal arteries. Methods and materials: 41 patients (35 men, 6 women; mean age 68 years) with peripheral arterial occlusive disease (PAOD) underwent multslice spiral-CTA and digital subtraction angiography (DSA) from the infrarenal aorta to the supramalleolar region. CT-parameters were 4 × 2.5 mm collimation, 1.5 cm table-increment (pitch 6) and 1.25 mm reconstruction-increment. Volume rendering technique (VRT), maximum intensity projection (MIP) and MIP together with axial CT-studies were reviewed for significant stenoses and occlusions. DSA was the standard of reference. Results: In 37 patients, 210 lesions were detected by DSA (84 stenoses, 126 occlusions). Considering all ³ 70 % lesions, VRT/MIP/MIP + axial CT revealed 12 (71 %)/14 (82 %)/15 (88 %) of 17 aortoiliacal, 45 (90 %)/47 (94 %)/49 (98 %) of 50 femoropopliteal and 114 (80 %)/121 (85 %)/127 (89 %) of 143 infrapopliteal lesions. On VRT/MIP/MIP + axial CT, 9/49/11 aortoiliacal, 9/10/9 femoropopliteal and 65/49/47 infrapopliteal vessel sections were considered to be ³ 70 % stenotic whereas DSA showed no significant lumen narrowing. Distinction of stenoses and occlusions was impossible in 035 (24 %)/38 (26 %)/41 (29 %) infrapopliteal lesions on VRT/ MIP/MIP + axial CT-studies.Conclusion: Multislice CTA is helpful in detecting hemodynamically significant lesions in PAOD. However, lesion overestimation is a frequent feature of all CTAimaging modalities. In infrapopliteal arteries, stenoses and occlusions are likely to be confused. Since axial CT-studies yielded most correct positive results, they should always be reviewed additionally.B-0781 15:00Multislice spiral CT angiography in the evaluation of patients with peripheral arterial disease C. Catalano, F. Fraioli, M. Bezzi, A. Laghi, A. Napoli, F. Pediconi, S. Vagnarelli, R. Passariello; Rome/IT Purpose: The aim of this study was to compare multislice CT-Angiography (MSCTA) with DSA in patients with peripheral obstructive disease. Materials and methods: 50 patients with peripheral arterial occlusive disease were evaluated with MSCTA after bolus administration of 140 ml of nonionic c.a. at 4 ml/s. A fixed time delay of 28 seconds was used in all patients. In all cases DSA was performed within 72 hours after CTA. A 3D real time interaction on a dedicated workstation was performed in all cases, utilizing different reconstruction algorithms and if necessary axial images, by three experienced blinded observers. The findings were graded as normal, < 50 % > 50 % single, > 50 % diffuse and occlusion for 23 different arterial segments. For statistical evaluation the arterial segments were then divided in 3 groups: aorto-iliac, femoro-popliteal and run off vessels. Results: By using a fixed time delay, good to excellent arterial enhancement and image quality was achieved in all cases. A total of 1147 arterial segments were evaluated with CTA and DSA. Regarding the degree of stenosis in the aorto-iliac, femoropopliteal and run off vessels, the values of sensitivity and specificity were respectively 100 % and 98 %, 100 % and 96 %, 98 % and 94 %. The interobserver variability showed a kappa value for the aorto-iliac segment of 0.93, for the femoropopliteal segment of 0.94 and for the run off vessels of 0.90. Conclusion: MSCTA appears particularly accurate in the assessment of peripheral arterial disease, and therefore can be proposed as a non-invasive imaging modality.B-078215:10 Timed arterial compression contrast enhanced magnetic resonance angiography (TAC-CEMRA) for optimized imaging of the hand vasculature K. Wentz, J.M. Froehlich, C. von Weymarn, M.A. Patak, R. Jenelten, C.L. Zollikofer; Winterthur/CH

Conclusion: TAC-CEMRA increases considerably the imaging time which directly translates into high resolution images resulting in a quality similar to DSA. Interval compression makes it possible to acquire arterial, capillary and venous phases. FIGREF172.text: Resovist-enhanced MRI accuracy in focal liver lesion detection and characterization improves when dynamic study is performed in addition to the late phase of enhancement.B-0789 14:40MRI of carcinoid liver metastases T.R. Bader 1 , R.C. Semelka 2 , V.C.Y. Chiu 2 , J.T. To evaluate the signal intensity and Gadolinium enhancement patterns of carcinoid liver metastases. Methods and materials: The MR examinations of 16 patients (4 men, 12 women) with liver metastases from gastrointestinal carcinoid tumors were retrospectively reviewed. All primary tumors had histolopathologic correlation. The liver metastases were confirmed by histopathology in 13 patients and by imaging and clinical follow-up in 5 patients. All MR studies were performed at 1.5 T comprising: T1weighted spoiled gradient echo (SGE), T2-weighted fat-suppressed turbo spin echo, HASTE, and serial postgadolinium T1-weighted SGE sequences without and with fat-suppression. Signal intensity and patterns of contrast enhancement of metastases were evaluated. Results: 156 liver metastases were evaluated in 16 patients. On precontrast T1-/ T2-weighted images, 117 metastases (75 %) were hypointense/hyperintense. 24 metastases (15 %) in 5 patients (31 %) showed globular areas of high signal on T1-and T2-weighted images. 5 enhancement patterns of metastases were identified on postgadolinium images. 146 metastases (94 %) were hypervascular, showing moderate intense enhancement during the hepatic arterial phase, and 9 metastases (6 %) were hypovascular. 23 metastases (15 %) were visible only on immediate postgadolinium images. Conclusion: Carcinoid liver metastases demonstrate a spectrum of appearances, are commonly hypervascular, and may only be demonstrable on immediate postgadolinium images.B-079014:50 Diagnostic imaging of FNH: Characterization using SPIO-enhanced MRI R.M. Hammerstingl, W.V. Schwarz, F. Marquardt, E. Staib-Sebler, M. Lorenz, C. Dietrich, T.J. Vogl; Frankfurt a. Main/DE Purpose: To evaluate the diagnostic potential of SPIO-enhanced MRI in the diagnosis of patients suffering from FNH in correlation with histopathologic and clinical findings.

Sauner, J. Seidel, S. Vogt, W.A. Kaiser; Jena/DE Purpose: To evaluate the potential clinical value of newly available bone densitometric technology based on radiogrammetry and bone texture analysis. FIGREF176.text: role of MRI in the evaluation of hip joint disease in clinical subtypes of idiopathic juvenile arthritis M.I. Argyropoulou, S.L. Fanis, T. Xenakis, S.C. Efremidis, A. Siamopoulou; Ioannina/GRPurpose: In Idiopathic Juvenile Arthritis (IJA) hip joint involvement is a sign of poor prognosis. Our purpose was to evaluate the role of MRI in the detection of hip joint involvement and to assess the relationship of MR findings with the clinical subtypes of IJA. Material and methods: 28 patients (mean age, 12.5 years) with IJA, 8 having an oligoarthritis, 13 polyarthritis and 7 systemic arthritis were studied with T2-weighted turbo-spin-echo and T1-weighted spin-echo sequences, before and after intravenous injection of Gd-DTPA. An MR grading score was established: grade 1 = no contrast enhancement, 2 = focal synovial enhancement, 3 = diffuse enhancement, 4 = 3 + diffuse synovial thickening, 5 = 4 + villonodular thickening, 6 = 5 + cartilage and bone erosions. Results: The clinical examination was abnormal in 32.1 % of cases and the MR in 57.1 %. The MR was abnormal in 25 % of patients with oligoarthritis, 53.8 % with polyarthritis and 100 % of patients with systemic arthritis. Higher MR grades presented in patients with active disease (mean 3.9, SD 2) compared to those with inactive disease (mean 2.1, SD 1.4) (p < 0.01) and patients with a positive clinical examination (mean 4.6, SD 1.34) compared to those with a negative one (mean 1.78, SD 1.13) (p < 0.001). The MR grades were different in the three clinical forms (oligoarticular: mean 1.5, SD 1.06, polyarticular: mean 2.38, SD 1.55 and systemic: mean 4.85, SD 1.21) (F: 12.3, p < 0.001). Significant differences were found between systemic arthritis and oligoarthritis and systemic arthritis and polyarthritis (p < 0.001). Conclusion: MRI helps in the detection of hip joint involvement and its use in the imaging protocol of patients with polyarthritis and systemic arthritis should be considered.B-0800 15:00Skeletal anomalies on hand and feet radiographs in patients with Saethre-Chotzen syndrom and Muenke-type mutation (FGFR3 Pro250Arg) A. FIGREF193.text: and management of laparoscopic adjustable gastric banding for morbid obesity M.-A. Pierredon-Foulongne, B.P. Gallix, C. Achard, L. Nebout, D. Nocca, J.-M. Bruel; Montpellier/FR Objective: The purpose of this study is to evaluate the role of radiology in the treatment of morbid obesity by adjustable laparoscopic gastric banding (ALGB). Methods: From September 1996 to September 2000, 374 consecutive patients underwent an ALGB-119 lap band system (LB) and 255 Sweedish adjustable gastric banding (SAGB). Upper gastrointestinal series were performed within 24 -48 hours after surgery in all patients. Radiologic examination was also used to detect complications and to adjust gastric band. Results: The 2 differents types of gastric band are easily identified on plain films. Early and late complications are illustrated: pouch dilatation (LP: 11 patients, SAGB: 5 patients), slippage (LB: 27 patients, SAGB: 5 patients), band migration (LB: 1 patient, SAGB: 0 patient), rotation of the access port and system disconnection (LB: 0 patient, SAGB: 2 patients). Radiological criteria for adjustment of gastric band are explained on the basis of barium studies performed before and after any modification of the stoma size. Conclusion: In patients treated with ALGB for morbid obesity, radiology plays an important role in evaluating early and late complications and in the management of weight loss. FIGREF198.text: methods: 68 patients with ACL-transplant underwent multiplanar MRI (T2, plain and postcontrast T1-weighted spin-echo and dynamic gradientecho turbo-FLASH sequences). MRI and clincal follow-up were performed 2, 12, 24, 52, 76, 104 weeks post surgery. Results: In the first postoperative follow-up all neoligaments showed homogeneous low signal-intensity in T1-and T2-weighted sequences indistinguishable from that of normal cruciate ligament (C/N in T1: 1.6) with synovial percentage enhancement of 9 %. 12 -52 weeks postoperative follow-up studies showed a signal-intensity-increase (C/N: 6.7) with mean synovial percentage enhancement of 50 %. The one-year follow-up allowed no definite assessment of course and state of the neoligament. The 76 and 104 weeks follow-up studies showed significant decrease in signal-intensity-(C/N: 3.0) and synovial percentage enhancement (25 %). In clincal testing 67 patients (98 %) showed a stability of the transplant two years postoperative. Conclusion: The use of contrast enhanced MRI in the follow-up allows an accurate determination of stability and morphology of the ACL-transplant up to 3 months and later than 1 -2 years postoperative with a nondiagnostic period between 3 to 12 months.B-0979 10:55 Hoffa's body impingement of the knee: MRI versus arthroscopy F. Methods and materials: 141 patients with suspected PE and abnormal perfusion scan underwent MRA prior to DSA and were managed on the basis of DSA results. Images were blindly assessed by independent reviewers. In case of disagreement, diagnosis was made based on subsequent consensus. MRA is sensitive for segmental or larger pulmonary embolism, and highly specific. The results are comparable to helical CT, but MRA has the advantage of using non-ionising radiation and safer contrast agents. With increasing availability of MRI systems, MRA could be part of a powerful diagnostic strategy in the future. Our initial experience indicates that optimized display of the density distribution within the lung parenchyma provides additional information in patients with suspected or proven PE with good correlation to V/Q SPECT. Comparison was carried out per nodule for calculation of true and false positives, false negatives, and with respect to nodule size.Results: 238 possible nodules had been analysed. If all nodules irrespective of size are included, the automated detection has a sensitivity of 84 %. If the minimum nodule size for detection is set to 2 mm, 34 out of the 172 computer-detected nodules are false positives, and 7 false negatives occurred (sensitivity: 95 %). Conclusions: With the use of thin-section multislice CT, computer-aided detection of small lung nodules may experience a break-through in clinical relevance. The algorithms can evaluate the fully isotropic, three-dimensional information of potential nodules and thus reduce ambiguities. An additional 100 normal and 100 pathologic scans were then used to test the detection of pathology by the algorithm. The total of 1000 CT scans required in the study were selected from the portal venous phase of upper abdominal CT examinations performed in patients with normal findings or hypovascularized liver lesions. For the preliminary version of the algorithm used in this study, it was necessary to define regions of interest that were converted to a 128 × 128 matrix with an 8 bit grey scale (in DICOM format). Results: Training of the algorithm with the 400 learning examples each of normal and abnormal findings took about 50 hours. The classification of a single image was performed within a few seconds. The diagnostic accuracy achieved for the test scans was close to 99 %. The error rate for the pathologic and normal images was comparable. Conclusion: The modified Perceptron algorithm has an accuracy of about 99 % in detecting pathology on CT scans of the liver showing either normal findings or hypovascularised focal liver lesions.Image fusion to guide and monitor therapeutic interventionF.L. Giesel, H. von Tengg-Kobligk, M. McAuliffe, D. McGarry, B. Wood, S.L. Bacharach, M.V. Knopp; Bethesda, MD/USPurpose: Targeted therapies depend on exact delineation of tumor tissue in order to encompass the lesion while sparing surrounding parenchyma. To achieve best results, a combination of morphologic and functional imaging is necessary. In this study, image co-registration was evaluated to guide and monitor radiofrequency ablation (RFA) therapy in the abdomen. Materials and methods: A prospective co-registration pilot study was performed according to GCP in 7 patients (4 m, 3 f) with different kind of abdominal tumors (6 liver, 1 kidney) undergoing RFA. Morphological imaging was performed using CT and MRI prior to and after RFA. Functional studies included concurrent FDG-PET and dynamic MRI. A PC based, open-software (MIPAV, NIH, Bethesda, USA) was optimized for image co-registration that was based on anatomical landmarks using least squares or thin plate spline registration. Results: Co-registration was successfully done in all patients with fusion of two morphological image sets (pre-and post-RFA) as well as studies of different modalities. The processed image sets were review by an interventional radiologist and assessed regarding their information gain. The most helpful image fusion sets were determined to be A: assessment of treated against targeted volume and B: fusion of morphologic with functional imaging (CT/PET, PET/MRI, MRI/FMRI). Volume Rendering of co-registered data sets enabled direct 3D visualization. Conclusion: Advanced image processing including co-registration for image fusion is an essential tool to guide and monitor therapeutic interventions. Current software and findings in a pilot study are already promising to rapidly advance this into clinical practice

TABREF12.text: Purpose:To evaluate the utility of rotator cuff ultrasound in depicting tendinosis, tendinitis, partial and complete tears, bursal effusion and periarticular calcifications, compared with MRI examination. Methods and materials: 548 patients have been studied with ultrasound using high frequency probes by an experienced sonographer. The same patients have been successively studied with MRI by another radiologist unaware of ultrasound findings. Results and clinical impact have been compared and all examinations with discordant findings have been reviewed. Results: All complete tears of the rotator cuff evident at MRI have been depicted by ultrasound whereas only 89 % of partial tears were evident. In all cases ultrasound has depicted subacromial bursal effusion and periarticular calcification. Conclusion: In our experience ultrasound can depict very well large rotator cuff tears. Discordant findings review has demonstrated that ultrasound can depict and quantify better than MRI tendinosis and small chronic partial tears. In our experience we have observed that partial tears were missed by ultrasound in obese patients. On the other hand MRI motion artifacts in patients with pain suggests directly ultrasound examination. Surgeons confirm the tendency to consider MRI as the preoperative gold standard, specially in depicting muscular atrophy and intraarticular effusions and deep bursal effusions but we noted that only a small percentage of rotator cuff tear were surgically treated. In conclusion we suggest ultrasound as first shoulder examination and MRI only to evaluate possible surgical treatment.Rotator cuff tears of the shoulder: Dedicated MRI versus high field MRI, with arthroscopic correlationsA. Masciocchi 1 ; 1 L'Aquila/IT, 2 Milan/IT Purpose: This work aims to verify the diagnostic capability of dedicated (E-SCAN) and whole body MRI units in the evaluation of rotator cuff pathology in respect to surgical findings. Materials and methods: Forty patients affected by rotator cuff dysfunction entered this study. In all cases MR examination was performed using both dedicated and whole body units. In selected cases arthro-MRI was employed to differentiate tendonitis from partial tears and partial from complete tears. All the patients underwent surgery. Considering surgery as the gold standard, the analysis of the results was conducted, comparing data from dedicated and whole body MR units. Results: Results from arthro-MRI performed on both whole body and dedicated units were compared with surgical findings. In nine cases of complete tendon tear both dedicated and whole body MR examinations revealed the lesions in agreement with the surgical findings. In one of the three cases of surgically proved partial tendon tears, dedicated MRI failed to reveal the lesion whilst it was detected by the whole body MR unit. Intra-articular injection of contrast medium allowed detection of the partial tear also using the dedicated unit. In 28 cases of high grade tendonitis both dedicated and whole body MRI revealed the lesion and arthro-MR, when performed, confirmed the absence of partial tendon tears. Conclusion: High correspondence was found between dedicated and whole body MR-units data when compared to surgical findings.MR arthrography in the unstable shoulder: a cost-benefit analysis J.A. Ahovuo, T. Visuri; Helsinki/FIPurpose: To assess the cost-benefit of MR arthrography in detection of the lesions of the glenolabral complex in unstable shoulder joint. Material and methods: 81 patients (age 17 -27 years, mean 20) suffering from dislocation of the shoulder underwent MR arthrography of the shoulder. 42 of them also underwent arthroscopy of the shoulder. MR arthrography showed 54 abnor-In favour of MR arthrography, the savings would have been 12806 • . The use of MR arthrography would save 22 % of the costs used in arthroscopy. Conclusion: MR arthrography is a cost-benefit tool in assessing the lesions of the glenolabral complex in unstable shoulder.Conclusion:On the bases of our experience we postulated arthro-MR to be a worthy diagnostic mean in the evaluation of traumatic and non-traumatic shoulder instability.Value of spiral CT arthrography in the assessment of the entire knee cartilage in cadavers B. vande Berg 1 , F.E. Lecouvet 1 , P. Poilvache 1 , R. Materne 1 , J. Jamart 2 , B. Maldague 1 , B. Lengele 1 , J. Malghem 1 ; 1 Brussels/BE, 2 Yvoir/BE Purpose: To assess the value of spiral CT arthrography (SCTA) for grading of articular lesions of the entire knee. Materials and methods: Twelve cadaver knees were investigated by means of Interobserver agreement was moderate for grading articular surfaces, and substantial for detecting grade 2A or higher and grade 2B or higher areas. Intraobserver agreement was substantial for grading articular surfaces and almost perfect for detecting grade 2A or higher and grade 2B or higher areas. Conclusion: SCTA is a valuable imaging modality for the assessment of the articular cartilage of the entire knee.

TABREF13.text: Correlation of bone mineral density determined by radiogrammetry and DEXA-measurements on different locations in patients suffering from rheumatoid arthritis -initial resultsA. Malich, G. Lehmann, A. Pfeil, J. Böttcher, J.-P. Heyne, W.A. Kaiser; Jena/DE Purpose: To evaluate the potential clinical value of a newly available bone densitometric technology based on radiogrammetry. Patients and methods: 50 randomly selected patients suffering from rheumatoid arthritis were included. Each patient has had bone mineral density (BMD) measurements of femoral neck and spine, using DEXA equipment. A radiograph of the hand has been acquired within 7 days of the DEXA-measurements. Radiogrammetry based bone densitometric system seems to be of promising clinical value due to a close correlation to DEXA-values, especially of the femoral neck. In patients receiving X-ray of the hand for e.g. diagnostic purposes, this new technology might be able to reduce additional radiation exposure.Diffusion imaging in osteoporosisE.C. Kavanagh, M. O'Connell, G.C.A. Hargaden, S. Eustace; Dublin/IE Purpose: To evaluate the role of diffusion imaging in the assessment of bone density, in particular osteoporosis.

TABREF14.text: Purpose:The assessment of Bone Mineral Density (BMD) in patients with homozygous -thalassaemia with DEXA and QCT and their correlation. Materials/methods: We studied the lumbar vertebrae of 79 patients with QCT and we classified them according to the number of trabeculae. BMD of trabecular, cortical bone, and Z scores were measured. DEXA was performed in 51 patients. Most of the patients were treated with Disodium Pamidronate. After one year, we resumed the measurements. We have already reassessed 12 patients.Conclusion:Both methods indicate a progression of osteoporosis with age. There is a good agreement of Z and BMD values between DEXA and QCT. QCT is more reliable than DEXA and provides additional data, such as the trabeculae number, thickness and distribution. DEXA overestimates osteoporosis. Reassessment shows a great response of cortical bone to treatment. PFR. The quantitative assessment by SPA was excellent in the cortical but not in the trabecular bone. HRCT offered quantitative and structural informations in cortical as well in trabecular bone. All three methods resulted significant differences between normal and osteoporotic bone. PFR produced the highest sensitivity while the highest specificity was found by using HRCT. The results of the three methods were highly convergent. Conclusion: Microradiography, clinical HRCT and SPA are relevant methods with comparable sensitivity, precision and accuracy. The combination of these techniques promises highest power to predict bone strength and risk of osteoporotic fractures.Purpose: Bone mineral density (BMD) evaluation without special densitometry equipment. Radiographic absorbtiometry upgrade by means of digital X-ray unit. Materials and methods: A digital X-ray unit was used for image acquisition of forearms and hands placed in special water container together with reference aluminium wedge. Original densitometry software calculated bone mineral density in grams per cm 2 in aluminium equivalent in distal part of radius and phalanges. 71 females with rheumatoid arthritis (RA) of differing stages and activity (39 patients were < 45 years old) together with a control group of 20 young healthy adults and 15 healthy older patients were examined by this technique.

TABREF15.text: Purpose: Aim of this study was to evaluate if MS-CT allows precise depiction of ossification after implantation of tissue engineered bone and if it is therefore possible to reduce the number of necessary animal experiments.

TABREF17.text: The technical feasibility and clinical applicability of diffusion-weighted SENSE-EPI in patients with sub-acute stroke was demonstrated. This novel technique is able to reduce typical EPI artifacts and to increase spatial resolution while simultaneously being quite insensitive to bulk motion. Our results indicate that SENSE can be combined with DTI and might be an important adjunct for future neuroimaging applications using this technique.Clinical usefulness of turbo-FLAIR and DW-EPI imaging in patients withhyperacute and acute stroke -a comparative study J.A. Sikorska, T.J. Bulski, J. Walecki, M.L. Nowicki; Warsaw/PL DWI shows higher sensitivity in detection of early ischemic lesions as compared to T-FLAIR. DWI allows differentiation of new and chronic ischemic foci in patients with multifocal changes. The clinical course of the ischemic stroke is better in patients with lesions that are silent on T-FLAIR. EPI DWI is sensitive in detecting haemorrhagic stroke.Purpose: Conventional postoperative evaluation of patients following carotid thromboendarterectomy (TEA) consists of a clinical neurologic examination to assess neurologic deficits, color duplex ultrasound to document the surgically reestablished patency of the carotid artery and CT for exclusion of postoperative ischemic infarctions. Recent studies prove that diffusion-weighted MRI is more sensitive in the detection of fresh insults than conventional MRI and CT. The objective of the study was to ascertain the incidence of clinically asymptomatic peri-and postoperative ischemic infarctions visualized at MRI. MRI returned findings of fresh disturbances of diffusion suggestive of ischemia that were not visualized on preoperative scans. Discrete neurologic deficits were observed in only two (3.9 %) of these patients. Deficits were transient and disappeared within 72 h. Conclusion: Our findings underscore MRI's capacity for visualizing perioperative ischemic events. Moreover, MRI provides evidence of clinically asymptomatic embolisms that occur perioperatively. The high rate of asymptomatic embolic lesions after aortic valve replacement, newly detected by DW-EPI MRI, makes frequency and volume of these lesions suitable parameters to evaluate the effectiveness of future neuroprotective strategies in cardiac surgery. Markers of neuronal destruction did not show to be valuable in this setting.

TABREF34.text: The image characteristics of different plaque components were determined based on signal intensity in comparison to surrounding muscles. Results: High resolution MRI was able to delineate vessel lumen from atherosclerotic lesion. Severe calcifications were seen as a signal void on all sequences. However, small calcified spots could not be distinguished from surrounding fibrous tissue. Fibrous tissue showed a high signal on both PDw and T2w sequences, and an intermediate signal on the T1w images. Lipid core showed a hyperintense signal on PDw images and a hypointense signal on T2w images. T1w images revealed no different signal intensity between fibrous tissue and lipid core. Conclusion: High resolution MRI of the carotid artery is able to characterize different atherosclerotic plaque components. This technique may be useful in the selection of patients for CEA.

Most patients show no signs of residual PR and both RVEDV and RVESV decrease dramatically, although no improvement in RVEF is found. TABREF41.text: Quantitative MR perfusion imaging of pharyngeal tumors: Is there additional information available from the time course of T2*? V. Hietschold 1 , T. Kittner 1 , N. Abolmaali 2 ; 1 Dresden/DE, 2 Frankfurt a. Main/DE Purpose: To derive information about the diversity of vascularization of tissue from the transient signal loss during the passage of paramagnetic contrast medium (CM). The time course of T2 * change is interpreted to result from different blood pathways (eg normal vascularization vs. shunts) giving rise to different curve shapes overlaying each other. Methods and materials: Investigations were performed on 8 patients suffering from pharyngeal tumors prior to and occasionally during radiation therapy. 0.2 mmol/kg of CM were injected as a bolus (Magnevist, Schering). Measurements were performed at 1.5 T (Magnetom Vision, Siemens; Symphony, Siemens) using double echo flash sequences. The change of T2 * in time was modeled overlaying two γ variate functions (GVF) or a simplified model basically consisting of two triangles.Results:The two-GVF model fits the data plausibly. Nevertheless, the simplified model gives more stable results due to the reduced number of free parameters. Preliminary evaluations show the AIF to be describable with one GVF (or triangle resp.). In 5 of 7 evaluable cases the T2 * course from tumor tissue is fit more plausibly by the two-pathway models. In all 3 evaluable samples of non-affected muscle, the broader model component seems to be at least less prominent compared to tumors. Conclusion: The passage of a CM bolus through pharyngeal tumor tissue can be modeled more plausibly with two-pathway models compared to the description with one-GVF models. Further studies will have to analyse the correlation of the findings presented here to vascularization properties and their prognostic value.Biological characterization and response monitoring in head andneck cancer therapy using multislice perfusion CT W. Römer, L. Muresan, B. Adamietz, G.G. Grabenbauer, H. Greess, W.A. Kalender, W.A. Bautz; Erlangen/DE

TABREF42.text: Nonenhanced helical CT (NHCT) vs. plain films (KUB) plus ultrasound (US)for acute flank pain -part 2: Prospective comparison of practical impact in two patients groups F. Sandomenico, O. Catalano, R. Lobianco, A. Siani; Naples/IT Purpose: To prospectively evaluate the cost-effectiveness of two different imaging approaches for urinary colic. Methods and materials: January 1999 to December 2000 we randomised the subjects with acute flank pain, 48 patients to NHCT and 48 to plain radiographs and US with the selective addition of NHCT in unclear cases. Results: In the first group a final diagnosis was available in 40 cases. CT depicted 20 out of 23 cases of ureterolithiasis; all false negatives were followed by stone expulsion. Three subjects underwent urologic treatment and all showed calculi on NHCT images. CT detected 4 of 5 alternative diagnoses with 1 false positive. In the second group a diagnosis was obtained in 39 patients. Combined US and plain films were positive in 15 of 21 patients with calculi; all false negatives were followed by uncomplicated course. Plain film was falsely positive for ureterolithiasis in 1 case. There was 1 false negative for alternative cause and 1 false positive. NHCT was performed in 11 out of 22 patients with a negative US plus radiographic evaluation, detecting a stone in 4. All 3 patients requiring an invasive management were positive on combined US and radiographs. Conclusion: Selective use of NHCT after US plus plain films is more cost-effective than primary use of this technique.Unenhanced helical CT (UHCT) vs. plain films (KUB) plus ultrasound (US)for acute flank pain -part 1: Prospective comparison of diagnostic accuracy in the same group of patients F. Sandomenico 1 , O. Catalano 1 , A. Nunziata 2 , A. Siani 1 ; 1 Pozzuoli/IT, 2 Naples/IT Purpose: To compare the accuracy of NHCT and of combined US and plain radiographs in patients with acute flank pain suspected for urinary colic. Methods and materials: From January 1997 to December 1999 181 consecutive patients (108 male and 73 female, age 19 -73 years, mean 40 years) were prospectively imaged because of suspected renal colic. History of nephrolithiasis or previous colics was present in 36 subjects while microhematuria was identified in 51. Patients first underwent combined plain films and US (including vesical jet colour-Doppler analysis); UHCT was successively performed blindly.Results: UHCT had a greater sensitivity (92 % vs. 77 %), negative predictive value (87 % vs. 68 %), and overall accuracy (94 % vs. 83 %) compared to KUB plus US. Nevertheless all 17 cases correctly depicted by UHCT and missed by US plus plain films were due to small stones and all but one had an uncomplicated course with spontaneous calculus expulsion. The differences in specificity (96 % vs. 93 %) and positive predictive value (98 % vs. 95 %), and the difference in detecting alternative causes of pain were not significant. Conclusion: Plain film plus US is effective in screening for urinary colic, mainly missing minor colics due to tiny, spontaneously expulsed stones. UHCT is more accurate but primary use of this technique is overestimating since it carries limited practical consequences.Spiral CT evaluation of the chemical composition of renal calculiR. Renard-Penna 1 , M.-F. Bellin 2 , J.-B. Meric 2 , P. Conort 1 , M. Daudon 1 , V. Hopirtean 1 , F. Richard 1 , P.A. Grenier 1 ; 1 Paris/FR, 2 Villejuif/FR Purpose:To evaluate the ability of dual voltage spiral CT to assess the chemical composition of renal calculi. Methods and materials: 100 human renal calculi, randomly chosen from among 7 chemically pure or mixed groups were surgically placed in 5 calices (2/pole + 1 in the middle) in each of 20 excised pig kidneys. Each kidney was then examined with 2 spiral CT scanners (Somatom Plus 4, Elscint-CT Twin Flash) at 80 -90 and 120 kV with 3 mm collimation. Two independent observers identified the regions of interest on each slice and mean CT density values of the whole calculus projection area were calculated. The relationship between CT values with calculus chemical composition determined by infrared spectrophotometry was studied. Paired tests were used and the interobserver variability was measured. Results: Seven groups of calculi were defined according to their predominant component: uric acid (n = 18), cystine (n = 9), struvite (n = 14), calcium oxalate monohydrate (n = 22), weddellite (n = 10), whewellite (n = 24), or brushite (n = 3). The maximal diameter of the calculi ranged from 4 to 27 mm (mean 9.8 ± 5 mm). Only dual kilovoltage CT values for pure cystine (363 -586 HU) and uric acid (287 -408 HU) calculi differed significantly from those of brushite (917 -1354 HU). Conclusion: Spiral CT cannot distinguish between the most common types of human calculi, except uric acid/cystine and brushite calculi.Renal diffusion and bold MR imaging in experimental diabetic nephropathy F. Basseau, N. Grenier, M. Ries, R.A. Jones, B. Tyndal, C. Deminière, C. Combe, C.T.W. Moonen; Bordeaux/FR

TABREF46.text: Conclusion:On-line antomically adapted tube current modulation with a predefined dose saving of 20 % (PDS 20 %) allows a mean dose reduction of 35 % at the level of the thoracic outlet without alteration of objective and subjective image quality.Visibility of low-contrast lesions in volume rendering: A phantom study using multislice CT data H.-O. Shin, C. von Falck, M. Galanski; Hannover/DE Purpose: To cope with the large data volumes produced by multislice CT, there is increasing interest in the use of volume rendering (VRT) as a diagnostic tool. Visibility of low contrast lesions was evaluated comparing use of a volume rendering tool with different transfer functions and with the original slices. Material and methods: A phantom consisting of spheres of different diameters (2 -6 mm, 1 mm increment) was placed in a sugar solution (contrast: 40 HU ± 25 HU) and scanned on a GE Lightspeed QX/I (slice width: 2.5 mm, Pitch 6, reconstruction interval: 2 mm). VRT was performed by mapping HU-values to gray levels equal to a CT window used for film viewing (center: 60 HU, window: 370 HU). A linear ramp was applied for the opacity transfer function varying the maximum opacity between 0.1 to 1.0 in 0.1 steps. No gradient transfer function was used. In the resulting images Regions of Interest were placed in all visible spheres (lesions) and in the sugar solution (background) on each slice. A statistical method based on the rose model was used to calculate the detection threshold (minimum grey level difference: MGLD) depending on lesion size and image noise. Results: Low contrast detectability (LCD) in VRT is comparable to the original slices. The observed loss in contrast in VRT is largely compensated by a decrease in image noise. Contrast-to-MGLD-Ratio: 2 and 3 mm: not visible/measurable, 4 mm: Conclusion: VRT shows comparable performance in LCD to the original slices.CT fluoroscopy: Evaluation of patient and staff radiation doses N. Buls, J. Pages, J. De Mey, M. Osteaux; Brussels/BE Purpose: Computed Tomography Fluoroscopy (CTF) is widely used as a guidance tool for various interventions such as biopsies, fluid collection aspirations, drainages, radio-frequency ablations and local drug injections. However, there is a potential for significantly high patient and staff radiation doses due to the high CT exposure settings and accompanying amount of scatter radiation. The purpose of this study is to evaluate both patient and staff exposure during various CTF procedures. Methods and materials: Up to now, 51 studies (31 biopsies, 6 aspirations, 8 drainages and 7 RF-ablations) were evaluated. For every patient, the exposure was quantified by estimating the effective dose (E) and by measuring the skin dose (ESD) with thermoluminescent dosimetry (TLD-100). Staff exposure was quantified for each procedure by estimating skin doses at different positions on the body (eyes, thyroid and hands) by using TLD-100H chips. Results: The following median values were determined (data per procedure): patient E (20.6 mSv), patient skin dose (354 mGy), staff ESD (in mGy) at eye level (0.22), thyroid level (0.24), at the left hand (0.17) and at the right hand (0.77). Conclusion: Although CTF patient doses are high compared to doses from standard CT examinations, no skin doses were observed which exceeded the 2 Gy threshold level for transient erythema. From the dosimetric data presented in this study, it is clear that CTF procedures require special attention to patient and staff protection. Actions to reduce the dose in terms of additional protection and limiting the exposure factors are applied.Dose reduction in multislice computed tomography by on-line tube current control W. Hundt 1 , F. Rust 1 , A. Staebler 1 , H. Wolf 2 , C. Suess 2 , M.F. Reiser 1 ; 1 Munich/DE, Purpose: Investigation of the attenuation-based on-line modulation of tube current to reduce the dose of multislice computed tomography.Material and methods: 25 patients (11 female, 14 male) had a follow up CT investigation of the thorax, abdomen or both together. The Multislice CT scanner (Somatom Plus 4 VZ, Siemens, Erlangen) was equipped with a prototype for tube current modulation. Except for tube current all acquisition parameter (collimation, pitch, KV) and reconstruction parameter (slice, increment, kernel) were identical.

MRE is inferior to MSCTE concerning interobserver agreement and sensitivity in detecting small bowel disease.MRI of the small bowel in the evaluation of coeliac disease in paediatric patientsA. Laghi, I. Carbone, I. Baeli, R. Iannaccone, P. Paolantonio, S. Trenna, C. Catalano, R. Passariello; Rome/IT Purpose: The aim of this study was to evaluate MR findings of the small bowel in a paediatric population of patients with suspected coeliac disease. Subjects and methods: Fourteen patients with clinical and laboratory findings indicating possible coeliac disease underwent MR study of the small bowel. After an overnight fast, immediately before MR examination a fixed amount of 10 ml/kg of weight of PEG solution was orally administered. No antispasmodic drug or other drugs were given. MR study was performed using HASTE (TR/TE/acq.t.: inf/90 ms/ 18 s) and truFISP (TR/TE/acq.t.: 4.8 ms/2.3 ms/14 s) sequences obtained sequentially for up to 20 minutes, on axial and coronal planes. Images obtained were analysed by two experienced gastrointestinal radiologists by consensus. Results: No alterations of bowel habit occurred.

TABREF48.text: Spiral CT enterography after oral administration of polyethylene glycol (PEG) solution in patients with Crohn's diseaseL. Crespi, V. Kirn, M. Tonolini, F. Croce, D. Della Chiesa, L. Solbiati; Busto Arsizio/IT Purpose: To evaluate the accuracy of spiral CT examination after bowel distention by means of oral isoosmotic solution (spiral CT enterography) in patients affected with Crohn disease. Methods: We performed 44 spiral CT examinations on 43 patients, of which 32 with suspected or confirmed Crohn disease and 11 as a control group. The degree of bowel loops' distention, obtained with oral administration of 2250 ml of polyethylene glycol electrolyte (PEG) balanced solution, was independently evaluated by two different radiologists. The results of CT enterography in patients with Crohn disease were compared with conventional radiologic studies in 22 cases, with endoscopy in 7 and with surgery in 4. Results: Both observers judged distention of the bowel loops to be adequate in more than 90 % of the patients. Crohn disease was diagnosed by CT in 27 cases, with 43 intestinal localized lesions of the disease. The sensitivity of CT enterography was 92.8 % (95 % if referred to detection of localized lesions), specificity 93.7 % and diagnostic accuracy 93.2 %. Conclusion: This method allows a good distention of the loops, is able to show extraluminal findings and complications of Crohn disease such as fibro-fatty proliferation, phlegmon, abscess, entero-enteric and entero-cutaneous fistulae. CT enterography may therefore be considered as the first choice to evaluate patients with acute or suspected disease.Magnetic resonance enteroclysis comprehensive imaging protocol: Application of HASTE, true FISP and post gadolinium 3D flash with fat saturation sequences N. Papanikolaou, P.K. Prassopoulos, J. Grammatikakis, M. Roussomoustakaki, T.G. Maris, E. Kouroumalis, N. Gourtsoyiannis; Iraklion/GR Purpose: To apply HASTE, true FISP and post-gadolinium fat suppressed 3DFLASH sequences for small bowel imaging with MR Enteroclysis. Materials and methods: Eighteen consecutive patients with suspected small bowel disease underwent MR Enteroclysis examination. HASTE, true FISP and postgadolinium fat suppressed 3D FLASH coronal and axial slices were acquired during breath-holding. A maximum amount of 2 l of iso-osmotic water solution was administered via a nasojejunal catheter. Small bowel distension, conspicuity of the wall, homogeneity of lumen opacification and artifacts presence were evaluated on a 5-point grading scale. Signal to noise ratio (SNR) of normal and thickened intestinal wall and lumen was calculated. Contrast to noise ratio (CNR) of normal intestinal wall -lumen and thickened intestinal wall -lumen were assessed in all. Results: Small bowel distention and wall conspicuity was excellent in all three sequences. True FISP and 3D FLASH sequences provided homogeneous lumen opacification, while HASTE images hampered by intraluminal flow voids, only when antiperistaltic drugs were not used. True FISP sequence was sensitive to susceptibility and black boundary artifacts, while 3D FLASH to motion artifacts. True FISP sequence provided significantly higher (p < 0.01) CNR between the normal intestinal wall and lumen comparing to HASTE and 3D FLASH sequences, while 3D FLASH provided significantly higher (p < 0.01) CNR between thickened wall and lumen comparing to true FISP and HASTE sequences. Conclusion: A comprehensive MRE protocol including true FISP, HASTE and 3D FLASH sequences, can provide integrated information from small bowel lumen, wall and surrounding tissues.Effect of subcutaneous butylscopolamine administration in the reduction of peristaltic artifacts in 1.5 T MR fast abdominal examinations L. Martí-Bonmatí, R. Dosdá, E. Mollá, E. Arana; Valencia/ES Purpose: In abdominal MR imaging, ghost artifacts from bowel movements can reduce the quality of the images. Although pharmacologic supression of motion is effective, no study has being conducted to analyse its influence on fast breath hold 1.5 T examinations.

TABREF49.text: Magnetic resonance imaging in Crohn's disease: Comparison of MRsellink with MRI of the small bowel P. Heim, M. Bonacker, V. Schoder, M. Bläker, A. de Weerth, P. Steiner, G.B. Adam; Hamburg/DE Purpose:To compare the accuracy of MRI in Crohn's disease adopting the MR-Sellink technique with and without jejunal intubation. Materials and methods: 20 patients with known or suspected inflammatory bowel disease were prospectively examined. All patients underwent an enteroclysis. In 10/20 randomized patients ferrooxide was added to the methylcellulose-contrast (MR-Sellink). The other 10/20 patients swallowed 600 ml ferrooxide and 300 ml were administered rectally 1 -3 days following enteroclysis (conventional MRI). MRI was performed adopting T2w HASTE, T2w FSE and T1w GRE sequences. After i.v. administration of Gd-DTPA i.v. (0.1 mmol/kg BW) a 3D GRE (VIBE) and T1w GRE sequence was added. Bowel distension, lesion length, wall thickness, contrast uptake and extraintestinal complications were reviewed independantly by two readers who were blinded to the findings of enteroclysis and surgery if performed. The Cohen's kappa test was used for data analysis. Results: Preliminary data showed a high level of correspondence in diagnosing Crohn's disease by means of enteroclysis, MR-Sellink with and without duodenal intubation. In all patients the diagnostic accuracy of T1w sequences seemed to be significantly higher after intravenous enhancement compared to the unenhanced T1w GRE sequences. Fast T2-w sequences and enhanced T1w sequences at MR-Sellink showed the same accuracy as the contrast enhanced 3D GRE (VIBE) sequence in both groups.Conclusion: MR-examinations with or without intubation revealed comparable diagnostic accuracies.MRI of carcinoid tumors in the gastrointestinal tractT.R. Bader 1 , R.C. Semelka 2 , V.C.Y. Chiu 2 , J.T. Woosley 2 ; 1 Vienna/AT, 2 Chapel Hill, NC/US Purpose: To evaluate the spectrum of MRI appearances of primary gastrointestinal carcinoid tumors. Methods and materials: The MR examinations of 29 patients (11 men, 18 women; age range 33 -87 years) with histologically confirmed gastrointestinal carcinoid tumors were retrospectively reviewed. 12 patients had MR examinations prior to resection or biopsy of the primary tumor (preoperative group), 17 patients were imaged postsurgically (postoperative group). All MR studies were performed at 1.5 T comprising: T1-weighted spoiled gradient echo (SGE), T2-weighted fat-suppressed turbo spin echo, HASTE, and serial postgadolinium T1-weighted SGE sequences without and with fat-suppression. Morphology, signal intensity, and contrast enhancement of primary tumors, and of metastases to the mesentery and peritoneum were evaluated. Results: Primary carcinoid tumors were visualized in 8 of 12 patients (66.7 %). The appearance of primary tumors was a nodular mass originating from bowel wall (4 patients) or regional uniform bowel wall thickening (4 of 12 patients) with moderate intense enhancement on postgadolinium images. In 4 of 12 patients (33.3 %) the primary tumor was prospectively not seen. 9 mesenteric metastases (in 8 patients) were observed presenting as nodular, spiculated masses showing moderate gadolinium enhancement, and were associated with mesenteric stranding in 7 patients. 5 patients showed peritoneal metastases that presented as multiple peritoneal implants demonstrating moderate to intense gadolinium enhancement on early postcontrast images. Conclusion: MRI is a helpful tool for the visualization of carcinoid tumors of the gastrointestinal tract.Spiral CT findings in patients with SMV thrombosis: Correlation with surgeryA. Oto, U. TABREF51.text: Combined/split 3D greyscale/colour Doppler imaging shows vascular morphology of breast lesions in greater detailW.E. Svensson, K. Humphries, P. Holt, A. McBride, D. Barratt, P. Stanley, P. Forouhi, A. Welsh; London/GB Aim: To determine the potential of a new method of demonstrating breast tumour vascularization using 3-dimensional ultrasound imaging techniques. Methods: Combined greyscale and colour Doppler volume data sets images have been obtained freehand from over 400 patients, using the 15 MHz transducer on the Acuson Sequoia system. Data sets are processed using in house software and the VoxBlast TM software to produce 3D combined semi-transparent greyscale/ colour split blocks. Results: 124 lesions (59 fibroadenomas, 24 cancers, 14 inflammatory masses, and 19 other benign conditions) have been reviewed so far. External and internal vascular morphology is better demonstrated using split 3D views of grey scale and vascular information than in either 2D images, 3D vascular only or transparent 3D block images. Enumeration of vessels in, around and within lesions is now possible. Combined greyscale and vascular information permits immediate accurate assessment of the relationship of vessels to the lesion. The radial feeding vessels and chaotic distribution of vessels within cancers is more easily appreciated. The marginal distribution of vessels in vascular fibroadenomas allows more diagnostic certainty. All cancers had suspicious features and over half of the fibroadenomas had definite benign features on 3D images alone. Diagnostic accuracy of these 3D images in combination with real time grey scale and colour Doppler examination is currently being assessed. Conclusions: These initial results already show that the 3-dimensional ultrasound angiographic techniques described demonstrate vascular morphology of breast lesions more accurately than heretofore.Does real-time compound imaging improve evaluation of breast cancer compared to conventional sonography? B. Seo, Y. Oh, H. Noh, J. Lee, N. Lee, J. Kim, S. Kim; Seoul/KR Purpose: Real-time compound imaging obtains multiple coplanar tomographic ultrasound images and combines them into a single compound image, reducing acoustic artefacts and noise. The purpose of this study is to determine if real-time compound imaging improves evaluation of breast cancer compared to conventional sonography. Materials and methods: 25 breast cancers were included in this study from May 2000 to July 2001. 22 of 25 patients were invasive ductal carcinoma and the remaining three were DCIS. Each image pair consisted of a conventional ultrasound and a real-time compound image with a stationary probe, to maintain an identical Real-time compound imaging improves contrast, margin, internal echotexture and internal microcalcification of the breast cancer. But compound image is not effective to evaluate posterior echo pattern of the breast cancer. MR-guided localization of suspicious breast lesions with embolization coils K.C. Siegmann, C. Gorriz, N. Methods and materials: We performed 55 coil localizations in 46 patients (mean age 49.5 a) with suspected breast lesions only detectable by MRI. Imaging of one breast was performed with a surface coil at 1.0 T (Magnetom Expert, Siemens Medical Systems, Erlangen, Germany). Dynamic contrast enhanced imaging was used for lesion detection (T1w-FLASH 3D, 0.16 mmol Gd-DTPA/kg BW). For needle guidance and lesion localisation a perforated plate with integrated markers and an MR-compatible 19

TABREF52.text: Follow-up after MR-guided vacuum biopsy (MR-VB)A. Heinig, B. Amaya, L. Hefler, T. Alberich, D. Lampe, S.H. Heywang-Köbrunner; Halle a. d. Saale/DE Purpose: To evaluate reliability of a negative diagnosis by MR-VB. Materials and methods: Between January 1, 1997 and September 30, 1999, 173 MR-guided vacuum biopsies have been performed. A dedicated breast biopsy coil was used on a 1.0 MR unit (Impact Expert, Siemens, Erlangen). Results: Apart from 47 malignancies (27 invasive cancers, 20 DCIS) and 4 atypical ductal hyperplasias (ADH) 122 benign diagnoses were obtained by MR-VB. Follow-up ranges between 6 -54 months. Follow-up failed in 13 patients. In 82 cases no lesion and absent (n = 63) or moderate diffuse enhancement (n = 19) was seen. Partial lesion removal was documented in 16 cases. An additional 4 lesions, in which after partial removal histopathological correlation appeared not sufficiently certain, the benign diagnosis was confirmed by open surgery. In one patient, in whom bloody nipple discharge occurred during follow-up, benign papillomatosis was confirmed. In 6 other cases benign changes in the area in question were confirmed by surgery (4 mastectomies, 2 subcutaneous mastectomies performed for other reasons or changes). Overall no false negative diagnosis occurred. Conclusion: A negative result by MR-VB based on pre-and post-interventional imaging and imaging-histology correlation is very reliable.Ultrasound-guided cryotherapy for breast cancer: Preliminary resultsS.O.R.
