TABREF55.text: Evaluation of prostate cancer with dynamic contrast-enhanced MRI: Comparison to thin section histology C.H. Coulam, F.G. Sommer, J. McNeil, R. Nolley, H. Gill, B.L. Daniel; Stanford, CA/US Purpose: Determine accuracy of dynamic gadolinium-enhanced prostate MRI for detection of Gleason grade III -V cancer.Methods: Whole-prostate dynamic Gd-enhanced MRI was performed on eight men prior to prostatectomy using multiphase 3D spoiled GRE imaging. (1.5 T scanner; external phased-array coil; TR/TE 3.7/0.7 ms; spatial resolution 2.8 × 2.8 × 3 mm; temporal resolution 10 s/frame; 20 consecutive frames). Parametric maps of the enhancement integral (EI) were generated by integrating voxel signal intensity over time. Early EI (EEI) (integration over first 2 enhanced frames) and total EI (TEI) (integration of all enhanced frames) images were generated and correlated with 3 mm serial section histopathology maps. Peripheral zone was divided into sextants and maximal EI values recorded for each sextant on both EEI and TEI images. Four threshold levels of EI values were considered for determination of "positive for cancer" on MRI. Results: Histology maps showed grade III -IV tumour in all 8 prostates, and 18 sextant peripheral zone regions. The sensitivity/specificity/PPV/NPV based on Conclusions: We found no useful correlation between the magnitude of either early or total enhancement integral maps and the location of grade III -IV tumour on thin section histology.Quantitative dynamic MR imaging indicates mikrovessel density in prostate carcinoma H.-P.W. Schlemmer 1 , J. Merkle 1 , R. Grobholz 2 , A. Werner 2 , T. Jäger 2 , H. Hawighorst 3 , J. Rabe 4 , M. Siegsmund 2 , G. van Kaick 1 ; 1 Heidelberg/DE, 2 Mannheim/DE, 3 Nottwil/CH, 4 Karlsruhe/DEPurpose: To evaluate the correlation between dynamic contrast-enhanced MRI (dMRI) parameters and microvessel density in carcinoma of the prostate. Methods and materials: MRI examinations with combined endorectal-body phased-array coil were performed in 27 patients with biopsy proven prostate carcinoma before surgery (1.0 T Magnetom Harmony, Siemens, Germany). After multiplanar T2-and T1-weighted MR imaging dMRI was performed using a fast dynamic T1-weighted turbo-FLASH sequence (TR/TE 1300/4.2 ms; TI = 654 ms; 10 slices, 4 mm slice thickness) during and after administration of 1 mmol/kg Gd-DTPA (22 repetitions). For image processing a pharmacokinetic 2-compartment model calculating for contrast enhancement (A) and contrast exchange rate (k21) was used on an independent workstation. Microvessels were stained using a CD31 monoclonal antibody (DAKO, Hamburg, Germany). The microvessel density (MVD) was quantified on surgical specimens by (a) counting microvessels in 3 high power fields and (b) determining the area fraction (%) of microvessels by morphometry (Leica, Bensheim, Germany) in 5 high power fields. In corresponding anatomic locations on MR images the mean A and k21 values were calculated and correlated to MVD. Results: MVD in tumour tissue was significantly higher than in surrounding nontumour tissue (p < 0.0001). The number of microvessels correlated with the area fraction (p < 0.0001). Area fraction and number of MVD were both significantly correlated to k21 (r = 0.80, p < 0.0001 and r = 0.62, p < 0.0001, respectively). No association was found between A and MVD. Conclusion: DMRI has the potential to indicate tumour neovascularization and may be important for the individual therapy management of prostate cancer patients.Non-invasive prostate cancer staging: A combined approach of T2weighted and parametrically analysed dynamic T1-weighted magnetic resonance imaging B.N. Bloch 1 , E. Furman-Haran 2 , H. Degani 2 , B. Djavan 1 , A. Haitel 1 , M. Susani 1 , G.M. Heinz-Peer 1 , C. Seitz 1 , T.H. Helbich 1 ; 1 Vienna/AT, 2 Rehovot/ILPurpose: To assess a combined approach of T2-and dynamic T1-weighted MR imaging (MRI) for non-invasive prostate cancer staging. Materials and methods: MRI of the prostate was performed on a 1.5 T unit (Vision, Siemens, DE) with combined surface and endo-rectal coils (Prostate-Coil, Medrad, USA) in 15 patients prior prostatectomy. T2-weighted TSE (4000/83/ 05 min 24 s; FOV 120) and dynamic contrast enhanced (Magnevist, Schering, DE) T1-weighted 3D-FLASH (8.1/4/01 min 35 s; FOV 160; 2 pre-, 5 postcontrast acquisitions) sequences were acquired. Dynamic T1-weighted images were analysed by a new three-time-point pharmacokinetic model. Vascular permeability and extracellular fraction volume were assessed with this model. T2-weighted images and the parametrically analysed dynamic T1-weighted images were evaluated separately and in combination by 2 independent readers. Tumour size, localization, and multicentricity, as well as extracapsular disease, infiltration of the seminal vesicles, and penetration of the neurovascular bundle were assessed. MRI data were correlated with the histopathological results. Results: On T2-weighted images tumour size and multicentricity (5/15 in the central and transitional zone, 1/15 in the peripheral zone) were underestimated in 6/15 cases. On dynamic T1-weighted images 2/15 cases (1/15 peripheral zone, 1/15 central zone) were underestimated and 3/15 cases overestimated (1/15 infiltration of seminal vesicles, 2/15 extracapsular disease). The combined evaluation of both sequences allowed an accurate tumour staging in all 15 cases. Conclusion: A combined approach of T2-and dynamic T1-weighted MRI is a reliable and non-invasive method for prostate cancer staging. Especially in the central and transitional zone of the prostate dynamic imaging facilitates accurate tumour localization.MR imaging of prostate cancer: Comparison of staging performance using pelvic phased-array and integrated endorectal pelvic phased-array coils J.J. Fütterer, M.R.W. Engelbrecht, G.J. Jager, J.J.M.C. De La Rosette, J.G. Blickman; Nijmegen/NLPurpose: To compare staging performance and anatomical detail using pelvic phased-array coil (PPA), integrated endorectal pelvic phased-array coil (ERC-PPA) and dynamic contrast enhanced MRI (dynMRI) in prostate cancer. Methods and materials: MRI was performed on 37 patients with prostate cancer, prior to radical prostatectomy on a 1.5 T scanner. T2-w FSE (axial views) images of the prostate were obtained using (1) PPA, (2) ERC-PPA and (3) T1-w GRE images using dynamic MRI. FSE scanning parameters were TR/TE: 4400/132, fa: 180°, fov: 28 cm. DynMRI parameters were TR/TE: 50Using ERC-PPA coil results in significant improvement of anatomic detail. Specificity increases significantly from 51 % to 96 % (p < 0.008) being important in order to reduce overstaging.

TABREF56.text: Müller-Lisse 1 , M.G. Swanson 2 , D.B. Vigneron 2 , J. Kurhanewicz 2 ;Munich/DE, 2 San Francisco, CA/US Combined MRI and 3D-MR spectroscopic imaging (MRSI) can be adapted for patients on hormone therapy (HT) for locally confined prostate cancer (PCA), such that diagnostic accuracy is equal to patients with untreated PCA. MRI/MRSI was used to determine prostate volume and tumour load in patients on HT for PCA. Three cohorts underwent MRI/MRSI prior to and during therapy consisting of either watchful waiting (WW, n = 7, follow-up 3 months), or short-term HT (n = 13, follow-up 3 months), or long-term HT (n = 14, follow-up 9 months). Prostate volume (total gland TG, central gland CG, peripheral zone PZ) was determined by planimetry in axial, T2-weighted MR images. Tumour load was calculated as (No. of PZ sextants with tumour at both MRI and MRSI)× (% of PZ sextant with tumour at MRI)× (PZ sextant volume at MRI).Prostate volume (TG, CG, PZ) and tumour load decreased significantly during HT (short-term, p = 0.0029 to 0.0007; long-term, p = 0.0041 to 0.0001, paired T-test). TG and PZ increased by 1.5 cm 3 during WW (p = 0.04 to 0.02), while CG and tumour load were unchanged. Tumour load decreased more than PZ volume during long-term HT (p = 0.02, Wilcoxon test), but not during short-term HT.In conclusion, prostate volume and tumour load decrease significantly during HT for PCA. Selective decrease of tumour load relative to prostate size appears to be a feature of long-term HT.Local staging of prostate cancer using magnetic resonance imaging; a meta-analysis M.R.W. Engelbrecht, G.J. Jager, R. Laheij, H. Van Lier, A. Verbeek, J.O. Barentsz; Nijmegen/NL Purpose: To determine the influence of patient, study design, and imaging protocol characteristics on staging performance of magnetic resonance imaging in prostate cancer. Materials and methods: Electronic literature search and review of bibliographies(January 1984 to May 2000. Articles selected included data on sensitivity and specificity of local staging. Subgroup analyses examined the influence of age, prostate specific antigen, tumour grade, hormonal pre-treatment, stage distribution, publication year, department of origin, verification bias, time between biopsy and MR imaging; consensus reading, study design, consecutive patients, sample size, histology preparation, imaging planes, fast spin echo, fat suppression, endorectal coil, field-strength, resolution, glucagon, contrast agents, MR spectroscopy and dynamic contrast-enhanced MRI. Results: 71 articles and 5 abstracts were included, yielding 146 studies. Missing values were highly prevalent for patient characteristics and study design. Publication year, sample size, histological gold standard, number of imaging planes, turbo spin echo, endorectal coil and contrast agents influenced staging performance (p ≤ 0.05). Conclusions: Due to poor reporting, it was not possible to fully explain the heterogeneity of performance presented in the literature. Our results suggest that turbo spin echo, endorectal coil and multiple imaging planes improve staging performance. Studies with small sample sizes may result in higher staging performance.Trans perineal prostate brachytherapy: Comparison of CT vs MRI in the evaluation of prostate volume, and radioactive seeds identification A. Zanello, F. De Cobelli, A. De Gaspari, P. Mangili, N. Di Muzio, A. Del Maschio; Milan/IT Purpose:To compare CT and MRI in the assessment of prostate volume, localization of radioactive seeds and urethra after transperineal prostate brachytherapy. Role of CT and different pulse sequences on MRI. Materials and methods: 15 consecutive patients treated with transperineal interstitial permanent prostate brachytherapy were evaluated (within 3 weeks after implant). Contrast-enhanced helical CT and plain MR (1.5 T, phased-array coils; FSE T2w and SPGR T1w seq.) examinations were conducted in the same session with the same longitudinal coordinates. CT and MRI were separately evaluated by 2 radiologists in order to delineate prostate contour and to identify radioactive seeds. Results: Prostate volume and calculated isodose curves derived from CT, were not statistically different from those calculated with MRI. FSE T2w images were useful to identify prostate volumes, while SPGR T1w images easily identified radioactive sources; both are useful to identify urethra. Conclusions: MRI (FSE T2w + SPGR T1w seq.) is an effective method to evaluate the results of interstitial brachytherapy. It is fast (10 -15 minutes) with almost the same cost (180 USD vs 160 USD) as CT; in this particular case MRI doesn't need i.v. contrast media. So, MRI can sobstitute CT to evaluate patients referred to prostate interstitial brachytherapy.Multicentre randomised comparison of two imaging policies in the management of low back pain: The Scottish back trial F.J. Gilbert, M.G.C. Gillan, M.K. Campbell, N.W. Scott, A.M. Grant, L. Vale, D. Wardlaw, D.J. Knight, the Scottish Back Trial Group; Aberdeen/GBPurpose: The aim of The Scottish Back Trial was to determine whether early use of MRI or CT influences clinical management and outcome of patients with LBP and whether it is cost-effective. Study design: Eligible patients were those with symptomatic lumbar spine disorders (without 'red flags') who were new referrals to orthopaedic or neurosurgeons. Patients giving informed consent, were randomised to 'early imaging' (imaging as soon as possible) or 'delayed, selective imaging' (imaging only if an imperative clinical indication developed). Principal outcome measures were the SF-36, the Aberdeen LBP scale and the EQ-5D. Patients completed questionnaires at trial entry and after 8 and 24 months. Healthcare resource was determined from hospital case notes. Results: From 15 hospitals, 782 patients were recruited and randomised. Both groups received similar clinical management. An improvement in health status was reported by both groups as measured by the SF-36 and the Aberdeen LBP scale with a small but statistically significant difference on the Aberdeen LBP scale in favour of 'early imaging' (P = 0.002) but no difference in SF-36 except a marginal improvement in the bodily pain subscale. Conclusion: For this group of LBP patients, imaging did not significantly affect clinical management. The clinical importance of the slight improvement in health is uncertain. The healthcare resource use in relation to patient outcome has to be judged against other health interventions.The trial was funded by the NHS Research & Development Health Technology Assessment Programme. Views expressed are those of the Scottish Back Trial Group. Early MRI: Its effect on health status and satisfaction in patients with low back pain V.L. Murrie, W. Hollingworth, A.-L. Kinmonth, J.R. Jenner, R.J.C. Laing, A.K. Dixon; Cambridge/GB Purpose: To investigate patients' symptoms and experiences of early Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI) in the diagnosis and management of chronic low back pain.Methods and materials: 168 patients with chronic back pain referred from primary to secondary care consented to be randomised into 2 groups; the first group underwent MRI before seeing a specialist at an outpatient appointment; the second underwent routine clinical evaluation which determined the need for subsequent imaging. We compared patient satisfaction and quality of life between groups. Results: Preliminary data shows that these two groups had similar mean baseline Roland Back Pain scores (MRI: 14.4, non-MRI: 14.66. Both groups had improved scores at 6 months, in fact there was slightly less improvement in the MRI group (to 12.3, 14.5 % clinical improvement) than the non-MR group (to 11.42, 22.1 % clinical improvement) although this difference did not reach statistical significance. Patient satisfaction with their health care was broadly similar, with 61.2 % of the MR group being very/satisfied compared with 57.1 % in the non-MR group. Conclusion: Early MRI makes little difference to the overall health status of the patient or in their satisfaction with the service provided.

TABREF57.text: Non tuberculous vertebral osteomyelitis presenting as acute vertebral collapse V.D. Bousson, B. Buchsenschutz, M. Cohen-Solal, J.-D. Laredo; Paris/FR Purpose: To describe, from a clinical and radiological point of view, a misleading and poorly known entity: a nontuberculous vertebral osteomyelitis presenting as an acute vertebral collapse. Materials and methods: During 13 years, in two musculoskeletal departments, six patients presented with a mix history of acute vertebral collapse and nontuberculous vertebral osteomyelitis. Patients were included only if a pathogen was isolated from the collapsed vertebra or from at least three blood cultures. Two senior radiologists retrospectively reviewed the medical history and the radiological examinations (plain radiographs, and CT or MRI) of these patients to check the following points: age, gender, underlying condition, delay between collapse and infectious syndrom, causative organism, culture sites, outcome, site and degree of vertebral collapse, vertebral osteolysis, disk space narrowing, and soft tissue mass.

Lagalla; Palermo/IT Purpose: To evaluate the role of preoperative Computed Tomography (CT) colonography to study the proximal colon in patients with distal occlusive carcinomas, diagnosed by conventional colonoscopy. Postoperative conventional colonoscopy, which was performed in 18 patients, confirmed the presence of 15 polyps in 12 patients. Three subcentimeter polyps removed during conventional colonoscopy were missed at CT colonography. Two polyps showed by CT colonography were not found at conventional colonoscopy. Postoperative barium enema was performed in three patients and confirmed three polyps identified at CT colonography. Preoperative barium enema was performed in five patients and failed to demonstrate adequately the proximal colon. CT colonography showed a sensitivity of 87 % and a specificity of 75 %.

Conclusions: In contrast to the so far reported MRA and EBCT studies parts of the stent lumen could be visualized in most products by MS-CTA. For example, the MTF of a 500 mm thick needle-IP was still higher than a current 250 mm thick commercial powder-IP and had about twice the X-ray absorption. TABREF84.text: Cirrhotic liver parenchyma was detected in 87 patients. In 47 cases no focal lesions were delineated. A sensitivity of 91.7 % and a specificity of 86.5 % were calculated using iron oxide-enhanced MRI compared with histopathologic findings. Seven false positive diagnosis were assessed concerning small HCC-nodules. Histopathology revealed portal cirrhosis with fibrotic changes and regenerating nodules. Four false negative case were reported missing a trabecular HCC in cirrhosis. Statistical analysis documented a significant improved detection rate using iron-oxide enhanced MRI compared to unenhanced MRI as well as previous conventional examinations (Spiral-CT) (p < 0.05). Conclusion: SPIO-enhanced MRI is an effective imaging tool in the preoperative staging and evaluation of patients concerned for liver transplantation.

To be noted is the observation that the individual results from each participating site were relatively consistent, such that these pooled results are representative. Conclusions: Our results suggest that EIS may be of use in lesion differentiation, particularly in small lesions, in malignancies associated with microcalcifications on the mammogram, in shallow-lying lesions and in older patients.

TABREF96.text: Purpose:The aim of our prospective study was to compare the diagnostic accuracy of planar 99 Tc-Sestamibi scintimammography (SMM) with magnetic resonance mammography (MRM) on the basis of histopathologic results, and to determine the clinical value of these methods as adjuncts to X-ray mammography (XMM). Materials and methods: A total of 96 consecutive female patients with 118 histopathologically verified breast lesions detected by clinical examination and/or XMM were enrolled in the study. Patients underwent SMM and MRM in addition to XMM.

TABREF111.text: Value of harmonic imaging in fetal USA. Sias, V. Alvino, F. Lecca, G. Mallarini; Cagliari/IT Purpose: US harmonic imaging enhances visualization of body structures in difficult patients compared with conventional fundamental imaging (FI). Its role during fetal US imaging is not well established yet. The purpose of this work is to evaluate the role of harmonic imaging in fetal US, in an outpatient clinic setting. Materials and methods: In the period January to September 2001 we performed US obstetric examination in 300 women, as part of standard controls. The examiners acquired the same number of images of fetal organs with fundamental and second harmonic imaging. The investigation time was also recorded for the two different methods. Image quality was subsequently graded independently. Results: Harmonic imaging improved overall fetal heart visualization in all patients, resulting in a modified diagnosis in 14 %, resulting also in lower examination time and diminished recall rate. Image quality was considered better with harmonic imaging, with a statistically significant difference. Conclusion: Second harmonic imaging allowed the visualization of finer details in fetal US, and the easiness of application resulted in a shorter examination time. It was the examination of choice in difficult patients (oligoidramnios, obese, etc).Effect of fetal MRI on cardiotocographic parameters of the unbornS.C.A. Michel, A. Rake, T.M. Keller, V. König, B. Marincek, R.A. Kubik-Huch; Zürich/CH Purpose: To determine whether fetal MRI has any effect on cardiotocographic (CTG) parameters or fetal movement. Materials and methods: MR pelvimetry (T1w FSGPR) and fetal MRI(T2w SSFSE)were performed on six pregnant women (mean 34 weeks GA) on a 1.5 T GE system. Fetal heart rate (FHR) was measured before, during, and after MRI. A technical modification of a standard Doppler ultrasound-based monitor made it possible to reduce interference and distortion in the MR images to acceptable levels, rendering the examinations diagnostic. Maternal heart rate, blood pressure, and body temperature were recorded, and fetal movements were counted. A manual analysis of FHR was performed, and basal FHR and short-term variations were calculated. Results: The mean basal FHR was 131 beats/min before, 135 beats/min during, and 128 beats/min after MRI. Short-term variation was in the normal range for all CTG-tracings. Fetal movements did not increase during MRI. Maternal blood pressure and body temperature were not influenced by the examination. Conclusion: Using technically modified standard equipment, cardiotocographic monitoring of the fetus during MRI is feasible. MRI at 1.5 T does not affect fetal heart activity or fetal movement.Colour Doppler evaluation of ureteral jets in normal second and third trimester pregnancy: Effect of patient position N. Karabulut, A. Karabulut; Denizli/TR Purpose: The study was designed to investigate the effects of patient position on the detection of ureteral jets in normal pregnancy. Materials and methods: The number of jets was recorded for one minute with colour Doppler sonography in 26 healthy asymptomatic gravid women between 16 and 34 weeks' gestation. Each patient was examined in the supine and both in right and left lateral decubitus positions. Results: Ureteral jets were present at least on one side in 24 patients in the supine position versus in 26 women in the lateral decubitus position. Of 24 patients in whom jets were seen in the supine position, 13 (54 %) had jets at only one side. A mean of 1.80 jets/minute was detected on the right, and 3.23 jets/minute on the left (p = 0.046) in the supine position. In the contralateral decubitus position, jets were detected on the right in 22 (84 %) women, and on the left in 25 (96 %) participants. A mean of 3.07 jets/minute on the right and 4.15 jets/minute on the left were re-corded. The difference in the frequency of ureteral jets between supine and lateral decubitus positions was significant (p = 0.004 for the right, and p = 0.011 for the left). Of 13 patients in whom unilateral absence of ureteral jets was noted, 10 (77 %) had detectable jets in the lateral decubitus position. Conclusion: Our findings demonstrated the utility of lateral decubitus position in the evaluation ureter suspicious for obstruction. However, caution is still recommended in diagnosing ureteral obstruction if jets are persistently absent after this manoeuvre.MR assessment of fetal lung development using measurements of lung signal intensities and volumesT.M. Keller, A. Rake, S.C.A. Michel, B. Seifert, N. Teodorovic, S. Wildermuth, B. Marincek, R.A. Kubik-Huch; Zürich/CH Purpose:The aim of this study was to investigate the potential of MR in the assessment of fetal lung development and in the diagnosis of pulmonary pathology by measuring signal intensity and fetal lung volume changes at different stages of gestation. Methods: 18 fetuses (22 -39 weeks of gestation) were examined once on a 1.5 T GE system using T2w single shot fast spin echo imaging. 7 fetuses were scanned at 25, 30, and 35 weeks of gestation for a longitudinal assessment of lung development. Ratios of the signal intensities (SI) of fetal lung and liver as well as amniotic fluid and maternal muscle were calculated. Fetal body, lung and liver were segmented manually, and volumes were calculated. Estimated volumes were correlated with gestational age. Data of 3 fetuses with lung pathology (2 adenoidcystic malformations, 1 lung sequester) were compared with the normative data. Results: Fetal lung volume varied from 15 to 179 cm 3 , the relative lung volume expressed as a percentage of the fetal body volume showed a range from 2.1 % to 4.9 % and decreased with gestational age (p < 0.01). Fetal lung and liver volume correlated well with gestational age (p < 0.01). The SI ratios of fetal lung to maternal muscle and amniotic fluid showed no change while the SI ratios of fetal liver to fetal lung, maternal muscle and amniotic fluid decreased with gestational age (p < 0.01). Conclusion: MR normative data of fetal lung signal intensity and volume may have important clinical applications in the confirmation and quantification of fetal pulmonary hypoplasia.MRI of fetal pathologiesT.M. Keller, N. Petrovic, A. Rake, J. Wisser, S.C.A. Michel, S. Kollias, T.A.G.M. Huisman, B. Marincek, R.A. Kubik-Huch; Zürich/CH

TABREF112.text: Fetal MRI is a valuable adjunct to sonography in the prenatal evaluation of fetal malformations. Furthermore it is an efficient diagnostic tool for evaluating maternal disorders during pregnancy.MRstaging of pelvic endometriosis; a comparison with American fertility society laparoscopic staging: A prospective study R. Zanardi 1 , C. Zuiani 1 , C. Del Frate 1 , G. Del Frate 2 , M. Bazzocchi 1 ; 1 Udine/IT, San Daniele del Friuli/IT Purpose: To introduce MR staging of pelvic endometriosis in comparison with the AFS laparoscopic staging. and methods: 30 consecutive females, with clinically suspected endometriosis, underwent MR examination using TSE T1, T2W, and SE FAT-SAT T1W sequences demonstrating the presence of endometriomas and pelvic implants. Laparoscopy was performed within one week. Two radiologists independently evaluated the presence of endometriomas and implants, and calculated a score classifying endometriosis in four categories, comparable with those of AFS laparoscopic staging. The MR score was based on size, edge, parietal thickness, segmentations, signal intensity on T2W images of endometriomas and presence of pelvic implants. Results: Laparoscopy confirmed 38/39 endometriomas, ranging in size from 1 to 11 cm, detected by MR, with only one false positive due to a hemorrhagic corpusluteum. Nevertheless, 2 intraovaric endometriomas were detected by laparoscopy only due to MR guidance. Implants were discovered in 17/30 patients with MR, laparoscopically in 18/30. MR detected 42 endometrial implants out of 52 detected by laparoscopy (80.8 %). 13/42 were directly confirmed by laparoscopy, 29/42 were confirmed depending on the presence of adhesions. Regarding endometriosis staging, concordance between the MR and AFS classification was obtained in 29/30 patients (96.6 %) with only one case of discordance. Conclusions: Although MR has limitations such as suboptimal depiction of small implants and adhesions, this technique is very useful as guidance for laparoscopy. Moreover the optimal concordance (96.6 %) between the MR staging purposed on this work and laparoscopic staging demonstrates a new advantage of MR in preoperative staging of endometriosis. 3D MR vs conventional X-ray hysterosalpingography in the evaluation of female infertility F. Iannessi, G. Cerone, F. D'Emidio, C. Di Berardino, G. Mascaretti, E. Di Cesare, C. Masciocchi; L'Aquila/IT

TABREF113.text: 15:10 Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of deep endometriosis: signal intensity varies according to localization of the lesions C.S. Balleyguier, C. Chapron, B. Vincent, A. Millischer, O. Hélénon, Y. Menu; Paris/FR Purpose: To describe the variation of MRI features of deep endometriosis according to localization.Methods and materials: Preoperative MRI were reviewed in 140 patients with deep endometriosis. All patients had sagittal and axial fast T2 and T1-weighted spin echo (SE) sequences with a phased-array coil. 45 patients had additional examination with an endocavitary coil. Visibility, signal intensity, size and contour of the lesions were analysed. Results: 173 lesions were diagnosed by surgery and pathology: uterosacral ligaments (USL n = 112), recto-vaginal wall (RVW n = 25), visceral endometriosis (VE n = 20) and bladder endometriosis (BE n = 16). MRI detected all bladder and rectovaginal lesions. Bladder endometriosis lesions were heterogeneous and hyperintense on T1 and T2 images. Conversely, RVW lesions were hypointense as compared to myometrium (n = 25). Sensitivity of MRI for detection of USL and VE lesions was 71 % and 70 % respectively. Abnormal USL were larger (> 9 mm) than normal USL (< 7 mm). Nodular contour was found in all abnormal USL and in none of normal USL. Most of USL and VE lesions were hypointense on T1 and T2 images (LUS n = 65/80), (VE n = 15/20). Only 25 % of the posterior lesions (USL, RVW, VE) showed hyperintense spots. Conclusion: Although deep endometriosis may be found in most compartments of the pelvis, appearance of the lesion may differ according to localization. Signal intensity is variable with localization of the lesions: posterior lesions are more likely to be hypointense in T1 and T2 images. Knowledge of this particularity may prevent the radiologist from overlooking posterior lesions.

TABREF114.text: Whole-body MRI with a moving table technique as a screening tool for metastases in patients with breast carcinomaK. Engelhard 1 , H.-P. Hollenbach 2 ; 1 Nuremberg/DE, 2 Erlangen/DE Purpose: Presentation of preliminary experience of a whole-body MRI technique with a moving table as a screening tool for metastases in patients with breast cancer. Material and methods: 17 patients with breast carcinoma underwent both a planar whole body bone scintigraphy and whole-body MRI at 1.5 T. MRI images were performed with an automatically moving table at 5 different anatomical positions within a measurement time of 20 minutes. Coronal images were acquired using a STIR sequence from head to the feet, accomplished by an axial T2-weighted TSE sequence through the head and a T1-eighted opposed-phase sagittal Flash-2D sequence covering the whole spine. Findings of bone scintigraphy and MRI were compared with respect to the consideration that metastases were absent or present. Each examination was graded into three categories: benign, uncertain origin or malignant on a standardized evaluation sheet. Metastatic lesions were confirmed by follow up over one year including diagnostic follow-up procedures.Results: Whole-body MRI was superior to bone scintigraphy in predicting lesion dignity with a sensitivity of 86 % (bone scintigraphy: 86 %), a specificity of 90 % (scintigraphy: 70 %) and an accuracy of 88 % (scintigraphy: 76 %). Whole-body MRI showed additional findings as metastases of the brain. lung and liver. Conclusions: Whole-body MRI with a moving table technique may represent a convenient and fast method of total body screening for metastases in patients with breast carcinoma, esspecially in women with high risk of distant metastatic disease.Breath-hold fast recovery optimized fast spin echo pulse sequence: Comparison with breath-hold half-Fourier and non breath-hold respiratory triggered fast spin echo pulse sequences for T2-weighted liver MR imaging J. Augui, O. Vignaux, C. Argaud, J. Coste, H. Gouya, P. Legmann; Paris/FR Purpose: To evaluate breath-hold Fast Recovery (BHFR) fast spin echo (FSE) magnetic resonance (MR) pulse sequence for T2-weighted MR imaging of the liver. Materials and methods: The addition of Fast Recovery to a FSE imaging technique was developed to provide an improved T2 weighting and signal compared with a conventional FSE sequence and to allow full liver coverage in two breath holds. Quantitative and qualitative characteristics of images obtained prospectively in 38 patients were compared with those provided by a conventional respiratory-triggered FSE sequence and by a breath-hold single shot half-Fourier fast spin echo sequence (SSFSE). Results: The mean signal-to-noise ratio for liver and contrast-to-noise ratio for hepatic lesions were significantly higher with BHFR than with respiratory-triggered FSE (p < 0.01) while they were comparable between both breath-hold techniques. BHFR images enabled significatively better lesion conspicuity than SSFSE (p < 0.05) and displayed less image artifacts than respiratory-triggered FSE sequence (p < 0.02). Lesion sizing and overall image quality were improved with BHFR sequence compared with SSFSE and non breath-hold FSE pulse sequences (p < 0.02). Conclusion: Our results may validate the use of the BHFR technique for first line T2-weighted MR imaging of the liver.

There was a significant difference between benign (2.45 ± 0.96) and malignant lesions (1.08 ± 0.50, p < 10 −3 ). Conclusion: Diffusion MRI, with the help of ADCs, can help characterize FLL and differentiate benign from malignant lesions.

TABREF118.text: 16:55Assessment of altered hepatic haemodynamics associated with liver tumours using functional MR E. Leen, J. MacQuarrie, W.G. Angerson, C.S. McArdle, J. Anderson, P. Horgan; Glasgow/GB Purpose: To assess the hepatic haemodynamic changes associated with liver tumours using functional MR. Methods: 36 patients with proven focal hepatic lesions (22 metastases and 14 patients with benign haemangiomas) were studied using Philips Gyroscan (1.5 T). Dynamic contrast enhanced (2 ml of Omniscan and 20 ml of saline at 2 ml/s) scan using 2D-FFE sequence with single transverse slice (20 mm) was performed through the liver. Data acquisition over a period of 100 seconds was subsequently recorded for quantification analysis. Time-intensity curves were derived from regions of interests placed over the liver and aorta. Peak enhancement (PE), time to peak (TP) & gradient (G) of the steepest portion of the curve for the liver and peak aortic enhancement (PA) were measured. Results: There was no significant difference in the TP, G and PA indices between the benign and malignant group. However there was a significant increase in the PE in presence of malignancy (metastases vs haemangiomas: 371 ± 176 vs 193 ± 53; p < 0.0001). PE to PA ratio was also significantly raised in patients with metastases. Conclusion: These preliminary data suggest that altered hepatic haemaodynamic changes associated with malignancy can be assessed using functional MR; Further refinements in the technique are still required.Safety of mangafodipir administration at abdominal MR imaging: Bolus injection vs. slow infusionC. Bernhard, W. Schima, A. Stadler, E. Schober, C. Loewe, I. Nöbauer, C.J. Herold; Vienna/AT Purpose: To assess the safety of the liver-specific MR contrast agent mangafodipir (Teslascan®) administered as a bolus in comparison with slow infusion. Materials and methods: 112 patients with suspected liver lesions underwent MRI at 1.5 T (Siemens Vision; Philips ACS-NT). In 59 patients (25 m, 34 f; mean age 55.2 a), mangafodipir (dosage of 5 µmol/kg) was administered as an IV bolus injection (18 ml/min) over 1.4 -2.8 min. In a control group of 53 patients (30 m, 23 f; mean age 53.4 a), mangafodipir was administered as a slow infusion over 10 -20 min, at the clinically approved rate. The rates of patient discomfort and adverse events after contrast administration were assessed. Examination times of both study protocols were evaluated. Results: There was patient discomfort after contrast administration in 33.9 % of the bolus injection and 32.1 % of the slow infusion control group (not significant). Mild to moderate adverse events were observed in 6.8 % of the rapid injection and 3.8 % of the control group (n. s.). Mean MR examination time was 41.2 min (bolus) and 45.1 min (control group) (P < 0.05). Conclusion: Bolus administration of mangafodipir does not increase the rate of patient discomfort or adverse events in comparison to the approved slow infusion, but it may speed up the examination.Parallel imaging (SENSE) improves VIBE sequences for dynamic contrast MR studies of the liver M. Dobritz, F.A. Fellner, M. Nittka, J. Wang, A. Schmid, W.A. Bautz; Erlangen/DEPurpose: Aim of this study was to evaluate potential advantages of paralell imaging in liver diagnostics. SENSE was used to shorten investigation time in VIBE sequences to acquire dynamic contrast studies of the liver in high resolution images.

TABREF119.text: Virtual endoscopy of the common biliary tract with 3D T2-weighted static fluid MR cholangiography. A prospective study C. Vasilescu sr., C. Roy sr., L. Solair sr., D. Coumaros sr., M. Filippi de la Palavesa sr., C. Tuchmann sr., D. Mutter sr.; Strasbourg/FR Purpose: Evaluate accuracy of virtual endoscopy (VE) cholangio MR to study biliary tract common duct obstructions. MR Philips) using a T2w 3D TSE (TR/eTE: 1800/500 ms, ETL: 130, 0.6 mm, 80 slices, 256, TA: 4 min 12 s). VE images were reconstructed using volume rendering technique and interpreted together with overall examination images (MIP reconstructions, source images). Correlations with conventional endoscopy and pathological findings. Results: Operator time: 20 min. MR sequences, as well as reconstructed images, missed stones inferior to 3 mm in size. VE depicted all stones superior to 4 mm. Among 10 calculi, ranged from 4 to 8 mm, detected on VE, source images and conventional T2w, 3 (4 and 5 mm, respectively) were invisible on MIP. Tumoral stenosis presented an irregular and asymetric pattern on endoluminal views. Morphologic assessment (smooth or irregular surface, location and extension in surface of tumoral filling defects) was better seen on VE than on source images. A smooth surface with abrupt margins was present in all cases of stones. With the surface structure alone, the differentiation between a calculus from a smooth polypoid tumor was impossible. Conclusions: VE is simple to realise, more accurate than MIP for identification of calculi. It allows an interesting evaluation of the morphology of a common duct stenosis. But to detect calculi, source images and conventional T2-weighted sequence are mandatory and essential for diagnosis.Virtual MR cholangioscopy: Feasibility and diagnostic accuracy of MRCP combined with endoluminal views K.A.J. Hellerhoff, S. Aratma, T. Rösch, T.M. Link, E.J. Rummeny; Munich/DE Purpose:To evaluate the feasibility of virtual MR-endoscopy (VMRE) of the biliary tract on the basis of MR-cholangiopancreatography (MRCP) data sets and to determine the diagnostic benefit combining MRCP with endoluminal views using ERCP as a standard of reference. Methods and materials: 31 patients were examined at 1.5 T with a respiratory triggered 3D TSE sequence. For VMRE intraluminal views were generated by volume rendering. Multiplanar reformations of MRCP alone vs multiplanar reformations and VMRE were compared with the ERCP findings. Results: Virtual reconstructions of the common bile duct (CBD), the common hepatic duct and right and left hepatic duct were feasible in 30/31 patients. The final diagnoses was: bile duct stones (n = 7), bile duct strictures (n = 19) and normal bile duct (n = 4). Using endoluminal views in addition to MRCP images did not alter the sensitivity for choledocholithiasis (71 %). One of two false positives using MRCP (specificity 91 %) was assessed as normal using the endoluminal reconstructions (specificity 96 %). For the detection and localization of bile duct stenosis with MRCP the sensitivity and specificity was 100 %. With VMRE 15/19 bile duct strictures were depicted. 4 cases of prepapillary stenosis could not be differentiated from the intrapapillary end of the bile duct. Conclusion: The additional use of VMRE did not improve the sensitivity in the diagnosis of choledocholithiasis. MRCP was superior to VMRE in depicting CBD stenosis, especially in the distal portion of the duct. VMRE therefore can not yet be recommended for the routine work-up of the biliary tract.Imaging patients with post-cholecystectomy syndrome (PCS): An algorithmic approach O.A. Terhaar, S. Abbas, F.J. Thornton, D. Duke, K. Abdulla, J.C. Varghese, M.J. Lee; Dublin/IE Purpose: To evaluate the role of MRC, US, LFT's and ERCP in patients with PCS. Method and materials: 57 patients (M:F, 15:42; age 33 -92 years; mean age 62) with PCS referred for diagnostic ERCP, had MRC and abdominal US performed.The interval from cholecystectomy ranged from 1 -600 months. MR (1.5 T; GE) images were obtained using a T2W (TR/TE; 11000/272) 2D-FSE multislice technique (18 × 3 mm, coronal and axial slices, FOV 20 -24 cm, matrix size 256 × 128, ETL 32, NEX 1 -3). Images were correlated with LFT's, ultrasound and ERCP findings. Results: 18 (32 %) patients had final diagnosis of choledocholithiasis. 1 patient had a biliary stricture. 16 patients had unrelated diagnoses made and 22 had no cause for pain identified. Ultrasound identified CBD stones in 5 of 18 patients (28 %), all of whom had dilated CBD's (≥ 10 mm). ERCP failed in 11 Patients, five of whom had stones while MRC identified 17 patients with stones (94 %). The CBD was dilated on US (≥ 10 mm) in 17 patients, 10 of whom had stones. A dilated CBD (≥ 10 mm) had a PPV of 59 % for choledocholithiasis whilst a normal calibre CBD (< 10 mm). had a NPV of 90 %. The overall accuracy of US was 76 % which increased to 80 % when LFT's were analyzed. Conclusion: Sonography remains the first line test in PCS. The Accuracy of US is marginally increased when LFT's are analyzed. In patients with CBD size of (< 10 mm) on US further MRC/ERC is not warranted. MRC should be performed in patients with a dilated CBD on US (≥ 10 mm).Erroneous diagnosis of intraductal papillary mucinous tumorsof the pancreas (IPMT): Frequency, type and pathologic correlation M. Kara, P. Hammel, M.-P. Vullierme, V. Vilgrain, B. Terris, Y. Menu; Clichy/FR Purpose: Determine the frequency and the nature of pancreatic lesions mimicking IPMT on conventional imaging and correlate the definitive pathologic findings with imaging studies. Materials and methods: Upon 75 patients (42 men; aged: 26 -76 years) undergoing surgery for suspicion of IPMT between 01/1994 and 10/2000, 8 (10.8 %) patients (6 women; aged: 35 -59 years) had finally another affection: chronic pancreatitis (alcoholic (n

TABREF120.text: An erroneous pre-operative diagnosis of IPMT occurred in 10.8 % patients. This rate must be reduced to avoid invasive surgical sanction.Infectious cholangitis: Imaging findings on MRI T.R. Bader 1 , L. Braga 2 , K.L. Beavers 2 , R.C. Semelka 2 ; 1 Vienna/AT, Chapel Hill, NC/US Purpose: To evaluate the appearance of infectious cholangitis on MRI. Methods and materials: The MR images of 13 patients (9 women, 4 men; age range, 14 -79 years) with clinically confirmed infectious cholangitis were retrospectively evaluated. All MR studies were performed at 1.5 T including: in-phase and out-of-phase T1-weighted spoiled gradient echo (SGE), T2-weighted fat-suppressed echo train spin echo, single shot T2-weighted sequences, and serial postgadolinium T1-weighted SGE sequences without and with fat-suppression. The biliary ductal system was evaluated regarding presence of dilatation, steno-sis, wall irregularities, wall thickening, and gadolinium enhancement of duct walls. The liver parenchyma was evaluated regarding focal signal abnormalities on precontrast and serial postgadolinium images. Results: Biliary ductal dilatation was observed in 100 % of patients. Mild to moderate thickening of bile duct walls combined with increased enhancement on postgadolinium images was observed in 92 % of patients. The liver parenchyma showed periportal or wedge-shaped areas of hyperintense signal on T2-weighted images in 69 % of patients. On T1-weighted images, 54 % of patients showed areas of hypointense signal and 15 % of patients showed wedge-shaped hyperintense areas. Areas with increased enhancement on immediate postgadolinium SGE were observed in 58 % of patients, and in 42 % of patients increased enhancement persisted on 2 minute postgadolinium fat-suppressed images. Conclusion: Infectious cholangitis demonstrates characteristic MRI findings on pre-and postgadolinium images.CT-cholangiography after intravenous injection of iodinated biliarycontrast agent F.J. González, C. Juanco, R. Landeras, M. Ruiz, M. López, M. Silván; Santander/ESPurpose: Spiral CT cholangiography (sCTC) has received little attention but it is capable of yield high resolution images and functional imaging regarding the biliary tree. This study evaluates the role of sCTC in the diagnosis of biliary tree anatomy and diseases comparing with other diagnosis technique. Method/materials: We briefly review the examination technique, indications, limitations and interpretation pitfalls of sCTC. The studies were performed after infusion with 50 ml intravenous iodinated biliary agent (Meglumine Iotroxato, Bilisegrol, Schering AG) diluted in 100 ml saline. Examination delay raged from 40 to 120 minutes after injection depending on bilirubin seric level. sCTC studies were performed with 3 mm collimation (1 mm reconstruction interval/pitch 1.5). The sets of source images were used to generate 2D and 3D (MIP and Surface) reformations. We compared the results with other diagnosis modalities (Ultrasound, MR cholangiography and CPRE) being CPRE and surgery the standar references. Results: Opacification of the biliary tree was considered optimal for diagnosis in 98 % of cases with a good evaluation of biliary anathomy and congenital variants. SCTC showed a good sensitivity (94 %) to detect common duct biliary stones and biliary stenosis. It was a good technique to evaluate the patency of biliodigestive anastomoses and biliary leaks. Its was also useful to evaluate biliary tree complications in liver trasplantation. Dinamic evaluation of biliary excretion is an important information that this method add comparing with other diagnosis modalities. Conclusions: SCTC is a good noninvasive method to evaluate biliary tree with a good diagnosis capability.Evaluation of pancreas divisum with CT cholangiopancreatography after secreatin stimulation: Comparison with MR cholangiopancreatographyS. Kiryu, M. Minami, M. Akahane, N. Yoshioka, H. Koga, M. Watanabe, I. Nakajima, K. Ohtomo; Tokyo/JP Purpose:The purpose of this study is to assess the diagnostic performance of CT cholangiopancreatography (CTCP) after secretine stimulation compared with MR cholangiopancreatography (MRCP). Methods: 84 patients suspected of having pancreatic diseases were studied with CTCP and MRCP. CTCP was performed with multi-detector row CT. Two minutes after administration of secretine, dynamic CT was performed 45 seconds after injecting iodinated contrast material at rate of 3 ml/s. Sections were obtained using 2.5 mm detector row and pitch of 3. The images were reconstructed at 1.25 mm interval using 24 cm field of view. Minimum intensity projection images of the pancreas head were obtained by selecting an oblique slab that contained the main pancreas duct and common bile duct. MRCP was performed with a 1.5 T unit. Multiple oblique coronal images were obtained using two-dimensional heavily T2weighted single shot fast spin-echo sequence; TR/TE ∞/1100 ms; section slice, 35 -45 mm; field of view, 25 -35 cm. Endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP) was performed in all patients as gold standard.Results: There was no complication induced by secretine stimulation. Nine patients were confirmed to have pancreas divisum by ERCP. CTCP depicted eight of the nine patients before ERCP. MRCP depicted all of the nine patients. However, one patient having anomalous arrangement of the pancreaticobiliary duct was diagnosed to have pancreas divisum by both CTCP and MRCP. Sensitivity, specificity and accuracy of CTCP were 88.9 %, 98.7 % and 97.6 %, while those of MRCP were 100 %, 98.7 % and 98.8 %.Conclusions: CTCP showed high accuracy in the diagnosis of pancreas divisum compared with MRCP. TABREF123.text: Pulmonary rhodococcus equi infection in HIV+ patients: Radiological findings P. Cabassa, R. De Paolis, F. Simeone, M.R. Cristinelli, R. Maroldi; Brescia/IT Purpose: To describe the spectrum of radiological characteristics of this rare opportunistic pneumonia in HIV+ patients. Methods & materials: From January 1992 to March 2001, 18 HIV+ patients withRhodococcus Equi infection (isolated from blood or sputum) were identified. All patients were free of concomitant infections. The clinical signs consisted in a sub-acute onset of respiratory symptoms and fever. All patients had chest X-ray examination within 3 days of bacterial isolation. Location, type and evolution of each radiological finding were evaluated. CT was performed in 9/18 patients. Results: 16/18 patients had persistent or progressive parenchimal abnormalities at chest X-ray. The chest X-ray findings in all patients were that of large dense areas of pulmonary consolidation, most of them with cavitations (10/16; 62.5 %). Upper lobe, or superior segments of the lower lobe, prevalence was noted. CT confirmed radiological findings and revealed 1 more cavitation and two cases of peribronchial dissemination. Pleural effusion (2/16 cases) and lymphadenopathy (2/16) were not common findings. Follow-up examinations showed a long term persistence of consolidations in most patients. Conclusions: Rhodococcus equi pneumonia should be considered in the differential diagnosis of pulmonary cavitary lesions in HIV+ patients. Knowledge of the clinical and imaging features of this infection may help suggest a particular diagnosis.Are technetium-DTPA pulmonary clearance studies of value in the diagnosis of radiation pneumonitis? Gleeson; Oxford/GB Purpose: To evaluate the detection of radiation pneumonitis by 99 Tc DTPA lung clearance in the irradiated and contralateral lung in patients undergoing radiotherapy for lung carcinoma, and compare with high resolution computed tomography.

TABREF124.text: Determination of different inspiratory time constants by dynamic CT. First experiences in patientsA.P. Gerhards, K. Markstaller, M. Doebrich, J. Karmrodt, B. Eberle, N. Weiler, M. Thelen, H.-U. Kauczor; Mainz/DEPurpose: Previous studies demonstrated that different pulmonary time constants (Tc) can be differentiated by dynamic-CT. Goal was the first application of this novel technique in patients with early ARDS for optimization of ventilatory pattern. Methods: In patients with ARDS and diffuse infiltrates on the chest radiograph a multislice-CT was performed. If there were signs of atelectasis or early ARDS, a dynamic-chest-CT serie was performed with the following parameters: slicethickness of 1 mm, collimation of 0.5 mm, reconstructionincrement of 0.1 mm resulting in a temporal resolution of 350 ms. For assessment of pulmonary Tc, a step-up in airway pressure from 0 to 40 cm H2O was performed during dynamic-CT acquisition. For planimetrical calculation of areas of defined density ranges the range between −910 and −300 HU has been defined as aerated lung parenchyma. The relative lung area of this density range during the step-up in airway-pressure was plotted against time and was analysed to identify different inspiratory Tc, assuming a two compartimental model. Results: An inspiratory Tc of 1.0 s was found which comprised 86 % of total recruitable lung area. The remaining 14 % of the lung followed a slow time constant of 7.2 s. Based upon these results the respiratory parameters were modified to allow longer inspiratory time. Within the three hours following the change of the ventilatory pattern oxygenation improved significantly. Conclusion: Dynamic-multiscan-CT allows to determine different regional Tc in patient with early ARDS. Lung compartments with long Tc can hardly be reached by conventional ventilation. Dynamic-CT may represent a promising new technique to optimize ventilatory patterns in ARDS.Multislice CT virtual bronchoscopy and multiplanar reformats for grading of tracheobronchial stenosisH. Hoppe, B. Walder, G. von Allmen, P. Vock, H.-P. Dinkel; Berne/CH Purpose: To determine the diagnostic value of noninvasive multislice CT (virtual bronchoscopy, axial CT slices, coronal reformats and sagittal reformats) in depicting and grading tracheobronchial stenosis versus that of flexible bronchoscopy. Methods and materials: Multislice CT and flexible bronchoscopy were used to examine 200 bronchial sections from 20 patients (n = 15 bronchial carcinoma, n = 5 without central airway pathology). CT data were obtained on a multislice CT in 4 × 2 mm collimation, pitch 5.5/4 and 2 mm reconstruction intervals. Postprocessing was performed using surface rendering and multiplanar reformats (MPR). CT images were independently interpreted by two radiologists. Flexible bronchoscopy was graded by a chest physician. Results: Virtual bronchoscopy, axial CT-slices and MPR were highly accurate (98 % accuracy for virtual bronchoscopy, 96 % for axial slices and coronal reformats, 96.5 % for sagittal reformats) in the detection of tracheobronchial stenosis. Virtual bronchoscopy correlated closely (r = 0.91) with flexible bronchoscopy in the grading of tracheobronchial stenosis. Because virtual bronchoscopy reduced overestimation of stenosis, it enabled better assessment of stenosis compared to axial CTslices (r = 0.84) or MPR images (r = 0.84) alone. Conclusion: Multislice CT virtual bronchoscopy is a reliable non-invasive method that enables accurate grading of tracheobronchial stenosis. It should be combined with axial CT-slices and MPR for evaluation of surrounding structures and optimal spatial orientation. Multislice CT provides high-resolution endoluminal views and MPR with a short scan time despite thin collimation.Segmentation of the tracheo-bronchial tree on radiological images leading to an individualized simulation of drug delivery and uptake S. Ley 1 , D. Mayer 1 , B.S. Brook 2 , E.J.R. van Beek 2 , C.P. Heussel 1 , M. Thelen 1 , H.-U. Kauczor 1 ; 1 Mainz/DE, 2 Sheffield/GB

TABREF125.text: Role of combined CT hepatic angiography and CT during arterial portography in the diagnosis and management of patients with hepatocellular carcinomas and liver metastases K. Furuichi, A. Furukawa, M. Yamasaki, K. Maeda, M. Ohnishi, M. Takahashi, K. Murata; Otsu/JP Purpose: To evaluate the role of combined CT hepatic angiography (CTHA) and CT during arterial portography (CTAP) in the diagnosis and management of patients with hepatocellular carcinomas (HCC) and liver metastases. Methods and materials: 51 patients with HCC and 13 patients with liver metastases were referred for CTHA and CTAP prior to surgery or interventional therapy. The final diagnosis was established by either surgery or by clinical observation. Alterations of diagnosis and management resulting from CTHA and CTAP information were recorded. Results: In patients with HCC, diagnosis was altered regarding number, location and extent of lesions in 39 %, 39 %, and 10 % of the patients, respectively. Overall, alterations of diagnosis were performed in 47 % of the patients and they were correct in 75 % of the time. Alterations of management were performed in 31 % of the patients in total, and they were correct in all but one. In the patients with liver metastases, diagnosis was altered regarding number, location and extent of lesions in 31 %, 23 % and 0 % of the patients, respectively. Overall, alterations of diagnosis were performed in 31 % of the patients and they were correct in 50 % of the time. Management was not altered after CTHA and CTAP in the patients with liver metastases. Conclusion: CTHA and CTAP provide valuable clinical information for patients with HCC and corrected their previous diagnosis and plans of management in a significant number. CTHA and CTAP should be performed in patients with HCC when either surgical or interventional therapy is their treatment option.Full organ CT liver perfusion of cancer patients displayed with volume rendering techniques T. Hahn; Würzburg/DE Purpose: Phosphorous metabolites are vital for regular hepatic function. 31 P-MR-Spectroscopy (MRS) allows non-invasive insight into hepatic energy metabolism.Recently, we reported about a new method for assessement of cardiac metabolism using SLOOP (Spectral Localization with Optimal Pointspread Function). Here, we present the first data regarding metabolite concentrations in healthy and diseased human liver. Methods: 31 P-spectra were acquired using a double resonant surface coil on a 1.5 T Magnetom VISION. TABREF127.text: Triple-phase multislice CT in patients at high risk for hepatocellular carcinoma R. Iannaccone, A. Laghi, P. Rossi, I. Carbone, I. Baeli, R. Ferrari, F. Mangiapane, R. Passariello; Rome/IT Purpose: To evaluate whether the use of triple-phase (early arterial, late arterial, and portal-venous phase) multislice CT improves the detection of hypervascular hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC). Methods and materials: 75 patients with 137 hypervascular HCCs underwent triple-phase multislice CT of the liver. Two ml per kg of contrast material were administered at 4 -5 ml/s. Early and late arterial phase were obtained within a single breath-hold. Portal-venous phase required a second breath-hold. Study parameters were: slice collimation, 2.5 mm; slice thickness, 3.0 mm; table feed, 10.8 mm/s. Analysis of early arterial, late arterial, double arterial (early arterial and late arterial phases combined), and triple-phase (double arterial and portal venous phases combined) images was performed separately by three radiologists. Sensitivity and positive predictive value (PPV) were calculated. Results: Average sensitivity and PPV for the detection of hypervascular HCC were 40.7 % and 90.2 % for the early arterial phase, 83.7 % and 90.4 % for the late arterial phase, 83.7 % and 90.4 % for the double arterial phase, and 85.9 % and 92.1 % for the triple phase, respectively. The analysis of the double arterial phase did not yield any improvement both in sensitivity and PPV compared to the analysis of late arterial phase alone. The addition of the portal-venous phase to image interpretation provided the highest sensitivity and PPV. Conclusion: Combined evaluation of late arterial phase with portal-venous phase was essential to achieve optimal detection of hypervascular HCC. The addition of an early arterial phase did not provide any benefit either in terms of sensitivity or PPV.Hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC): Technical biopsy considerations and histologic prognostic factorsT. Petsas, A.C. Tsamandas, C.P. Kalogeropoulou, I. Tsota, N. Samaras, T. Kordonouri, K. Tepetes, I. Dimopoulos; Patras/GR Purpose: Prognosis of HCC is related to histologic type, grade of the tumor and expression of molecular factors (apoptosis, cell proliferation and oncogenes). In this study we evaluated the adequacy of biopsy material and expression of prognostic factors in specimens obtained following tumor resection. Materials and methods: 20 patients with HCC underwent resection of the tumor. Following excision of the tumor multiple biopsies were obtained, using: 24, 23, 22, 21, 20, 18 G aspiration needles, 23, 21, 20, 18 G/TIP-CUT aspiration needles, 14 G, 16 G, 18 G, 20 G/9 cm/20 T TRU-CUT core biopsy and the Rotex needle. Pathologic evaluation included histochemical and immunohistochemical stains. Following microscopic examination the specimens were classified as adequate [identification of histologic type, estimation of tumor grade, evaluation of prognostic factors and evaluation of additionally obtained non-neoplastic liver tissue [architecture (fibrosis degree) and activity (inflammation degree)] were possible], intermediate (diagnosis of malignancy and identification of histologic type were possible, but evaluation of non-neoplastic liver tissue was not), and non-adequate (the specimen was not sufficient for histopathologic examination and diagnosis of malignancy could not be established). Results: According to the aforementioned criteria, adequate specimens were obtained when: 14 G, 16 G, 18 G, 20 G/9 cm/20 TRU-CUT and 18 G/TIP-CUT needles were used, intermediate, when 20 G/TIP-CUT, 18, 20, 21, 22 G and non-adequate when 24, 23, 23 G/TIP-CUT needles and Rotex needle were used. Conclusion: Our study suggests that histologic confirmation of HCC is possible when certain needles are used. Further studies have to be made in order to determine the specific needle characteristics, for correct histopathologic diagnosis.Hepatocellular carcinoma in non-cirrhotic liver: CT and clinico-pathologic findings in 39 United States residents G. Brancatelli 1, 2 , M.P. Federle 1 , L. Grazioli 3 , B.I. Carr 1 ; 1 Pittsburgh, PA/US, Palermo/IT, 3 Brescia/IT Purpose: To review the clinical, pathological, and helical multiphasic computed tomography (CT) findings in 39 patients with hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) in a noncirrhotic liver. Materials and methods: Authors retrospectively evaluated the clinical, pathologic and imaging findings in 39 patients with HCC in non-cirrhotic liver. Helical multiphase CT was performed in all patients. Images were reviewed for morphologic features of tumours such as size, margins and haemorrhage and degrees of enhancement.Results: There were 25 men and 14 women with a mean age of 61; 62 % of patients had no identifiable risk factors and 87 % were symptomatic HCC was proved and cirrhosis excluded by biopsy in all cases. The HCC was moderately (n = 32) or well (n = 6) differentiated in 97 % of cases and poorly differentiated in one. Large tumours (mean diameter, 12.4 cm) were depicted at CT in all cases. 32 patients had a solitary or dominant mass. At CT, the margins of the tumours were well defined in 21 patients (54 %), with a lobulated surface in 33 (85 %). Calcifications were depicted in 11 (28 %), haemorrhage in 10 (26 %), fat in 4 (10 %). The HCC were hypoattenuating in 34 patients (87 %) on unenhanced images, heterogeneously hyperattenuating on arterial phase in 38 patients (97 %), and hypoattenuating in 35 patients (90 %) on portal phase. Conclusion: In our patients, HCC developed in the absence of cirrhosis or known risk factors and typically appeared as a large, symptomatic hepatic tumour with clinical, laboratory and CT features that distinguish it from most other hepatic masses.Local recurrence of hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) after percutaneous ablation procedures: Category-based managementO. Catalano, B. Cusati, A. Giorgio, L. Tarantino, A. Siani; Naples/IT Purpose: To report our experience in the detection and treatment of recurring HCC in patients initially treated successfully with percutaneous procedures. Recurrence management was based on our original categorisation system. Methods and materials: During 4 years there were 50 patients showing recurrence after single-or multisession percutaneous ethanol injection (PEI), laser photocoagulation, or radiofrequency thermotherapy. These subjects were categorized by using a previously published personal system based on imaging findings: (A) intranodular recurrence (tumour regrowth within the margin of necrotic former lesion), (B) perinodular recurrence (growth around the lesion border), (C) segmental recurrence (growth in the same segment of treated nodule, without continuity with the original lesion). Results: Five patients showed a pattern A, developed after multisession PEI, and were treated percutaneously with success. There were 16 subjects showing a pattern B that were managed by using transarterial chemoembolisation (TACE), alone (n = 12) or combined with percutaneous treatments (n = 4); complete necrosis was obtained in 9 cases. There were 38 patients with pattern C that were treated with TACE and/or percutaneous procedures, depending on number and size of new nodules; complete necrosis was achieved in 22 cases. One subject underwent surgery. Conclusion: Patients with exclusive local regrowth after percutaneous ablation can still be managed effectively. Treatment modality should be chose according to the imaging recurrence pattern.Multicentric origin of sporadically recurrent hypervascular hepatocellular carcinomas in cirrhotic livers: Retrospective analysis by repeated CT during arterial portography and CT during hepatic arteriography O. Matsui, S. Kobayashi, N. Terayama, J.-I. Sanada, T. Gabata; Kanazawa/JPPurpose: To analyse the multicentric origin of sporadically recurrent hypervascular hepatocellular carcinomas (HCC) in cirrhotic livers by the retrospective observation of repeatedly performed CT during arterial portography (CTAP) and CT during hepatic arteriography (CTHA). Materials and methods: 33 cirrhotic patients (hepatitis C related 26, B 7) with a solitary hypervascular classical HCC locally well-controlled by local ablation therapy or transcatheter arterial embolization in whom repeated CTAP and CTHA were carried out within two years and less than five recurrent new hypervascular HCCs were found were subjected to the study. The HCC patients with portal venous tumor thrombi or small hypervascular daughter nodules surrounding the main HCC nodule were excluded. A total of 77 hypervascular HCC nodules were analysed. When the nodule showed decreased arterial supply relative to the surrounding liver and the existence of intranodular portal flow indicating borderline lesion of HCC on the previous CTHA and CTAP, it was diagnosed as multicentric origin. Results: 56 out of 77 hypervascular recurrent HCC nodules (73 %) were originated from borderline lesions. In the remaining 21 nodules, a tiny entirely hypervascular nodule or no definite nodule was detected on the previous CTHA and CTAP. Conclusion: In B or C virus-related cirrhotic livers, more than 70 % of sporadically recurrent hypervascular HCCs seen following the treatment of a solitary hypervascular HCC were considered to be multicentric origin (not metastasis). This fact is very important for the management of cirrhotic patients.CT imaging of liver tumors -a study to determine specificity and prevalence of capsular retraction A. Trojanowska, E. Czekajska-Chehab, K. Rosinska-Bogusiewicz, A. Drop; Lublin/PL Purpose: To investigate if a liver capsule retraction is a specific sign of a malignant liver tumor in CT examination.

TABREF129.text: Linear measurements made off-line from previously scanned 3D datasets are sufficiently accurate to replace measurements made by skilled operators during real-time abdominal ultrasound examinations.Volumetry of the spleen obtained by ultrasound: A prospective study in 465 patients M.A. Bertoni, N.E. Sclavi, A. Tersol, E. Uslenghi, M. Ozuna; Bahia Blanca/AR Purpose: To evaluate relationship between volumetry of the spleen by ultrasound and sex, weight and height in a prospective series of 465 normal patients. Materials and methods: In a period of 24 months 465 patients' records with no evidence of haemopoietic disorders, who underwent an ultrasound examination of the abdomen, were examined. Sex, weight, height and linear dimensions of the spleen were tabled. "Forward stepwise" multiple regression analyses were performed, considering volumen, longitudinal, transverse and ventrodorsal diameters of the spleen as independent variables, and height, weight and age as dependent in both sexes. Analyses for males and females separately, were also performed. Results: The whole series showed regression between weight, height and age, as dependent, and craneocaudal diameter of the spleen as independent, with R = 0.6374; R2 = 0.4063; F (3.461) = 105.16. Regression parameters increase when variables are transformed into logarithms. Males showed regression between weight and craneocaudal diameter of the spleen with R = 0.6518; R2 = 0.4248; F (3.124) = 30.53. In females, regression was found between height, weight and age, as dependent; and craneocaudal diameter of the spleen as independent variable, with R = 0.5679; R2 = 0.3225; F (3.333) = 52.85. No other regression models were found between mentioned variables. Conclusion: Spleen's longitudinal diameter was predictable in 40 % of the patients in our series, while a wide variation was seen for both sexes. Spleen's longitudinal diameter in males is more predictable when weight in considered as dependent variable. Height, weight and age are to be considered in females, but their ability in predicting longitudinal diameter of the spleen is less accurate.High resolution multislice CT in the preoperative evaluation of laparoscopic splenectomy C. Catalano, A. Laghi, F. Fraioli, F. Pediconi, A. Napoli, R. Brillo, I. Reitano, R. Passariello; Rome/IT

TABREF130.text: Results: 34 endoprosthesisis were placed on the 32 patients. Fourteen patients had an adequate biliary drainage, resulting in a successful drainage rate of 43.7 %. The decrease of the RHD/LHD and intrahepatic bile ducts were semnificative in case of an adequate biliary drainage. Aerobilia was present in the drained lobe in all cases with successful drainage. The positive and negative predictive values for aerobilia assessed on day 3 after stenting were 66 % and 70 %. The proximal end of the endoprosthesis was correctly visualized in 81.2 % of cases. Conclusions: In the evaluation of an endoscopic biliary drainage in proximal obstructions, the importance of ultrasound examination is based on the correct assessment of the endoprosthesis position and of the bile ducts size above the stenosis. In these cases aerobilia has a limited value.Study of pulse inversionmode with the late phase of Levovist to detect hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) in cirrhotic liver E. Quaia 1 , C.J. Harvey 2 , M.J.K. Blomley 2 , D.O. Cosgrove 2 , W. Gedroyc 2 ;Trieste/IT, 2 London/GB Purpose: To evaluate if Pulse Inversion Mode (PIM) with the late phase of Levovist can improve hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) conspicuity and detection, compared to baseline ultrasound (US), using magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) or helical CT as reference examinations. Methods and materials: To date, 23 consecutive cirrhotic patients, with known HCC or suspected on alphafetoprotein rise, were evaluated by baseline US and PIM 3 minutes after intravenous injection of Levovist. Subjective conspicuity of HCC was evaluated by comparing PIM to baseline US and grading conspicuity as worse, unchanged or improved. Each lesion suspected to be an HCC was counted. HCC diagnosis was proved by biopsy or autoptic assessment and/or imaging features. Lesions not proved as HCCs were excluded. Results: HCC conspicuity improved in all cases. In 5 patients no HCC was detected by all imaging techniques. In the remaining 18 patients, in comparison to baseline US, PIM revealed the same number of lesions in 13 patients and an higher number in 5 patients. In comparison to reference examinations, PIM revealed the same number of lesions in 16 patients and an higher number in 2 patients. Average number of detected HCCs for patient was 1.47 for US, 2.13 for PIM and 1.95 for reference examinations. Difference between PIM and US was found statistically significant (p < 0.05), while difference between PIM and reference examinations was found non-significant (p = 0.161). Conclusions: PIM with Levovist improves detection of HCC if compared to baseline US and presents a similar sensitivity to helical CT and MRI.Sonographic characterisation of focal liver lesions using new blood pool contrast agent with non-linear imaging modes E. Leen 1 , D. Becker 2 , D. Strobel 2 , J. MacQuarrie 1 , P. Horgan 1 ; 1 Glasgow/GB,Erlangen/DEPurpose: To assess the use of SonoVue in the characterisation of focal liver lesions using non-linear imaging (NLI) modes. Methods: 36 patients with focal liver lesions (12 with metastases, 11 HCCs, 7 haemangiomas & 6 others) were studied using ATL5000 & Siemens/Elegra scanners. NLI mode, fundamental B-mode & power Doppler (PD) imaging were performed at baseline. NLI imaging of the hepatic lesion was then carried out at low MI (0.1 -0.3) immediately after an IV administration of SonoVue (dose: 2.4 ml). Biopsy or combined CT/MR & markers were used as "reference standard". Diagnosis was established on the basis of tumour vascularity & pattern of enhancement. Comparison and correlation between the US and CT/MR enhancement findings were also performed. Diagnostic accuracy (% agreement) and performance of contrast enhanced US in identifying the lesion as benign or malignant were analysed. Results: The rank-correlation between contrast-enhanced US and CT/MR classifications of tumour vascularity was highly significant in arterial phase (r = 0.92, p < 0.001) and portal phase (r = 0.73, p < 0.001). Of the benign tumours, 83 % were classified as indeterminate, 8 % as probably benign and 8 % as almost definitely benign using baseline US. On contrast enhanced US, 92 % were classified as definitely benign and 8 % as almost definitely benign. All haemangiomas (even those measuring less than 1.5 cm) showed progressive centripetal contrast uptake. The improvement in diagnostic classification was highly significant for both malignant and benign tumours (p < 0.001, Wilcoxon). Conclusion: These results suggest that SonoVue enhanced non-linear imaging modes may be useful in improving the characterization of focal liver tumours.Comparative evaluation of MR imaging and sonography in hydatid liver diseaseI. Sansoni, A. Laghi, I. Carbone, I. Baeli, R. Iannaccone, S. Trenna, V. Panebianco, R. Passariello; Rome/IT Purpose: To evaluate the reliability of MRI in detecting and characterizing hydatid cysts of the liver in comparison with sonography. Materials and methods: 47 patients with suspected hepatic hydatid disease (positive serological tests), underwent both hepatic MR imaging and liver sonography. All MR examinations were performed on a 1.5 T superconductive system, acquiring both T1 and T2 weighted images. Diagnostic confirmation of cystic nature was based on surgical findings, cytologic examination (after PAIR aspiration) or integrated clinical, serological, imaging findings and follow-up response to therapy. PPV 97.10 %). The 68 sonographic examinations characterized hydatid cysts with accuracy 91.18 %, sensitivity 93.65 % and PPV 96.72 %. Agreement between sonography and MR imaging was observed in 63/68 (92.65 %) lesions, whereas disagreement was observed in 5/68 (8.8 %) cysts. Conclusions: No significant differences were observed between MRI and sonography in identifying and characterizing liver hydatid cysts. Therefore MRI should be reserved to cases with doubtful sonography, to complicated cysts and to pre-surgical planning.Evaluation of hepatic tumors vascularization on C3-mode bidimensional gray scale US after contrast agentM. Silván, F.J. González, P. Sadaba, R. Landeras, M. López, C. Juanco; Santander/ES Purpose: The evaluation of a focal liver mass is a complex issue that is often the major focus of a cross sectional imaging study including two essential elements: lesion detection and lesion characterization Both of these are improved on sonography with the addition of contrast agents and the use of specialized imaging techniques We employ the C3-mode (Combined Contrast Chain, Esaote) to characterize focal liver lesions after intravenous injection of microbubble contrast agent. Method and material: We evaluate 35 previously detected and evaluated hepatic tumors (10 hemangiomas, 10 HCCs, 10 liver metastases 3 FNH and 2 adenomas) in 35 patients with C3 mode using a Technos sonography scan (Esaote, Italy). The images were obtained before and after injection of as bolus of 3 g microbubble contrast agent (Levovist (Schering, Germany) with incremental interval delay scaning technique. Results: The hemangiomas revealed peripheral and progressive enhancement with centripetal filling-in. Most of the HCCs showed early enhancement after injection with rapid wash-out in portal phase. Metastases showed a sharply hypoechogenicity comparing with normal liver parechyma with a soft rim-like enhancement on early phases. FNH showed intense and early enhancement on arterial phase with homogeneous filling-in during the examination. The enhancement of adenomas was heterogeneous. Conclusion: US evaluation of hepatic lesions on C3 mode after US contrast injection is a good method to characterize the tumors. The results are equivalent to other dynamic (CT, MRI) techniques.Diagnostic accuracy of tissue harmonic imaging (THI) versus conventional B-mode scan (BM) in the evaluation of pancreatic abnormalities with ultrasound C. Hohl, T. Schmidt, M. Blaum, G. Staatz, J. Meyer, D. Honnef, R.W. Günther; Aachen/DE Purpose:To compare the diagnostic accuracy of conventional ultrasound and THI in patients with pancreatic abnormalities. Material and methods: In a prospective study 66 patients, aged between 28 and 85 years with a total of 31 pancreatic lesions underwent ultrasound examinations with a Siemens Sonoline Elegra scanner. The patients underwent a CT-scan of the upper abdomen as a diagnostic gold standard. TABREF131.text: MR imaging of lymph nodes metastasis with a superparamagnetic contrast media G. Morana 1 , E. Motta 1 , G. Pollini 1 , F. Bonetti 1 , F. Pellini 1 , M. Brunelli 1 , L. Grazioli 2 , C. Procacci 1 ; 1 Verona/IT, 2 Brescia/IT Purpose: To evaluate the possibilities of diagnosing lymph nodes metastasis with USPIO-enhanced MRI. Material/method: 8 patients with suspected axillary lymph nodes metastasis from breast carcinoma were evaluated. MRI imaging 24 hours after i.v. injection of ferumoxtran (SINEREM) was conducted with 1.5 T magnet with surface coil with SE T1w, TSE DPw and FLASH T2w sequences. For each lymph node minimum axis and signal intensity (hypo/iso/hyperintensity) with sequences sensitive to SINEREM were recorded. Diagnosis was made according to these parameters and to subjective impression with and without SINEREM. All patients were surgically evaluated within 15 days MR examination, and all lymphnodes were send for pathological evaluation.Results: 95 lymph nodes were found at surgical exploration, of whom 58 (61.1 %) visible at MRI. Mean diameter of non visible lymph nodes was 2.5 mm. 14/58 visible lymph nodes were metastatic, 42/58 normal, 2/58 inflammatory. Sensitivity, specificity, PPV and NPV for each parameter was calculated: minimum axis > 1 cm(28.6 %, 97.7 %, 80 % and 81.1 %); subjective impression with SINEREM-insensitive sequence (42.9 %, 93.2 %, 66.7 % and 83.7 %); signal intensity with SINEREM-sensitive sequence (92.9 %, 54.5 %, 39.4 % and 96 %); subjective impression with SINEREM-sensitive sequence (85.7 %, 86.4 %, 66.7 % and 95 %).
